Designing is a key activity in architecture, landscape architecture, urban planning, design and engineering. The design, as the result of a design process, can remain a purely intellectual idea. As a rule, however, the term design is understood to mean a representation and presentation in the form of texts, drawings, graphics, models and calculations.

Name: Ignaz-L.-Lieben Prize for Physics, Chemistry and Physiology

Name: Large-scale nature conservation project in the Thuringian Rhön

Name: Turing system
Definition: Theory (model, idea) of pattern formation in animals and plants developed by A. Turing within mathematical biology. According to H. Haken, the Turing model has proved its worth as a conceptual basis for explaining a range of pattern formation processes in chemical and biological processes.

Name: Virtual laboratory
Definition: Form of (partial) virtualization of teaching methods of laboratory experiments, especially in the natural sciences and engineering, for multimedia and interactive learning

Name: Mesokosmos

Name: Neurowissenschaften

Name: Copley Medal

Name: John Fritz Medal

Name: Nanowissenschaften

Huxley gave to samples from the sea floor in 1868 (named after Ernst Haeckel) and which he described as a primeval creature (primordial ooze); after the Challenger expedition in 1875, it turned out to be colloidally precipitated calcium sulphate, which occurred due to the addition of alcohol in which the samples had been preserved; Huxley then called Bathybius Blunderibus (blunder = mistake, blunder).

Name: Tempestit
Definition: Storm-induced sediment, can also be caused by tsunamis

Name: Seam gas
Definition: Methane in coal seams

Name: Schungit
Definition: Impure anthracite coal, partly converted into graphite

Name: Speleothem
Definition: Secondary mineral deposition

Name: Verrucano
Definition: Verrucano, named after Monte Verruca near Pisa, series of rocks characterized by coloured quartz conglomerate in the Permian and Lower Triassic in the Alps, Apennines and adjacent areas

Name: Buchit
Definition: Vitrified sandstone, which is formed on contact with basalt at high temperatures

Name: Pandermit
Definition: after Panderma on the Sea of Marmara; triclinic mineral; used in the production of boric acid and other boron compounds.

Name: Wachskohle
Definition: Purest form of liptolite; forms nodular and nest-shaped deposits in carbonized coal seams

Name: Schwelkohle
Definition: Bitumen-rich lignite suitable for lignite smelting

Name: Palite stone
Definition: Rock compound of biotite gneiss, granulite and amphibolite

Name: Leogangit
Definition: Blue-green, light green in the line color, transparent mineral; chemical formula: Cu10[(OH)6|SO4|(AsO4)4]·8H2O

Name: Bodenmatrix
Definition: In soil science, term for the solid components of the soil

Name: Ullmannit
Definition: Mineral from the mineral class of sulfurides

Name: Kieselkalk
Definition: Siliceous limestones are gray to dark gray hard rocks, mainly consisting of the minerals calcite and quartz

Name: Cobalttsumcorit
Definition: Light brown mineral belonging to the group of phosphates, arsenates and vanadates

Name: Auerbach marble
Definition: Metamorphic rock, which occurs in an approx. 2 km long strip in the Odenwald near Auerbach

Name: White peat
Definition: Entsteht im Hochmoor

Name: Milling village
Definition: Milled peat is extracted from the surface of peat bogs by removing a layer 1 - 2 cm thick

Name: Kallmünz geology
Definition: Silicified sandstones from the Upper Cretaceous period

Name: Windkanter
Definition: Edged stone cut by wind grinding

Name: Takonit
Definition: for banded iron ores from the USA; iron-bearing Precambrian sedimentary rock, iron can be extracted using technical processes

Name: Coltan
Definition: An ore whose main deposit is located in Central Africa and from which the metal tantalum (Ta) is primarily extracted. The name "coltan" is derived from the mineral group columbite-tantalite (coltan = short form). Columbite itself (according to Römpp) is a niobite and tantalite. Coltan is classified as a conflict mineral. Coltan mining in the Congo is mainly concentrated in the Lake Kivu region in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Internationally known since 2004 due to the battles over exploitation rights between Rwanda and Congo. Coltan is a necessary raw material for the computer and cell phone industry.

Name: Ankerit
Definition: Brown spar named after the mineralogist Matthias Joseph Anker from the mineral class of anhydrous carbonates without foreign anions

Name: Biomineral
Definition: Biominerals are compounds of minerals and biomolecules. They are formed by various plants and animals to build particularly strong tissue structures (biomineralization).

Name: Rock crack system
Definition: The fissure system in the rock is an artificially created fissure system in which the natural fissure system present in the rock is artificially widened by means of injected fluid (water).

Name: Flammenmergel
Definition: Lithological unit of the Lower Cretaceous (Alb) in Germany, slightly clayey to slightly sandy marlstone, named for its mottled appearance

Name: Schmirgel
Definition: Fine-grained mixture of corundum with magnetite, hematite and quartz as natural deposits; mainly used as an abrasive

Name: Geochemikerin
Definition: Eigener Studiengang

Name: Antigorit
Definition: a common mineral from the serpentine group within the mineral class of "silicates and germanates"

Name: Dopplerit
Definition: Accumulation of humus gel in peat; named after the Austrian mathematician and physicist Christian Andreas Doppler

Name: Xanthokon
Definition: a rare mineral from the mineral class of sulphides and sulphosalts

Name: Lithos database
Definition: Mineral collection management for Windows 95/98/ME and Windows NT, main parts are a database with all minerals recognized by the IMA until December 2000 and a database for the management of levels of the own collection

Name: Labradorit
Definition: Plagioclase, a relatively common mineral mixture of albite and anorthite from the group of feldspars and the mineral class of silicates

Name: Pennin
Definition: Pennine is a mineral that forms thick tabular crystals of a bluish green color

Name: Akanthit
Definition: The mineral silver luster occurs as a cubic high-temperature modification, argentite, and as a monoclinic low-temperature modification, acanthite.

Name: Danburit
Definition: Mineral from the mineral class of silicates and germanates

Name: Geode
Definition: in sediments concretions, in metamorphic and magmatic rocks secondary filling of bubble cavities. Filling of bubble cavities

Name: Cerussit
Definition: Lead mineral from the carbonate group

Name: Black smoker
Definition: Submarine hydrothermal hydrogen sulphide springs with temperatures >350 C Celsius

Name: White smoker
Definition: Submarine hydrothermal springs with more temperatures <350 C Celsius, precipitation of predominantly barium sulphate

Name: Phenakit
Definition: Trigonal mineral with the chemical composition Be2[SiO4]

Name: Amazonit
Definition: Green gemstone, mineral variety of microcline

Name: Gelberde
Definition: Soils of different origins colored yellow by iron oxide compounds due to humus depletion

Name: Römerite
Definition: rarely occurring mineral from the mineral class of sulphates (and relatives); it develops yellowish-brown to reddish-brown crystals

Name: Hörnesite
Definition: Mineral from the mineral class of phosphates, arsenates and vanadates; Mg3(AsO4)2-8H2O

Name: Krokoit
Definition: monoclinic, yellow-red mineral with the chemical composition Pb[CrO4]

Name: Descloizit
Definition: brown-red to almost black, rhombic mineral with the chemical composition Pb(Zn, Cu)[OH|VO4] ; belongs to the mineral class "phosphates, arsenates, vanadates"

Name: Bournonit
Definition: gray to black, rhombic mineral with the chemical composition PbCuSbS3 ; belongs to the mineral class sulfides and sulfosalts

Name: Mandelstein
Definition: volcanic or subvolcanic rock with numerous bubble cavities (almonds, geodes) that have been completely or partially filled with mineral substances

Name: Triphylin
Definition: bluish to greenish gray, rhombic mineral with the chemical composition Li(Fe, Mn)[PO4]

Name: Ternesit
Definition: Ca5[SO4|(SiO4)2; calcium sulfosilicate; was registered by the I.M.A. in July 1995 under the number 95-015

Name: Dufrenite
Definition: Ca0.5Fe2+Fe3+5(PO4)4(OH)6-2H2O; rather rare mineral from the mineral class of phosphates

Name: Beraunit
Definition: Fe2+Fe53+(PO4)4(OH)5-4H2O; mineral from the mineral class of phosphates, arsenates and vanadates

Name: Kakoxen
Definition: (Fe3+,Al)25[O6|(OH)12|(PO4)17]-75 H2O ; mineral from the mineral class of phosphates, arsenates and vanadates

Name: Andersonit
Definition: Mineral from the mineral class of carbonates and nitrates; Na2Ca(UO2)(CO3)3-6H2O

Name: Syngenit
Definition: K2Ca(SO4)2-H2O

Name: Astrakanit
Definition: Na2Mg(SO4)2-4H2O

Name: Freieslebenit
Definition: AgPbSbS3

Name: Diaphorit
Definition: Pb2Ag3Sb3S8

Name: Atacamit
Alternate Name: Salt copper ore, according to Abraham Gottlob Werner
Definition: is a rather rare mineral from the halide mineral class

Name: Botryogen
Definition: Botryogen is a rather rare mineral from the mineral class of "sulphates, selenates, tellurates, chromates, molybdates and tungstates"

Name: Druse mineralogy
Definition: a former cavity (geode) in the rock that is incompletely filled with various types of crystals

Name: Leuchtenbergit
Definition: Low-iron clinochlorine variety. (Mg,Fe2+)5Al(Si3Al)O10(OH)8

Name: Hells Bells stalactite
Definition: bell-shaped underwater dripstones discovered in water-filled cenotes on the Yucatán Peninsula, Mexico

Name: Hösbachite
Definition: Variety of the chlorite-hornblende rock or talc-chlorite-amphibole rock found exclusively in the Hösbach region to date, named by its discoverer Martin Okrusch after the place where it was found

Name: Ablagerungsmilieu
Definition: Geological term describing the environmental conditions under which a sediment was deposited; is specified by attributes such as eolian, glacial, marine, etc.

Name: Halloysit
Definition: monoclinic clay mineral

Name: Lawsonit
Definition: CaAl2[(OH)2/Si2O7] ⋅ H2O Mineral from the mineral class of silicates and the order of group silicates (sorosilicates).

Name: Citrin
Definition: Light yellow to golden brown quartz variety

Name: Milchquarz
Definition: Whitish, milky-cloudy quartz variety due to liquid or gas inclusions

Name: Sulfosalze
Definition: Salts of thioacids; metal arsenide sulphides and metal antimonide sulphides.

Name: Glacial channel
Definition: Gullies eroded by meltwater under glaciers and/or inland ice

Name: Slurry chalk
Definition: Very fine, high-quality chalk, cleaned by slurrying and dried to powder; slurry chalk is used as a pigment for water-based or distemper paints, as a polishing agent (polishing lime) and is also used in cosmetics and cleaning agents when processed

Name: Wettervorhersage
Definition: Exceptionally also to be used for existing forecasts, but without annual figures

Name: Blitz
Definition: Only for natural spark discharge

Name: Thirty-millibar surface
Definition: S. Keil: Handw. d. Meteorology

Name: High atmosphere
Definition: Summarizing f. Stratosphere, mesosphere and thermosphere

Name: Aeronomie
Definition: Science of the ionosphere and magnetosphere

Name: Air layer close to the floor
Definition: Air layer of a few meters to a few decametres in thickness lying directly on the ground

Name: Gletscherkunde
Definition: The branch of glaciology that deals with glaciers

Name: Vereisung
Definition: used for the formation of ice on bodies; e.g. on airplanes, as a generic term for glaciation and in medicine

Name: Windfahne
Definition: Meteorolog. Measuring instrument

Name: Unwetter
Definition: Associated with storm damage, erosion and flooding

Name: Glaziologie
Definition: Branch of research concerned with the study of frozen water in all its forms.

Name: High wind
Definition: Air mass movement in the upper atmosphere

Name: Afroalpine stage
Definition: Alpine stage d. afric. High mountains

Name: Gebietsniederschlag
Definition: Total precipitation in a catchment area

Name: Makroklima
Definition: The SW climate is preferred, especially in connection with geographics, e.g. Wales / climate

Name: Long-distance transportation
Definition: Only use for substances in the atmosphere etc., not for goods

Name: Hugo Hurricane
Definition: Hurricane on the US coast, 1989

Name: Air flow
Definition: Only for atmospheric flows

Name: Thermal tides
Definition: Periodic process due to the absorption of solar radiation in the atmosphere

Name: Hydrometeor
Definition: Total precipitation of water vapor in the atmosphere

Name: Telekonnektion
Definition: Connection between two weather processes in distant areas

Name: Bergwind
Definition: Downhill air flow, antagonist to the valley wind

Name: Eddytransport
Definition: Transport due to disturbances in the atmosphere

Name: Cleaning precipitation
Definition: Cleaning the atmosphere, e.g. through rain

Name: Ionospheric storm
Definition: Spatially extended strong currents in the upper ionosphere

Name: Kaltlufteinbruch
Definition: Supply of cold air masses

Name: Wetness
Definition: Mainly used for the moisture of surfaces, e.g. traffic routes (rain wetness)

Name: Wetterbeeinflussung
Definition: Only for artificial influence, not for the effects of environmental damage, etc.

Name: Bright ribbon
Definition: Transition area in a cloud between snow and rain

Name: Windklima
Definition: Climate characterized by strong winds

Name: Boreonemoral area
Definition: Transition zone between boreal coniferous forest zone and nemoral deciduous forest zone

Name: Andrew Hurricane
Definition: Hurricane in Florida, 1992

Name: Jahreszeitenklima
Definition: Climate with changing temperatures

Name: Catabatic wind
Definition: Heavy, cold downdraft

Name: Hangwind
Definition: Air flow on slopes

Name: Mitch Hurricane
Definition: Hurricane in Central America, 1998

Name: Secondary aerosol
Definition: Secondary aerosol

Name: Prandtl layer
Alternate Name: Boundary layer close to the ground
Definition: Lower 10 % of the atmospheric boundary layer with an average height of 100 m

Name: Windprofiler
Definition: Meteorolog. Remote sensing system for measuring wind and temperature

Name: Einstrahlung
Definition: Total radiation that reaches an atmospheric layer or the earth's surface

Name: Bestandsklima
Definition: Special climatic conditions prevailing in plant populations, formations and communities

Name: Stormtrack
Definition: Characteristic spatial pattern of the standard deviation of synoptic-scale fluctuations in geopotential height

Name: Stockbarometer
Definition: The stock barometer is used as a measuring instrument for determining the weather. It consists of a cardanic suspension to which a glass body with a mercury filling is attached. If the temperature and air pressure change due to warm or cold fronts, the position of the mercury column also changes and you can see what weather change is imminent.

Name: Lothar Orkan
Definition: Winter storm over Western Europe, 26.12.1999

Name: Little ice age
Definition: Modern glacier advance phase from around the end of the 16th century to around 1850

Name: Vivian Orkan
Definition: Winter storm over Western and Central Europe, 26-28.2.1990

Name: Clearness Index
Definition: Relationship between global irradiation and extraterrestrial irradiation on the horizontal plane

Name: Global Atmosphere Watch
Definition: International program to collect data on chemical composition and changes in the atmosphere

Name: Katrina Hurricane
Definition: Tropical cyclone in south-eastern parts of the USA, 2005

Name: AEROS research satellite
Definition: German research satellite for studying the high atmosphere; AEROS-A was deployed 1972-1973, AEROS-B 1974-1975

Name: Deep cloud
Definition: Cloud family according to altitude (cloud levels):0-200km altitude

Name: Dunst
Definition: Meteorology: Clouding of the atmosphere at a visibility of more than 1 km.

Name: Rita Hurricane
Definition: Strongest hurricane to date in the Gulf of Mexico, 2005

Name: Energiemeteorologie
Definition: New branch of research dealing with the development of methods and the acquisition of data for the optimization of solar and wind energy systems

Name: Mittwinter
Definition: Time of the winter solstice, which can extend over December and January.

Name: Kyrill hurricane
Definition: Winter storm over Europe, 18./19.01.2007

Name: Planet Simulator
Definition: Modeling software for climatology / paleoclimatology

Name: Cyclone Nargis
Definition: Tropical cyclone in the northern Indian Ocean, 2008

Name: Cyanometer
Definition: Histor. Instrument for measuring the color intensity of the blue sky color

Name: Okklusionsfront
Definition: Union of a cold front with a warm front

Name: Jeanett Orkan
Definition: Storm over Europe on October 27/28, 2002

Name: Wetterdrachen

Name: Niklas Orkan
Definition: Storm depression that moved across Europe from 30.03.-01.04.2015

Name: Austauschkoeffizient

Name: Altweibersommer

Name: Polar mesospheric summer echoes
Definition: Radar echoes from an altitude of 80-90 km that occur at polar latitudes

Name: Barograf
Definition: Barometer equipped with a recording device for creating a barogram

Name: Weltraumwetter
Definition: Changes in the interplanetary and interstellar medium that are perceived especially in the near-Earth region of the magnetosphere

Name: Friederike Orkan
Definition: Winter storm over Europe with its peak on 18.01.2018

Name: Columbus Day Storm Typhoon
Definition: Northwest wind storm that hit the west coast of Canada and the Pacific Northwest coast of the United States on October 12, 1962.

Name: Wetterleuchten

Name: Eisheilige
Definition: Days of cold air intrusions in mid-May

Name: Xaver hurricane
Definition: Hurricane over Northern Europe, December 2013

Name: Sabine Orkan
Definition: North Atlantic low, peak February 9/10, 2020

Name: Climate Prize of the Borken district
Definition: Awarded annually since 2001 for climate protection activities and projects in the Borken district

Name: Astrobiologie
Definition: Deals with extra-iridian life

Name: Kosmologie
Definition: Scientific study of the structure and development of the universe.

Name: Weltraumforschung
Definition: Space exploration with the help of space travel

Name: Relativistic astrophysics
Definition: Astrophysics on the basis of the general theory of relativity

Name: Extraterrestrial intelligence
Definition: Predominantly, i.e. not only for speculative presentations

Name: Spektralklasse
Definition: Used for the spectral class as a distinguishing criterion for stars

Name: Compact object
Definition: Summarizing term f. White dwarf, neutron star or black hole

Name: Active galaxy
Definition: Galaxy with active nucleus

Name: Astrodynamik
Definition: Astrodynamics is sometimes used synonymously with celestial mechanics, but refers specifically to the movement of artificial bodies in the gravitational field.

Name: Coma astronomy
Definition: Gas shell on the head of a comet

Name: Massive star
Definition: Stars with masses above the Chandrasekhar mass

Name: Solar activity
Definition: Includes sunspot maximum, prominences, flares, filaments

Name: Spiralgalaxie
Definition: Type of regular galaxies in which the majority of stars and gas nebulae are arranged in the form of spiral arms, which usually attach to opposite points of an only weakly oblate nucleus

Name: Zenitkammer
Definition: Astrogeodetic measuring instrument

Name: Pancake theory
Definition: Hypothesis of galaxy formation

Name: Tag
Definition: day as opposed to night and for the astronomical day

Name: Eureca
Definition: Reusable spacecraft of the ESA

Name: Umlaufbahn
Definition: Orbit of a natural or artificial satellite or celestial body around a single other celestial body

Name: Delta Cephei star
Definition: Group of stars with certain characteristics, not designation of a single star

Name: Hubble Space Telescope
Definition: Commissioned in 1990

Name: R-Coronae-Borealis star
Definition: Type class changeable stars

Name: Mirastern
Definition: Long-period variable giant and supergiant stars, mainly of spectral class M, named after Mira in the constellation of Whale

Name: Flare
Definition: Link e.g. with the sun or other star names

Name: Hochenergieastronomie
Definition: Collective reference for X-ray and gamma astronomy

Name: Infrarotquelle
Definition: Only for astronomy

Name: MOMS
Definition: Earth observation instrument developed by MBB. Launched June 1983 and February 1984

Name: Edge-on-Galaxie
Definition: Galaxy appearing in edge-on view from Earth

Name: Landsat/TM
Definition: Sensor for recording land use of small-scale structures

Name: Radialgeschwindigkeit
Definition: Used for astronomy

Name: Downfall Astronomy
Definition: Link to the respective celestial body

Name: Space debris
Definition: Space debris consists of artificial objects with no utility value that are in orbit around the Earth and pose a threat to space travel.

Name: V-max method
Definition: Method for approximate calculation of the luminosity function

Name: OLBI
Definition: Astronomical observation with several telescopes whose beams are coherently superimposed, analogous to aperture synthesis in radio astronomy

Name: SETI
Definition: Research programs to search for electromagnetic signals that could originate from extraterrestrial civilizations; since the first modern search for extraterrestrial artificial radio signals, over 100 SETI projects have been carried out worldwide

Name: Evershed effect
Definition: Radial flow from the sunspot

Name: Himmelsdurchmusterung
Definition: Large-scale observation for stocktaking; def. in B 1986 for survey is not up to date

Name: Cosmic dust
Definition: includes interplanetary, interstellar, intergalactic, circumstellar, etc. Dust

Name: HEGRA
Definition: Large-scale detector system for high-energy cosmic gamma radiation on the Canary Islands

Name: Magellan space probe
Definition: Venus probe launched in 1989

Name: Spektralklassifikation
Definition: Used for the classification systems and the classification process

Name: CGRO
Definition: 1991-2000 in orbit

Name: Rotation modulation collimator
Definition: Astronom. Instrument

Name: Horizontalaststern
Definition: Star on the horizontal branch in the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram for globular clusters

Name: UX-Ursae Majoris star
Definition: Doppelsterntyp

Name: Protoneutronenstern
Definition: Stage after gravitational collapse, radius approx. 100 km, from which the star slowly contracts into a neutron star (radius approx. 10 km)

Name: Zentralregion
Definition: Central area of a galaxy

Name: Platonic year
Definition: Comprises about 25850 solar years, the period in which the Earth's axis orbits the pole of the ecliptic once as a result of precession

Name: CHAMP satellite mission
Definition: Satellite mission for geoscientific exploration of the earth, the satellite launch is scheduled for 1999; launch on July 15, 2000

Name: Voyager program
Definition: Macintosh planetarium program

Name: Voyager II Program
Definition: Macintosh-Planetariumsprogramm

Name: Pathfinder space probe
Definition: Mars probe launched in 1996

Name: Kalenderjahr
Definition: In contrast to the financial year

Name: Himmelsregion
Definition: Part of the starry sky that includes several constellations

Name: D1 mission
Definition: German space mission, 1985

Name: Riesenplanet
Definition: Massive planet of low density (mainly gaseous)

Name: MOS Scanner
Definition: Developed in DLR and launched in 1996 on board the Indian earth observation satellite IRS-P3

Name: D2 mission
Definition: German space mission, 1993

Name: Milankovič's radiation curve
Definition: From the long-period. Calculated and graphically represented curve of the intensity of solar radiation on the earth

Name: Pulsation Astronomy
Definition: Regular expansion and contraction of the outer layers of stars

Name: Hohlwelttheorie
Definition: Re: the concave earth and the earth as a hollow sphere

Name: Monduhr
Definition: Moon dials are usually additional dials to normal clocks, but they are also often integrated into the dial of a normal clock. In the case of sundials with an additional device for reading the time even in moonlight.

Name: Nocturnal
Definition: Old timekeeping instrument for determining time at night; the determined sidereal time is converted into solar time

Name: Tin sundial
Definition: Belongs to the travel sundial type and consists of individual plates stored in boxes, which are sometimes connected by hinges or hinges.

Name: Medium Earth Orbit
Definition: Asynchronous, elliptical satellite orbit between 5000 and 13000 km altitude; mainly used by navigation satellites

Name: IUE Satellite
Alternate Name: International research satellite for ultraviolet radiation
Definition: Research satellite of NASA, ESA and Great Britain to study the UV radiation of cosmic objects, launched in 1978

Name: Tellurium
Definition: Device used to model the movements of the moon and earth around the sun.

Name: Sternfinder
Definition: This device can be used in conjunction with a star chart to determine the starry sky at any hour, the position of the sun or its rising and setting.

Name: Ringbecken
Definition: Surface shape on the moon: large crater surrounded by several concentric rings

Name: Low Earth Orbit
Definition: Approximately circular satellite orbit between 500 and 1500 km altitude

Name: Orion project
Definition: 1958-1965; USA project for the use of nuclear power to propel rockets

Name: SIGMA radio telescope
Definition: Franz. Space radio telescope

Name: Zenitsektor
Definition: Astronom. Instrument for meridian determination

Name: Horizontalsonnenuhr
Definition: Sundials with a horizontal reading scale

Name: Weltraumbeobachtung
Definition: Scientific observation (with telescopes, sensors, etc.) from space (of spacecraft)

Name: UHECR
Definition: Cosmic radiation with particle energies above approx. 1 EeV

Name: Heliometer
Definition: Special telescope for measuring small angular distances in the sky

Name: Analemma
Definition: Method of projecting the earth's linear network onto a surface, especially for sundials and astrolabes

Name: Neuschwanstein meteorite
Definition: Meteorite that fell near Neuschwanstein Castle on April 6, 2002, officially named as such

Name: Ap star
Definition: A-star with an unusual spectrum

Name: Virtual observatory
Definition: Comprehensive astronomical database that allows simultaneous, standardized access to observation data from large earth-based and space-based telescopes

Name: Stunde
Definition: An hour is a measurable unit of time and corresponds to exactly 60 minutes or 3600 seconds.

Name: Navicula de Venetiis
Definition: Travel sundial in the shape of a ship

Name: NexStar
Definition: Telescope series from Celestron

Name: CLUSTER satellite mission
Definition: Satellite mission of ESA to study the Earth's magnetosphere and its environment in the solar wind with 4 satellites simultaneously

Name: Astillejos
Definition: Span. Refers to the two brightest stars Castor and Pollux in the constellation Gemini

Name: Zwergplanet
Definition: Objects that are in orbit around a star, have sufficient mass to form an approximately round shape due to their own gravity, have not cleared their orbital environments and are not moons

Name: Ringsonnenuhr
Definition: mostly portable sundial

Name: International Celestial Reference System
Definition: Internationally agreed, worldwide reference system of Cartesian coordinates of the solar system

Name: Eye sundial
Definition: Type of sundial in which the sun's rays fall through an opening (eye, the so-called solar eye) in the roof of a building onto a scale set into the ground

Name: Reisesonnenuhr
Definition: All sundials which, unlike fixed sundials and table sundials, are suitable for taking on a journey.

Name: Analemmatic sundial
Definition: The term stands for a type of clock with a movable shadow projector and hour scale (analemma)

Name: Azimutalsonnenuhr
Definition: A type of sundial with which the time of day can be read from the azimuth of the sun and the altitude of the sun.

Name: Dosensonnenuhr
Definition: Sundial in the form of a box with a lid, which protected it from external influences

Name: Äquatorialsonnenuhr
Definition: The name is due to the position of the dial: it is parallel to the equatorial plane

Name: Klappsonnenuhr
Definition: Portable sundial that can be opened with hinges and has a small compass for north-south alignment. A gnomon serves as a shadow caster.

Name: Curvilinear sundial
Definition: The curvilinear sundial is a further development of the ancient scaphe.

Name: Hollow face sundial
Definition: The hollow-face sundial is a further development of the ancient scaphe.

Name: Skaphe
Definition: A term derived from the Greek for bowl or basin. Ancient Greek sundials had the shape of an open hemispherical bowl with a gnomon in the center. The scaphe only shows temporal hours.

Name: Column sundial
Definition: Type of so-called curvilinear sundial in the form of a column with a base and crown and a laterally protruding, usually retractable shadow caster, whose shadow falls on a scale on the circumference of the column and thus indicates the time

Name: Bechersonnenuhr
Definition: Playful version of a hollow-face sundial, artfully engraved in a drinking cup

Name: Kugelsonnenuhr
Definition: Rare form of a table sundial in which the hour division is marked on a sphere with a pole-facing axis, as in an equatorial sundial. The shadow is cast by a semicircle that can be rotated around the axis.

Name: Oblique sundial
Definition: A sundial with inclined indication scales.

Name: Polyhedral sundial
Definition: A very rare type of sundial whose dials consist of the faces of a polyhedron (cube or octahedron). The purpose of the many dials was to be able to indicate different hours (e.g. Italian, Basel, Nuremberg, Prague hours).

Name: Cube sundial
Definition: one of the many possible forms of the polyhedral sundial

Name: Vertikalsonnenuhr
Definition: A sundial with a vertical reading scale. These include sundials painted on the walls of buildings or window sundials integrated into colored glass windows

Name: Fenstersonnenuhr
Definition: A sundial consisting of colored glass pieces on window panes with a pin attached to the pierced glass as a shadow caster. It could be used to tell the time inside rooms.

Name: Zylindersonnenuhr
Definition: The cylinder sundial was widely used at the end of the Middle Ages and in modern times. Its advantage lies in its independence from the north-south direction, making a compass unnecessary.

Name: Hirtensonnenuhr
Definition: A shepherd's sundial (or shepherd's watch, also known as a dragon watch) is a cylinder sundial made in a smaller format that is portable and, as the name suggests, was often used by shepherds.

Name: Minute
Definition: One minute is a measurable unit of time and corresponds to 60 seconds.

Name: Differential microwave radiometer
Definition: Precision device for measuring cosmic background radiation

Name: Terraforming
Definition: The imaginary transformation of other planets into habitable Earth-like celestial bodies

Name: LISA Astronomy
Definition: Gravitational wave detector in space based on a Michelson interferometer, planned as a joint mission of NASA and ESA.

Name: Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect
Definition: Anisotropy of cosmic background radiation in galaxy clusters

Name: LIGO Astronomy
Definition: Earth-bound gravitational wave detector with laser interferometer detectors at LIGO Hanford Observatory in Hanford (Washington) and at LIGO Livingston Observatory in Livingston (Louisiana).

Name: Syzygy Astronomy
Definition: Angular position of planets

Name: Radarastronomie
Definition: Research discipline for the investigation of cosmic objects using radar techniques

Name: Mariner space probe
Definition: Series americ. space probes, 1962-1973

Name: Mariner 9
Definition: US space probe, launched in 1971

Name: Prospero Satellite
Definition: Brit. Satellite, launched 1971

Name: Morasko meteorite
Definition: Meteorite from the asteroid belt, discovered in 1914 near the village of Morasko north of Poznan

Name: Habitable Zone
Definition: Zone in which the distance of a planet from the central star allows the occurrence of liquid water and thus possibly also earth-like life

Name: Sothisperiode
Definition: In ancient Egypt. Chronology period of 1461 years, after which the heliak. Rising of Sirius (Sothis, Dog Star) coincided with the beginning of the year of change of 365 days

Name: Astrolabe B
Definition: Mesopotamian compilation listing astronomical positions of planets, stars and constellations in an annual calendar on cuneiform tablets

Name: European Extremely Large Telescope
Definition: Planned earth-bound giant telescope of the ESA, expected completion 2024

Name: Nakhla meteorite
Definition: Martian meteorite found in 1911 near the village of El Nakhla El Bahariya in Egypt, namesake of the Nakhlite class, the first Martian meteorite with traces of the former presence of liquid water on Mars

Name: 40-foot reflector telescope
Definition: Formerly the largest telescope in the world, manufactured in Slough, part now in Greenwich Observatory

Name: Stellar archaeology
Definition: Searching for the oldest stars in the universe

Name: Astronomical unit Unit of measurement
Definition: By definition, exactly 149,597,870,700 meters

Name: Astronomical chair
Definition: Seat combined with ladder and elevator, used in the historical use of large telescopes

Name: GEO 600 Astronomy
Definition: Earth-bound gravitational wave detector in Ruthe near Hanover, based on a Michelson interferometer.

Name: Non-gravitational force
Definition: Forces of motion in celestial bodies that cannot be explained by gravity

Name: Eigenfarbe
Definition: Used for all typical inherent colors of substances and solids, e.g. also star colors, excluding the variable color effects produced by their surroundings

Name: Vaiśākha
Definition: Second month of the Hindu lunar calendar; the 1957 calendar reform adopted month names, but the dates are based on the Gregorian calendar (April 21-May 21).

Name: Herschel Space Telescope
Definition: Space telescope named after Sir J.F.W. Herschel, which took measurements in the far infrared from 2009 to 2013. As a project (from 1984), it initially ran under the name Far Infrared and Submillimetre Telescope (FIRST).

Name: Planetenweg
Definition: Special type of hiking trail where a scaled-down model of the solar system is displayed along the hiking route

Name: Cosmological redshift
Definition: The cosmological redshift is a form of shift in the spectrum of electromagnetic radiation emitted by celestial bodies towards the "red" range of longer wavelengths. The cause of this lies in the process of the expansion of the universe or space-time as such. The phenomenon is to be distinguished from the Doppler effect and gravitational redshift.

Name: Noachian period
Definition: 3.8 to 3.5 billion years ago

Name: Hesperian period
Definition: 3.5 to 1.8 billion years ago

Name: Amazonian period
Definition: 1.8 billion years ago

Name: Apogee
Definition: The farthest point of the orbit of a celestial body or an artificial satellite.

Name: Hawking radiation
Definition: Hawking radiation is a hypothetical radiation emitted by black holes, the existence of which was proposed by British physicist Stephen Hawking. Theoretically, this postulate is supported by quantum field theory and the general theory of relativity. Experimental verification is not possible according to the state of the art.

Name: Great Melbourne Telescope
Definition: Erected in 1869 at the Melbourne Observatory, dismantled in 2003

Name: Cherenkov Telescope Array
Definition: Earth-based gamma-ray observatory with locations in the northern (La Palma) and southern hemisphere (Atacama Desert).

Name: Sekunde
Definition: The second is the basic unit of time in the SI system.

Name: Period-luminosity relationship
Definition: Means of distance measurement in astronomy

Name: Virgo Astronomy
Alternate Name: Variability of solar Irradiance and Gravity Oscillations
Definition: Earth-bound gravitational wave detector in Santo Stefano a Macerata near Pisa, Italy, based on a Michelson interferometer.

Name: Voyager Golden Record
Definition: The Voyager Golden Records are data disks with image and audio information that are on board the two interstellar space probes Voyager 1 and Voyager 2, which were launched in 1977.

Name: Steady-state theory
Definition: Cosmological theory that postulates a continuous, everywhere and constant creation of matter

Name: Modified Newtonian dynamics
Definition: Physical hypothesis to explain the rotational behavior of galaxies

Name: Lunar Laser Ranging
Definition: Measuring method that uses laser beams and reflectors to measure the distance between the earth and the moon. This allows conclusions to be drawn about the earth-moon system, information about the moon's rotation and gravitational physics

Name: Araneiform
Definition: A spider is a topographic feature consisting of several dendritic troughs that converge radially to a common central depression and are found exclusively in the southern polar regions of Mars.

Name: Gaia space probe
Definition: Gaia, the Global Astrometric Interferometer for Astrophysics, is an instrument of the ESA for three-dimensional mapping of the Milky Way.

Name: Multi-messenger astronomy
Definition: Multi-messenger astronomy or astrophysics is an extension of multi-wavelength astronomy. The simultaneous measurement of events in different spectral ranges and their joint interpretation enables deeper insights into the universe. In the last decade, multi-messenger astronomy has developed into an independent discipline in astronomy.

Name: Kryovulkan
Definition: Geological or hydrological manifestation of volcanism that only forms at very low temperatures and permafrost.

Name: Euclid space telescope
Definition: Space telescope named after the mathematician and astronomer Euclid of Alexandria to explore the distribution of dark matter and dark energy in space. Euclid is part of the Cosmic Vision Program of the ESA and is expected to be launched in 2022.

Name: BepiColombo
Definition: Space probe launched to Mercury on October 20, 2018 at 03:45 (MESZ). Cooperation between ESA and the Japanese space agency JAXA

Name: Jilin meteorite
Definition: Stone meteorite, fell on March 8, 1976 near the Chinese city of Jilin (Jilin province)

Name: Rosseland approximation
Definition: Approximation for radiation transport in optically dense media

Name: Standardkerze
Definition: Astronomical object with known absolute luminosity that can be used to determine distance.

Name: Pioneer space probe
Definition: Series of 19 different space probes of the NASA

Name: Equatorium Astronomy
Definition: Device for the mechanical-geometric determination of planetary positions in the zodiac on the basis of Ptolemy's geocentric planetary system

Name: Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array
Definition: International radio telescope observatory in the northern Chilean Andes, operated jointly by ESO, AUI/NRAO and NAOJ

Name: James Webb Space Telescope
Definition: The JWST is a space telescope for infrared astronomy and is considered the successor to the Hubble Space Telescope and the Spitzer Space Telescope.  The telescope reached its final orbit around the sun on January 24, 2022.

Name: Three-body problem
Definition: Also used for the quantum mechanical three-body problem. If necessary, link to the relevant branch of physics

Name: Exergie
Definition: The proportion of energy that can be converted into any other form of energy without restriction (i.e. completely in the case of reversible processes). The difference between the free enthalpy of the system and the free enthalpy at ambient pressure and temperature.

Name: Feldtheorie
Definition: used without HZ for physics

Name: Quantenmechanik
Definition: Through quantization of class. Non-relativistic quantum theory resulting from the quantization of classical mechanics

Name: Statistical physics
Definition: Generic term for statist. Mechanics and quantum statistics

Name: Vielkörperproblem
Definition: Usually under approx. 100 bodies; classical or quantum mechanical treatment, no statist. methods

Name: Anderson model
Definition: Kristallmodell

Name: Free Lagrange method
Definition: Numerical method for solving hydrodynamic equations

Name: Brownian dynamics
Definition: Computer simulation method

Name: Brownian motion
Definition: 1. random, trembling movement of small particles suspended in a liquid or gas. 2. model for share prices or other speculative prices. 3. mathematical model for the 1st and 2nd order.

Name: Perturbation theory
Definition: St. examines the behavior of operator properties under disturbances (Bronstein).

Name: Dissipative structure
Definition: Term coined by I. Prigogine for thermodynamic systems and processes that are no longer in thermodynamic equilibrium, but still in a kind of stable state (steady state, etc.).

Name: Erhaltungssatz
Definition: In physics, a law of conservation refers to the fact that certain physical quantities, called conservation variables, remain constant in various processes or interactions in a closed system. (Wikipedia)

Name: Physics transition
Definition: Change in the quantum state of a particle or a system

Name: Dirac matrices
Definition: Entirety of four matrices, therefore pluralization

Name: Complementarity
Definition: Used for physics

Name: Lagrange equations of motion
Definition: Special case of the Euler-Lagrange equation for generalized coordinates and the Lagrange function.

Name: Liouville operator
Definition: Superoperator derived from the Hamilton operator, which describes the temporal development of the density matrix, for example.

Name: Lorenz model
Definition: named after Edward N. Lorenz, born 1917, meteorologist

Name: Matrizenmechanik
Definition: Historical term

Name: Quantenzustand
Definition: State of a quantum mechanical system characterized by quantum numbers

Name: Spinwelle
Definition: Elementary magnetic excitation of a solid with magnetic order from its ground state

Name: Complex theory of relativity
Definition: Further development of the general theory of relativity by the French physicist Charon. physicist Charon

Name: Time resolution
Definition: Link with field of application; e.g. vibrational spectroscopy / time resolution

Name: Unit of area
Definition: Unit of measurement to indicate the size of an area

Name: Temperaturstrahlung
Definition: Thermal radiation in which the emitter and receiver are thermally balanced, i.e. in thermal equilibrium

Name: Quantenphysik
Definition: Used as a superordinate term for quantum mechanics, quantum field theory, quantum chromodynamics, etc.

Name: Winkelverteilung
Definition: Distribution of emitted radiation, particle flux, etc. as seen from the radiator

Name: Gravimagnetic field
Definition: Additional component of the gravitational field during rotation in the general theory of relativity

Name: Foldy-Wouthuysen transformation
Definition: Method for approximation of Dirac equation and non-relativistic wave equation. wave equation

Name: Cross-over Critical phenomenon
Definition: Change of universality class when approaching the critical point

Name: Order-disorder transformation
Definition: Used in the broad sense according to the 3rd Def. in the Encyclopedia of physics

Name: Migdal approach
Definition: Approximation method in renormalization group theory. Grids with different edge lengths are set in relation to each other

Name: Lagrange-Formalismus
Definition: Treatment of mechanical problems based on the Lagrange equations of motion

Name: Thirring model
Definition: Model for the four-fermion interaction

Name: Hochtemperaturentwicklung
Definition: Development of the sum of states around T equals infinity

Name: Vielteilchentheorie
Definition: Used in contrast to the many-body problem for methods of statist. Mechanics/quantum statistics; treats microscop. "Particles" (molecules, electrons) mostly quantum mechanical, partly quantum field theoretical; number of particles over approx. 10

Name: Three-d element
Definition: The transition metals of the fourth period

Name: Kontinuumszustand
Definition: Unbound quantum state (with positive energy)

Name: Niveaudynamik
Definition: Dynamics of the eigenvalues of the Hamilton operators of a chaotic system

Name: Superoperator
Definition: Operator that acts on quantum mechanical operators

Name: Five-d element
Definition: Transition metals of the 6th period

Name: t-J model
Definition: Model to describe a system of strongly interacting electrons

Name: Casimir effect
Definition: Force between two uncharged printed circuit boards, caused by vacuum fluctuations of the electromagnetic field. field

Name: Hamilton formalism
Definition: Treatment of mechanical (and other) problems on the basis of Hamilton's equations

Name: Punktquelle
Definition: Source for fields, can also be used for radiation, insofar as UB to emitter

Name: Spin boson model
Definition: Quantum mechan. Model for a spin 1/2 particle (or two-level system) coupled to a boson (or field mode)

Name: Clock model
Definition: Extension of the Ising model

Name: Spectral decomposition physics
Definition: Used in physics and technology for all types of spectra (frequency, energy, mass spectra, etc.)

Name: Slave boson method
Definition: Formal addition of bosonic operators to the fermionic operators

Name: Schwinger-Dyson equation
Definition: S.-D. equations form a numerical formulation of field theory; they are a system of infinitely many coupled, non-linear integral equations for Green's functions

Name: Noether-Theorem
Definition: Noether's theorem is a mathematical theorem. When applied in physics, it states that for every continuous symmetry of a physical system there is a conservation variable and vice versa. It was proved by Emmy Noether in 1918. (Wikipedia)

Name: Entangled state
Definition: State that cannot be represented as a sum or product of individual states.

Name: Ultra-relativistic range
Definition: Speeds greater than 90% of the speed of light, in nuclear reactions energies to generate a quark-gluon plasma (above approx. 200 GeV/nucleon)

Name: Relativistic model
Definition: Model of the theory of relativity

Name: Permeat
Definition: Substance transferred during permeation

Name: Mixed conductor
Definition: Semiconductor that can conduct both electrons and holes

Name: Accelerated observer
Definition: Concept of the theory of relativity

Name: Doppler positioning
Definition: Determining location by measuring the Doppler effect

Name: Hollow dimension
Definition: Used for the unit of measurement and the measuring vessel

Name: Effective theory
Definition: Theory with limited scope of validity in physics

Name: Spektralbereichsverfahren
Definition: Numerical method for solving the electromagnetic scattering problem

Name: Petaelektronenvoltbereich
Definition: Energy range from 1*10 to the power of 15 to 1*10 to the power of 18 eV

Name: Separabler Zustand
Definition: State that can be represented as the sum or product of individual states.

Name: Stochastic resonance
Definition: Amplification of weak signals due to the presence of noise activity

Name: Exaelektronenvoltbereich
Definition: Energy range from 1*10 to the power of 18 to 1*10 to the power of 21 eV

Name: Classical physics
Definition: The areas of physics that were essentially formulated by around 1900 and can be described without the concepts of quantum theory, e.g. classical mechanics, classical electrodynamics, classical thermodynamics. Contrast: modern physics.

Name: Moderne Physik
Definition: The branches of physics that emerged after 1900, e.g. quantum mechanics, quantum electrodynamics, solid state physics. Contrast: Classical physics.

Name: INSPEC
Definition: Bibliographic database for physics

Name: Phasenfeldmodell
Definition: Mathematical model for the description of phase transformations

Name: Quantenreflexion
Definition: Quantum mechan. Reflection without class. reversal point

Name: Quantum phase transition
Definition: Phase transitions that take place at absolute zero temperature under variation of an external control parameter (such as pressure)

Name: Einstein-Hilbert effect
Definition: The matter-free part of the action functional in the general theory of relativity.

Name: Zeptosekundenbereich
Definition: Zepto stands for ten to the power of minus twenty-one (DIN 3101-1)

Name: Mehrfeldproblem
Definition: A multi-field problem is made up of individual field problems that describe coupled phenomena in nature and technology.

Name: Mehrskalenmodell
Definition: Mathematical model on various length and time scales. Primarily for solid mechanics and chemical processes.

Name: Dissipative particle dynamics
Definition: Stochastic, mesoscopic simulation method for simple and complex fluids

Name: Einstein relation
Definition: D = my*kB*T

Name: Seidel
Definition: Old unit of volume for liquids in Germany and Austria-Hungary; today's value as beer measure: 1 Seidel = 0.5 liters (Bavaria) or 0.3 liters (Austria)

Name: Directional size
Definition: Physical quantities whose description requires the quantity value and an additional directional specification

Name: Euler's buckling formula
Definition: Formula for determining elasticity

Name: Hypersonic speed
Definition: > Mach 5

Name: Geometric frustration
Definition: Geometric frustration occurs when the lattice geometry of a solid prevents the electrons from assuming a quantum mechanical ground state as a many-body system that corresponds to a strongly pronounced (typically magnetic) order. In the case of geometric frustration, this is due to the fact that the locally energetically most favourable configuration cannot be realized globally for geometric reasons.

Name: Regge calculus
Definition: Formulation of the Einstein field equations of general relativity for discrete spacetimes.

Name: German physics
Definition: Anti-Semitic physics directed against the theory of relativity and quantum mechanics

Name: Pint Unit of measurement
Definition: Old English (0.568 l ) and American (0.473 l ) unit of volume for liquids

Name: Spindichtewelle
Definition: Antiferromagnetic ground state of metals in which the density of the conduction electron spins is spatially modulated.

Name: Conservation of mass Fluid mechanics
Definition: The law of conservation of mass, the continuity equation of fluid mechanics, states that in a defined fluid volume, mass is generally neither lost nor can it be created.flow calculations are also based on the law of conservation of mass. However, this is not a law of conservation in the true sense of the word.

Name: Schleifenquantengravitation
Definition: Background metric-independent theory of quantum gravity in which space-time is represented by a network, i.e. is discrete.

Name: Quantum Zeno Effect
Definition: The quantum Zeno effect is a quantum mechanical effect in which repeated measurements on an unstable quantum system prevent the transition from one quantum state to another.

Name: Topological phase
Definition: The 2016 Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to David J. Thouless, F. Duncan M. Haldane and J. Michael Kosterlitz for "theoretical discoveries of topological phase transitions and topological phases of matter".

Name: Wurmloch
Definition: Mathematical-theoretical structure resulting from special solutions to the field equations of the general theory of relativity. The existence of wormholes is disputed.

Name: Warp drive
Definition: Theoretically proposed propulsion mechanism that enables travel at faster-than-light speeds by deliberately bending space-time. The theory is controversial and speculative.

Name: Hybrid physics system
Definition: A hybrid system, in terms of physics, is a physical system that is composed of two or more subsystems that can be clearly distinguished by one (or more) physical parameter(s) and form an interaction that underlies a physical phenomenon under consideration.

Name: Zeiteinheit
Definition: A time unit is a physical unit in which time is measured, e.g. hour, minute, second.

Name: Quantenmaterie
Definition: Quantum matter refers to multi-particle systems whose macroscopic properties are determined by quantum physical phenomena. Quantum matter is relevant in research areas such as solid-state physics, atomic physics and astrophysics.

Name: Modius
Definition: Ancient Roman unit of volume for grain, also the name for the corresponding vessel

Name: Erdbeschleunigung
Definition: Acceleration experienced by a freely falling body in the gravitational field of a celestial body, especially the earth (acceleration due to gravity), formula symbol g

Name: Zeitkristall
Definition: The time crystal as a theoretical concept for a quantum system with temporal periodicity in the ground state was introduced by Frank Wilczek in analogy to the conventional crystal (with spatial periodicity).

Name: Fallturm
Definition: Tower that enables experiments to be carried out under zero gravity conditions in free fall.

Name: Drop Tower Bremen
Definition: Drop tower at the Center of Applied Space Technology and Microgravity (ZARM) in Bremen.

Name: Einstein elevator
Definition: The Einstein Elevator is a further development of a classic drop tower that can be used to carry out experiments under conditions of weightlessness and a high repetition rate.

Name: Lieb-Thirring inequality
Definition: In mathematical physics, Lieb-Thirring inequalities give an upper bound on the sums of powers of negative eigenvalues of a Schrödinger operator.

Name: Kontsevich model
Definition: Matrix model in the theory of non-commutative quantum field theories

Name: Matrix product state
Definition: Quantum state of a many-body system that can be represented by products of matrices

Name: Quantengatter
Definition: Elementary operations of a quantum computer, analogous to electronic logic gates

Name: Allen-Cahn equation
Definition: Reaction-diffusion equation, which describes e.g. the phase separation in multi-component alloys

Name: Tagewerk
Definition: old German unit of area (field measurement)

Name: Nahm equations
Definition: System of differential equations in differential geometry and gauge theory

Name: Quantengraph
Definition: Quantum graphs, i.e. graphs in which each node is provided with a differential operator, are studied as model systems in quantum physics.

Name: Nicolai illustration
Definition: Transformation in supersymmetric quantum field theory discovered by Hermann Nicolai

Name: Absorption
Definition: not in the biol. for the uptake of substances, there see resorption

Name: Grenzschicht
Definition: Boundary layer is the boundary layer in a fluid in which the wall exerts an influence.

Name: Kinematik
Definition: Kinematics is a field of mechanics that describes the movement of bodies purely geometrically with the variables of time, location, speed and acceleration.

Name: Turbulent flow
Definition: Used for turbulence in fluids (liquids and gases). Also used in particular for atmospheric turbulence and in astronomy.

Name: Oszillator
Definition: An oscillator is an oscillating system.

Name: Tieftemperatur
Definition: Only for temperatures well below 0 degrees Celsius

Name: Impulsfluss
Definition: p*delta_ik + rho*v_i*v_k

Name: Acoustic signal
Definition: Ben. for signals that can be heard

Name: Dichtegradient
Definition: Method of substance separation

Name: Galvanomagnetic effect
Definition: Entirety of effects caused by the interaction of magnetic field and electric current

Name: Pulse transmission
Definition: Only used for the transmission of a phys. pulse

Name: Stoffübergang
Definition: Describes the phys. Process of mass transfer from a solid or liquid surface to another fluid phase

Name: Thermalisierung
Definition: generally used for the relaxation of a non-equilibrium (velocity) distribution into the equilibrium distribution.

Name: Thermomagnetischer Effekt
Definition: All of the effects caused by the interaction of magnetic field and heat flow

Name: Heat transfer
Definition: Heat transfer between solid and flowing fluid

Name: Wirbelaufplatzen
Definition: Formation of a free stagnation point on the vortex axis and a subsequent backflow area

Name: Schwerefeld
Definition: The field of almost spherically symmetrical celestial bodies resulting from gravitational, centrifugal and tidal fields

Name: Ultraschallspektroskopie
Definition: Measurement of the sound absorption of a system in a larger frequency range; this term can also include a characterization of the speed of sound (according to the template)

Name: Aeroelasticity
Definition: Aeroelasticity is the umbrella term for the physical processes that occur in flow around structures when aerodynamic loads interact with an elastic structure. The forces exerted can deform solid bodies and possibly cause them to vibrate.

Name: Adsorptionskalorimetrie
Definition: Physicochemical examination method

Name: Taylor Couette flow
Definition: Flow modes above the Couette flow for rotating cylinders

Name: Interdiffusion
Definition: Diffusion between several substances, in contrast to self-diffusion

Name: Zero sound
Definition: Special collective excitation of a Fermi liquid at low temperature

Name: Stokes problem
Definition: Subproblem of fluid mechanics according to Georg G. Stokes (1819-1903). Describes the dependence of the frictional force of spherical bodies on their radius, the viscosity of the fluid in which the particle is located and the velocity of the particle.

Name: Elektrorheologie
Definition: Rheology under consideration of the electrical state

Name: Lorentz-Dirac equation
Definition: Relativistic equation of motion of a charged particle taking into account the mass inertia as well as its interaction with its own and an external electromagnetic field

Name: Bezugstemperatur
Definition: Internationally agreed calibration, adjustment and measuring temperature set to 20_347

Name: LES Flow
Definition: Method for the numer. Treatment of turbulent flows using wide-mesh grids

Name: Verzerrungstensor
Definition: Distortion tensors are dimensionless second-level tensors that describe the ratio of the instantaneous configuration to the initial configuration during the deformation of continuous bodies and thus changes in the mutual positional relationships of the material elements.

Name: Duffing oscillator
Definition: Oscillator with friction term and cubic disturbance term

Name: Burnett apparatus
Definition: Apparatus for determining the behavior of real gases

Name: Spinodal segregation
Definition: Segregation in the area between the spinodal and the binodal

Name: Overflow
Definition: (Air) flow over unevenness such as a mountain range

Name: Diffusionsschicht
Definition: Thin layer formed at interfaces by diffusion

Name: Hallraum
Definition: Room closed on all sides with smooth walls in electroacoustics

Name: Niedrigtemperatur
Definition: depending on the process used, e.g. 0-15 degrees C for foodstuffs, up to 200 degrees C for CVD processes.

Name: Gewichtsverlust
Definition: Used e.g. for weight loss through heating

Name: Mikrobruch
Definition: Fracture in the smallest area

Name: Thermoacoustic effect
Definition: Effect discovered in 1777 of self-excited sound wave generation in an acoustic resonator to which a temperature difference is applied. It is also possible to reverse the effect (heat pump).

Name: Hertzbereich
Definition: Vibrations from 1-1000 Hz

Name: Direct numerical simulation
Definition: Exact method for solving the Navier-Stokes equation that does not require turbulence models

Name: Schwingsaitenwaage
Definition: Balance that works with the string vibration

Name: Impact-impact interaction
Definition: Interaction of compaction impacts

Name: Squeeze flow
Definition: Behavior of a viscous fluid that is displaced from a narrowing gap

Name: Rhineland foot
Definition: approx. 310 mm

Name: Neigungswaage
Definition: belongs to the group of lever scales

Name: Electromechanical effect
Definition: Combination of electrical and mechanical phenomena, analogous to thermoelectric effects.

Name: Winkelbeschleunigung
Definition: For rotary movements, change in angular velocity

Name: Tollmien-Schlichting wave
Definition: Unstable disturbances of a laminar boundary layer

Name: Downforce aerodynamics
Definition: Opposite of buoyancy

Name: Density flow
Definition: Equalizing flow due to density differences

Name: Balkentheorie
Definition: Beam theory describes the behavior of beams under load. It is a branch of engineering mechanics, especially strength theory, elasticity theory and statics. It is often also referred to as the bending theory of the beam.

Name: Advanced thermodynamics
Definition: Theory that extends the variable theorem of ordinary thermodynamics

Name: Wilhelmy method
Definition: Method for measuring the surface tension

Name: Cone flow
Definition: Laminar (supersonic) flow on a cone

Name: Kontaktmechanik
Definition: Mechanics of bodies in contact

Name: Adiabatic cooling
Definition: Physical process for cooling a gas by expansion

Name: Kornbaum
Definition: Old fruit measure

Name: Zentripetalkraft
Definition: The force that causes a circular motion in a stationary reference system and is directed towards the center point

Name: Mechanical shaft
Definition: Waves that are bound to a medium (Wikipedia)

Name: Wellenfeldsynthese
Definition: Spatial audio reproduction method with the aim of creating virtual acoustic environments

Name: Schwingungsakustik
Definition: Vibration acoustics deals with the generation and propagation of noise caused by mechanical vibrations.

Name: Sirene
Definition: Device for generating acoustic signals

Name: Phononic crystal
Definition: Material with periodic modulation of acoustic properties; analogous to photonic crystals in optics

Name: Creeping current
Definition: Flows with very slow movements of a fluid with relatively high viscosity. The creeping flows are to be regarded as solutions of the Navier-Stokes equations for the limiting case of very small Reynolds numbers.

Name: Chladni figures
Definition: Patterns of a thin plate sprinkled with sand, which are produced when it is set in vibration. Described in E.F.F. Chladni, Die Akustik

Name: Thermomechanik
Definition: Die beiden Disziplinen Kontinuumsmechanik und Thermodynamik bilden ein geschlossenes Ganzes, das  als Thermomechanik bezeichnet wird. The study of the effects of heat upon the mechanical properties of materials.

Name: Thermo-Struktur-Wechselwirkung
Definition: In the case of TMC, there is an interaction of thermal and structural-mechanical problems. This coupling must be taken into account where thermal cycles are run through during the operation of a component.

Name: Thermoakustik
Definition: Thermoacoustics is a special field of acoustics and thermodynamics that deals with thermal processes and the associated acoustic waves. Thermoacoustics is based on the thermoacoustic effect.

Name: Turbidity flow
Definition: Density flow containing suspension

Name: Aneroidbarometer
Definition: Form of barometer in which a change in air pressure is indicated by elastic deformation of hollow metal bodies containing no air

Name: Taragewicht
Definition: Weight of the required packaging of a product; the gross weight minus the tare gives the net weight, which is usually used as the basis for price calculation and customs clearance

Name: Forchheimer equation
Definition: The Forchheimer equation (according to Philipp Forchheimer) describes the pressure loss in a flow (usually in porous media)

Name: Wurfparabel
Definition: The throwing parabola is the trajectory that a body describes when thrown in a homogeneous gravitational field, if the influence of air resistance is neglected.

Name: Holographic microscopy
Definition: Holographic microscopy is a method of microscopy based on the use of holography.

Name: Akustophorese
Definition: Transport by sound

Name: Entwurfsaerodynamik
Definition: Design aerodynamics deals with the aerodynamic design of aircraft and aircraft components, i.e. specifically with the design of aircraft components with regard to optimal aerodynamic behavior.

Name: Stereostatik
Definition: Is a part of statics and deals with the equilibrium of forces on rigid bodies, i.e. non-deformable bodies.

Name: Whispering gallery mode
Definition: Modes that propagate along a concave surface or boundary. Historically discovered on the basis of the acoustic whispering gallery, they can also be optical or electromagnetic modes.

Name: Blowby
Definition: Blowby refers to the gas passing the piston rings from the working chamber into the engine compartment during compression in an internal combustion engine or piston compressor.

Name: Lean combustion
Definition: In lean-burn combustion, a larger proportion of air is mixed with the fuel than before.

Name: NVH Oscillation
Definition: In summary, NVH refers to the audible or perceptible vibrations in motor vehicles or on machines. Roughness refers to the audible and perceptible transition range from 20 Hz to 100 Hz.

Name: Thermophon
Definition: A thermophone is a physical device in which electrical currents in a medium that acts as an electrical resistance generate heat that is released into a surrounding gas. This produces sound. The thermophone also exists as a musical instrument.

Name: Ultraschalllevitation
Definition: Ultrasonic levitation is the contactless handling of objects with ultrasound.  It is used to make objects float in a controlled manner. Various effects of ultrasound are used to improve the handling of objects - for storing, securing and moving.

Name: Bernoulli beam
Definition: The Euler-Bernoulli beam theory is a simplification of the linear theory of elasticity for calculating the deformation behavior of slender beams under mechanical load.

Name: Fluiddynamik
Definition: "Fluid dynamics is a branch of fluid mechanics and deals with moving fluids (liquids and gases). The subfield for gases is aerodynamics, for liquids hydrodynamics. For example, laminar and turbulent flows in open and closed channels as well as movements and force conditions in pressure lines are investigated." (Wikipedia: Fluid dynamics)

Name: Bingham fluid
Definition: Bingham fluids are special non-Newtonian fluids named after Eugene Cook Bingham. However, their dynamic viscosity is not a function of the shear rate (or shear gradient) and leads to linear flow behavior.

Name: 3-omega microscopy
Definition: 3-omega microscopy is a microscopic method for recording the thermal material properties of thin or structured layers with a lateral resolution in the range of a few 100 nm. The 3-omega microscopy is derived from the macroscopic so-called 3-omega method (https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/3-Omega-Methode).

Name: Peridynamik
Definition: Peridynamics is a non-local theory of continuum mechanics. It is used, for example, in the formation of cracks in solids.

Name: Knudsen diffusion
Definition: Knudsen diffusion describes diffusion processes in which particles collide with flow boundaries more often than with other particles.

Name: Licht
Definition: Visible part of the optical radiation

Name: Optoelektronik
Definition: Application of physical effects based on the interaction of electromagnet. Radiation with electric charge carriers

Name: Radiologie
Definition: Medical radiology used in medicine

Name: Photoacoustic spectrometry
Definition: Optotherm. Spectroscopy in which the exciting light beam is periodically modulated. The temperature increase is usually detected acoustically.

Name: Change detection
Definition: For image processing, signal processing

Name: Fourier spectroscopy
Definition: Infrared and infrared spectroscopy are considered pleonastic

Name: Elektrooptik
Definition: Physical effects caused by the influence of external electric fields on the optical properties of solids

Name: Blau
Definition: For the color

Name: FIR
Definition: 50 µm to 1 mm

Name: Schwingkreis
Definition: An electrical resonant circuit is a resonant electrical circuit consisting of a coil (component L) and a capacitor (component C) that can perform electrical oscillations.

Name: Electrical discharge
Definition: Only in the sense of the definition of discharge in Lex. Electrotechn. to be used

Name: Blaulicht
Definition: Without HZ used for blue light in general

Name: Cotton mouton effect
Definition: Caused by magnetically polar molecules

Name: Elektrolyt
Definition: Any substance that is subject to electrolytic dissociation.

Name: Faraday effect
Definition: Light propagation parallel to the magnetic field. In certain materials, the direction of polarization can then be rotated

Name: Halo Atmospheric optics
Definition: Collective term for certain atmospheric optical phenomena

Name: Hochspannung
Definition: for voltage > 1 kV to differentiate from low voltage and for high voltage in the narrower sense > 110 kV to differentiate from medium voltage

Name: Maximum voltage
Definition: 500 and 750 kV

Name: Kundt effect
Definition: Faraday effect in the ferromagnetic

Name: Linse
Definition: used for the optics

Name: Macaluso-Corbino effect

Name: Magnetic susceptibility
Definition: Chi=My_relative-1

Name: Magneto-optical Kerr effect

Name: Majorana effect
Definition: Caused by particle aggregates

Name: Schwarz
Definition: Für die Farbe

Name: Speckle interferometry
Definition: Recording of speckle patterns with a (video) camera. This enables time-resolved measurement of changes in length. Also used for astronomy

Name: Spektrograph
Definition: Used as a historical designation

Name: Radiation intensity
Definition: Non-specific designation for sizes of the dimension watt/sqm

Name: Active scattering spectroscopy
Definition: Nonlinear spectroscopy of excited systems

Name: Streustrahlung

Name: Superstrahlung
Definition: Atomic dipoles are aligned by coherent excitation

Name: Synchrotronstrahlung
Definition: Synchrotron radiation is the electromagnetic radiation that is emitted tangentially to the direction of movement of charged particles when they move at relativistic speed and are deflected from a straight path.

Name: Voigt effect
Definition: Magnetic birefringence near the absorption lines

Name: Synthetic aperture
Definition: Construction of a large aperture using a much shorter antenna

Name: Optothermische Spektroskopie
Definition: The absorbed radiation energy is detected via the temperature increase.

Name: Crushed condition
Definition: Two-photon states are special squeezed states (contrary to Lex. Optics)

Name: Resonance-enhanced multiphoton ionization
Definition: The intermediate state is not virtual but a real excited state

Name: Optische Strahlung
Definition: Includes ultraviolet, visible light and infrared (100nm-1mm wavelength)

Name: Electronic property
Definition: Property of electrons in solids

Name: Drehmagnetometer
Definition: Instrument for measuring the magnetic field; not identical with rotary magnetic instrument

Name: Magnetische Doppelbrechung
Definition: Light propagation perpendicular to the magnetic field

Name: Beugungsbegrenzung
Definition: Figure <physics> and optical system can be understood as pleonastic

Name: Dynamic light scattering
Definition: Line broadening, frequency smearing due to disordered thermal movement

Name: Extreme ultraviolet
Definition: approx. 10-100 nm wavelength

Name: Linienstrahlung
Definition: Line spectrum is quasisynonymous

Name: Frictional electricity
Definition: Frictional electricity is a special case of contact electricity.

Name: Spectral filtering
Definition: Wavelength or energy-selective filtering of radiation

Name: Critical current
Definition: The collapse of superconductivity

Name: Continuum resonance Raman scattering
Definition: Raman excitation into the continuum, then de-excitation

Name: Quenching
Definition: Premature termination of a process, link to application area from physics and technology

Name: Camera lucida
Definition: Historic. Device for tracing objects

Name: Langspaltspektroskopie
Definition: The observed object is covered by a long slit. This allows simultaneous frequency and spatial resolution

Name: Photothermal radiometry
Definition: Heating of a solid by means of (laser) radiation. The resulting heat wave is detected by the thermal radiation it emits.

Name: Rastersondenmikroskopie
Definition: Summary of all methods in which a surface is scanned with a probe

Name: Rastermikroskopie
Definition: Summary of all microscopy methods that scan an object point by point

Name: Rasterkraftmikroskop
Definition: High-resolution microscope for imaging surfaces and measuring atomic forces on the nanometer scale

Name: MIR Physics
Definition: 3.0 µm to 50 µm

Name: NIR
Definition: 780 nm to 3.0 µm

Name: Field-cycling
Definition: Not related to fast switching according to Lex. Electrical engineering;Method for determining the time for spin-lattice relaxation in the NMR

Name: Evanescent wave
Definition: Wave in thin medium along the surface with total internal reflection

Name: STIRAP procedure
Alternate Name: Stimulated Raman Scattering Involving Adiabatic Passage
Definition: Process for selective population transfer in atoms and molecules

Name: Mikrooptik
Definition: Miniaturized optical components, without electro-optical components, without integration on a carrier substance

Name: Fiber optic amplifier
Definition: Laser-active fiber optic cable that amplifies optical signals

Name: Optical bench
Definition: Device for setting up optical test arrangements

Name: Lichtenberg figure
Definition: Dust figures named after their discoverer Georg Christoph Lichtenberg (1778) on a plate of insulating material, along the surface of which an electrical sliding discharge has taken place

Name: Gelb
Definition: Für die Farbe

Name: Stereobild
Definition: used for illustrated books with stereophotographs, for the process named. SW Stereophotography

Name: Optical tomography
Definition: Tomography using optical radiation

Name: Analytical electron microscopy
Definition: Includes at least energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy and electron energy loss spectroscopy, usually in transmission

Name: Kapillarentladung
Definition: According to the template, a high-voltage discharge through an evacuated or gas-filled hole in an insulator called a capillary; lengths of 10-150 nm and diameters of 0.5-7.5 mm are typical; various plastics and ceramics are used as capillary material

Name: Grau
Definition: Für die Farbe

Name: ZEKE spectroscopy
Definition: Link with other methods

Name: Abstrahlung
Definition: Radiation emitted by a body

Name: Optical coherence
Definition: Property of electromagnetic radiation; to differentiate from coherence in the broader sense (e.g. stochastic systems, matter waves, currents)

Name: Stromdichtefilament
Definition: Areas of increased current density

Name: Upward conversion
Definition: Emitted frequency greater than input frequency (due to effects of non-linear optics)

Name: Rotlicht
Definition: Without HZ used for red light in general

Name: Cavity ring down spectroscopy
Definition: Method in which a frequency-stable IR laser is combined with a high-quality optical resonator

Name: Dobson spectrophotometer
Definition: Measuring device for determining the ozone layer

Name: Doppelstrahltechnik
Definition: Lasermethode

Name: Ocker
Definition: Für die Farbe

Name: Quarzlampe
Definition: Metal halide lamp for generating UV radiation

Name: Photoanisotropie
Definition: The generation of birefringence and dichroism of a material by irradiation with linearly polarized light

Name: Optical tweezers
Definition: Device for manipulating small particles (approx. 1-100 micrometers) using laser beams.

Name: Backscatter signal
Definition: E.g. light signal or radar signal

Name: Coercive field strength
Definition: Is the magnetic field strength required to completely demagnetize a ferromagnetic substance previously charged to saturation flux density, so that the resulting total flux or local flux density is zero.

Name: Laserstrophometrie
Definition: Optical method for measuring velocity gradients in flows

Name: Spinventil
Definition: Magnetoelectronic component based on the effect of tunnel magnetoresistance

Name: Rosa
Definition: Für die Farbe

Name: Fernmikroskop
Definition: In contrast to conventional microscopes microscopes, the distance between the object plane and the optics is several centimeters in distance microscopes

Name: Opernglas
Definition: Small binoculars used in the theater or concert hall.

Name: Taschenmikroskop
Definition: Based on the design of two cylinders screwed into each other. Can be adjusted precisely and easily thanks to the screw drive.

Name: Quantenkaskadenlaser
Definition: Intraband semiconductor laser, the electrons remain in the conduction band after light emission

Name: Lamp optics
Definition: Ben. for the artificial light source

Name: KCP
Definition: Partially oxidized cyanoplatinates: K2[Pt(CN)4]Br0.3 . 3 H2O

Name: Laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy
Definition: Laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) is a versatile method for the multi-element analysis of any solid, liquid or gaseous sample in environmental and process analysis.

Name: Gasochromic layer
Definition: Thin layer that reversibly changes its optical properties depending on the surrounding gas atmosphere (analogous to thermochromism, electrochromism, photochromism)

Name: Microscope slide
Definition: Plane-parallel plate that carries the object under examination in the microscope

Name: Cavity Leak-Out Spectroscopy
Definition: Determining the absorption coefficient of a gas by measuring the decay time of an optical resonator

Name: Method of physical optics
Definition: Standard method in electrodynamics; asymptotic approach for calculating electromagnetic scattering problems on electrically large structures

Name: Zufallslaser
Definition: Disordered optically active dielectrics that are excited by pumps to emit laser radiation

Name: Magnetic induction tomography
Definition: Non-contact imaging method

Name: Deep ultraviolet
Definition: According to template 180-280 nm; according to Elektroniknet.de lexicon 200-300 nm

Name: Photophorese
Definition: Migration of suspended particles under illumination

Name: Maker interference
Definition: Measuring method in crystal optics

Name: Magnetfeldeffekt
Definition: Summarizing term for all effects triggered by magnetic fields in matter

Name: Virtual microscopy
Definition: As a digital procedure, it is an alternative to the examination of glass slides under a light microscope.

Name: Ferroelektret
Definition: Ferroelectrets are electrically charged cellular or porous electret films that exhibit piezoelectric properties.

Name: Ladungsordnung
Definition: In physics, charge order refers to the self-organization of charge carriers into a superstructure

Name: Yellow light
Definition: Without HZ used for yellow light in general

Name: Optical frequency comb
Definition: Precision device for measuring the wavelength of light

Name: Sehtheorie
Definition: Also includes the visual radiation theory founded in antiquity

Name: TDLAS
Definition: Absorption spectroscopy using tunable laser diodes

Name: Opening error
Definition: Monochromatic lens defect that leads to blurred images due to different intersection widths of parallel incoming light beams

Name: Multiplexhologramm
