Definition: Hologram type that can also be used to capture movements

Name: Nanooptik
Definition: Miniaturized optical components that are smaller than the wavelength of light.

Name: Elmsfeuer
Definition: Rare light phenomenon caused by electrical discharges in the atmosphere

Name: Candela Unit of measurement
Definition: Law. Unit of luminous intensity, symbol: cd

Name: Optical disk
Definition: Instrument for demonstrating optical phenomena

Name: Correlative microscopy
Definition: Combination of different microscopy techniques

Name: STED-Microscopy
Definition: Stefan Hell was awarded the 2014 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for the development of STED microscopy as a method of super-resolution fluorescence microscopy (alongside Eric Betzig and William E. Moerner).

Name: Viewfinder optics
Definition: Optical device for aiming at a subject

Name: Photon recoil spectroscopy
Definition: Precision spectroscopy for very fast energy transitions in atoms or molecules. Further development of quantum logic spectroscopy.

Name: Goniofotometrie
Definition: Measuring method for determining the spatial distribution of illuminance

Name: Mikrolinse
Definition: A microlens is the miniaturized form of a conventional lens. It can be found in nature, but also in technology.

Name: Superkontinuum
Definition: Laser light, which has an extremely broad optical spectrum

Name: White light interferometer
Definition: This is a non-contact optical measurement method that uses the interference of broadband light (white light) and thus allows 3D profile measurements of structures with dimensions between a few centimeters and a few micrometers.

Name: Coherence radar
Definition: The coherence radar is a white light interferometer that can be used to measure the shape of smooth and rough surfaces.

Name: 3D technology
Definition: 3D technology comprises techniques and processes that make it possible to display images in three dimensions and true to space.

Name: Fizeau interferometer
Definition: Is a special interferometer that is used, among other things, to assess the optical quality of surfaces and optics

Name: Kugelinterferometer
Definition: The sphere interferometer is a two-arm Fizeau interferometer with spherical reference surfaces.

Name: Hong Ou almond effect
Definition: The Hong-Ou-Mandel effect is an interference phenomenon between two photons and can only be described in quantum mechanical terms.

Name: Numerical aperture
Definition: The numerical aperture describes the ability of an optical element to focus light. In lenses, it determines the minimum size of the light spot that can be generated in its focus and is therefore an important parameter that limits the resolution.

Name: LIDAR spectroscopy
Definition: Spectroscopy is carried out here using laser beams.

Name: Tilted wave interferometer
Definition: Is a special interferometer that is used, among other things, to assess the optical quality of surfaces and optics with aspheres and free-form surfaces. It is based on measuring the test specimen in parallel with several wavefronts tilted towards each other in a non-zero test.

Name: IR-B
Definition: 1.4 to 3.0 µm

Name: IR-A Physik
Definition: 780 nm to 1400 nm

Name: Optical lattice Quantum optics
Definition: In quantum optics, an optical lattice is a spatially periodic structure of interfering laser beams in which atoms or molecules can be trapped.

Name: Photoelektrode
Definition: Electrode of a photoelectric cell that initiates an electrochemical conversion after the absorption of light.

Name: Ampere Unit of measurement
Definition: SI-Basic unit of electric current

Name: Magnetic X-ray scattering
Definition: Method for researching magnetic order phenomena and magnetic dynamics in solids. Magnetic X-ray scattering requires high beam intensities, such as synchrotron radiation.

Name: Spin fluid
Definition: A spin liquid is a system of quantum spins that exhibits characteristics of long-range order as well as non-trivial fluctuations of the individual quantum spins.

Name: Barkhausenrauschen
Definition: If a piece of steel is magnetized by an external alternating field, the magnetic flux change follows a hysteresis loop, which consists of incremental changes (jumps). If a coil is placed close to the surface of the workpiece, a pulse-like signal is generated in the coil. Such pulses generated in solid material form a noise-like signal with a broad spectrum, the so-called Barkhausen noise.

Name: Quantenmetrologie
Definition: Quantum metrology is concerned with the high-resolution and highly sensitive measurement of physical quantities using quantum effects.

Name: Photoinjektor
Definition: A photoinjector generates intense electron beams based on the principle of the electron beam tube. The most basic realization is the radio frequency (RF) photoinjector. This essentially consists of an RF shooting device ("gun") with a photocathode, a laser and optical system that generates the desired pulse structure, an RF source and a timing and synchronization system.

Name: Homogeneous electric field
Definition: A homogeneous electric field has the same strength and orientation in every area of the room in which it is present.

Name: Epsteinrahmen
Definition: The Epstein frame is a standardized measurement method for determining iron losses in soft magnetic, grain-oriented and non-grain-oriented electrical sheets.

Name: Einzelblatttester
Definition: The single sheet tester is a state-of-the-art measuring device for characterizing soft magnetic materials. The aim of the characterization is to determine the magnetic material properties as accurately and reproducibly as possible.

Name: Quantenwellenleiter
Definition: A quantum waveguide is a mesoscopic physical system that has the ability to conduct electrons when specific quantum effects occur.

Name: Superaustausch
Definition: Super-exchange is an interaction between the electron spins of neighboring magnetic ions in the solid state, which occurs due to virtual electron hopping across intervening non-magnetic ions. Super-exchange typically favors antiferromagnetism.

Name: Undulationstheorie
Definition: (F.M. Grimaldi, 1665; R. Hooke, 1665; C. Huygens, 1678) Wave theory of light, in contrast to the emission or corpuscular theory, traces light back to a wave process

Name: Organic laser
Definition: An organic laser uses an organic (carbon-based) material as the laser medium. The first realizations of this were dye lasers that worked with a liquid dye as the laser medium.

Name: Spin-transfer torque
Definition: The spin moment of the electrons causes a moment in the ferromagnetic layer, whereupon it changes its spin orientation (German Wikipedia at Spin-Transfer-Torque-MRAM under MRAM)

Name: Superradianz
Definition: Superradiance is a phenomenon in the field of quantum optics in which a number of emitters emit an intense radiation pulse in a collective and coherent behavior as soon as the emitters are jointly exposed to light irradiation.

Name: Coherent Multidimensional Spectroscopy
Definition: The CMDS enables the investigation of structure, dynamics and fluctuations in samples that are not accessible using conventional optical spectroscopy methods and is therefore used in chemistry, molecular physics, biochemistry and biophysics as well as in materials science. The CMDS is based on methods of two-dimensional spectroscopy and combines different techniques and frequency ranges (VIS, IR, UV, THz, X-ray). An essential prerequisite for this is the development of new ultrafast laser sources in recent years.

Name: Incoherent radiation
Definition: In contrast to coherent radiation, incoherent radiation lacks fixed phase relationships

Name: BICEP
Alternate Name: Background Imaging of Cosmic Extragalactic Polarization
Definition: Experiment to measure the polarization of cosmic background radiation at the Amundsen-Scott research station in Antarctica. In 2014, the BICEP team published measurements that suggested the detection of gravitational waves, but a later, more precise analysis showed that the signal was due to interstellar dust in the Milky Way.

Name: Valleytronik
Definition: Valleytronics is an experimental field in semiconductors that exploits local extrema in the electronic band structure. Vallytronics can refer to other forms of quantum manipulation of valleys in semiconductors, including quantum computation with valley-based qubits, valley blockade, and other forms of quantum electronics.

Classification Name: Elementary particles, nuclear, atomic and molecular physics
Name: Atomphysik
Definition: In the narrower sense, physics of the electron shell; can be used in a broader sense as a summary of atomic, nuclear and elementary particle physics to describe popular scientific literature.

Name: Atomphysiker
Definition: Colloquially also used for nuclear and elementary particle physicists (cf. SW atomic physics)

Name: Elektronenstrahlung
Definition: Non-directional, in contrast to electron beam

Name: Molecular impact
Definition: Used in molecular physics (collision partners are atoms, ions, molecules)

Name: Neutronenstreuung
Definition: Occurs in nuclear reactions; particle character

Name: Kernfotoeffekt
Definition: Not identical with the nuclear photoprocess, only used for the case: gamma + nucleus = X; X = nucleus + emitted particle

Name: Radioactivity
Definition: Used for the property to decay, e.g. aerosol; radioactivity (= A. radiates itself). In contrast, aerosol; radioactive radiation (= A. is irradiated)

Name: Kernstreuung
Definition: Scattering at the atomic nucleus: Coluomb interaction and strong interaction

Name: Photonenstrahlung
Definition: Collective term for X-rays and gamma radiation

Name: Molekularbewegung
Definition: For the observed dynamics of molecules, atoms and groups of atoms

Name: Metallcluster
Definition: (Naked) metal clusters. They show transitional behavior between clusters and cluster bonds: small clusters are covalent, large ones show metal bonding; hence the double OB.

Name: Slow neutron
Definition: Energy less than 100 e.V.

Name: Mikrocluster
Definition: Microscopic aggregates of a few 10 to a few 100 atoms

Name: Kernresonanz
Definition: To be distinguished from nuclear magnetic resonance

Name: Atomtheorie
Definition: Theory of the physical properties of free atoms, based on the properties of their basic building blocks and their interactions. Today, the quantitative treatment takes place within the framework of quantum theory.

Name: Accelerator mass spectrometry
Definition: Mass spectrometry using a heavy ion accelerator

Name: Elektroneneinfang
Definition: Only used in nuclear physics

Name: Elektronenspektrum
Definition: Energy spectrum of free electrons, especially in electron spectroscopy

Name: Electron impact ionization
Definition: Ionization by electron impact (def. contrary to abc physics)

Name: Elektronenstrahl
Definition: Limited diameter, directional

Name: Energy transfer microphysics
Definition: Used for atomic/molecular physics, but also in biochemistry

Name: Inelastic neutron scattering
Definition: SW is not decomposed (majority opinion 1996); see note under Inelastic scattering

Name: Kernexplosion
Definition: Explosion of a single nucleus into many components

Name: Lineardichroismus
Definition: Directional dependence of the light absorption of molecules

Name: Massenseparator
Definition: Also used in elementary particle physics

Name: Molekulardynamik
Definition: Method for investigating the statistical-mechanical behavior of molecular systems using computer simulation

Name: Molecular model
Definition: Can also be used in a broader sense for mathematical models

Name: Molekülstreuung
Definition: Used in solid state physics (in condensed matter or on surfaces)

Name: Myonium
Definition: Positive muon and electron

Name: Myonspinrotation
Definition: Polarized muons are placed in a transverse magnetic field and rotate. The decay rate therefore exhibits oscillations.

Name: Neutronenbeugung
Definition: Occurs during crystal structure analysis; wave character

Name: Photospaltung
Definition: Used for the generation of fission products in the nuclear photoprocess

Name: Radioaktive Strahlung
Definition: A distinction is made between the property to decay (radioactivity) and the resulting radiation. Objects of dosimetry, radiation biology, shielding etc. are linked to rad. radiation. E.g. aerosol ; Rad. Radiation (= A. is irradiated). In contrast, aerosol; radioactivity (= A. radiates itself).

Name: Rydberg state
Definition: beyond Römpp also used for certain highly excited molecular states

Name: Fast neutron
Definition: Energy between 100 keV and 50 MeV

Name: Spinpolarisation
Definition: Polarization of the spin of particle beams and the products of scattering processes

Name: Thermal neutron
Definition: Energy between 5 meV and 0.5 eV

Name: Vigier theory
Definition: Elementarteilchentheorie

Name: Positron impact
Definition: Only used for collisions against atoms, molecules and ions

Name: Vektorboson
Definition: Boson with spin 1, especially as a field quantum of the electroweak interaction

Name: Austauschstrom
Definition: Flow of elementary particles through particle exchange

Name: Beauty
Definition: Charge-like quantum number B of the elementary particles

Name: Gluonenkondensat
Definition: Collective ground state of gluons

Name: Dynamic core polarization
Definition: Term for a process (nuclear polarization is a property of atomic nuclei)

Name: Vibronic coupling
Definition: In molecular physics, coupling of nuclear and electron motion

Name: Quasi-elastic scattering
Definition: Link e.g. with light scattering or electron scattering

Name: Electron stretcher system
Definition: Synchrotron development at the University of Bonn

Name: Charm baryon
Definition: Baryon with open charm

Name: Charm-Teilchen
Definition: Elementary particles with an open charm

Name: Charm meson
Definition: Meson with open charm

Name: d-Electron
Definition: Electron of the atomic shell with angular momentum quantum number l = 2

Name: f-Electron
Definition: Electron of the atomic shell with angular momentum quantum number l = 3

Name: Atomstreuung
Definition: Mainly used in solid state physics (in condensed matter or on surfaces)

Name: f1-1420-Resonance
Definition: Former name: E-Meson, renamed in 1986

Name: Penning cage
Definition: Arrangement of 3 electrodes in a vacuum with a superimposed homogeneous magnetic field, allows charged particles to be confined in a specific space. space

Name: Beta-NMR spectroscopy
Definition: Utilization of the spin-dependent asymmetry (CP violation) of beta decay

Name: Hadronenjet
Definition: The cause of the jet is not pleonastic; e.g. quark fragmentation

Name: Quantenhadrodynamik
Definition: term has recently been used for the Walecka model. The QHD is a relativistic field theory. Field theory, the forces between the nucleons are mediated by mesons

Name: Myonspinrelaxation
Definition: Muons are placed in a magnetic field parallel to the muon polarization. The muon polarization then relaxes to an equilibrium value.

Name: Precompound reaction
Definition: Reaction mechanism between compound core reaction and direct reaction

Name: CP parity
Definition: In the decay of neutral kaons

Name: Stripping Atomic Physics
Definition: Stripping of envelope electrons

Name: Bottomonium
Definition: Bound bb state: Y', Y'', Y''',... (1S state = Y meson)

Name: Y-Meson
Definition: bb 1S state

Name: Electrical quadrupole interaction
Definition: Ww between core quadrupole moment and electric field gradients

Name: Bag model
Definition: Hadronenmodell

Name: ARGUS particle detector
Definition: Commissioned in 1982 at DESY in Hamburg

Name: Elektronenzustand
Definition: Quantum state of an electron in an atom, molecule, solid state

Name: Strahldynamik
Definition: Behavior of the particle beam in the accelerator

Name: Undulator
Definition: Particle accelerator with serpentine acceleration path

Name: Bottom particle
Definition: Elementary particle with b-quark

Name: Fixed coupling
Definition: Coupling of resonant circuits to bandpass

Name: Solid oscillating model
Definition: Oscillator model with mass particles

Name: Semileptonic decay
Definition: Decay of a particle into leptons and hadrons

Name: Leptonic decay
Definition: Decay of a particle into leptons

Name: Hadronic decay
Definition: Decay of particles into hadrons

Name: Cold nuclear fusion
Definition: Test tube experiment with hydrogen in palladium at room temperature mistakenly interpreted as nuclear fusion by Pons and Fleischmann, 1989

Name: Pair-plus-quadrupole model
Definition: Pair correlation in conjunction with quadrupole interaction

Name: Nambu-Jona-Lasinio model
Definition: Model in the low-energyQCD of Nambu & Jona-Lasinio

Name: Ultracold neutron
Definition: Energy less than 10 microelectron volts

Name: Parton
Definition: Hypothetical building block of nucleons

Name: Anyon
Definition: Particles without determination of integer (boson) or half-integer (fermion) spin or the associated statistics (Bose-Einstein, Fermi-Dirac)

Name: Zerfallskonstante
Definition: The inverse of the time constant of decay

Name: Pomeron
Definition: For interactions in the context of QCD, an intermediate state with particle-like properties

Name: Refraktionsstreuung
Definition: Deflection towards the scattering center

Name: Strange particles
Definition: Elementary particle with s-quark

Name: Overhauser effect
Definition: As a result of the coupling of nuclear and electron spin

Name: Fréjus detector
Definition: Underground detector for cosmic radiation

Name: Zero-range potential
Definition: Potential with zero extension (e.g. delta function)

Name: Barkla scattering
Definition: Polarization of the originally unpolarized X-rays scattered at a real angle

Name: D-s-Meson
Definition: Meson with charm and strangeness

Name: OPAL Particle detector
Definition: Particle detector on the LEP ring of CERN

Name: DELPHI particle detector
Definition: Teilchendetektor am LEP-Ring von CERN

Name: EDDA detector
Definition: Particle detector at COSY in Jülich

Name: Pulsed beam
Definition: For periodic recurring radiation pulses

Name: UA2 detector
Definition: Particle detector at the super proton-antiproton synchrotron of CERN

Name: L3 detector
Definition: Teilchendetektor am LEP-Ring von CERN

Name: Electrospray ionization
Definition: Electrodynamic atomization of an electrolyte-containing sample solution into charged droplets and ion release by evaporation

Name: Internal target
Definition: Target in the accelerator track

Name: ATLAS particle detector
Definition: Detector on LHC at CERN

Name: Wake-Field-Transformator
Definition: Cavity resonator for accelerating elementary particles with a wake field (keel wave field)

Name: Unstable particle
Definition: Collective term for various particles in atomic and nuclear physics that decay after a short time

Name: Heliumstreuung
Definition: Method of surface analysis

Name: Rumpfelektron
Definition: Designation mostly for shells located further out, inner shell electron only for the two inner shells

Name: Thermospray ionization
Definition: A solution containing electrolytes is vaporized. Fluctuations in the ion concentration lead to charged particles in the vapor phase.

Name: Photonenstrahl
Definition: Directed beam of X-ray or gamma quanta

Name: Mehrstufenanregung
Definition: Several steps of the "energy level ladder" are climbed by absorbing photons, whereas in the multiphoton process only one step is taken by absorbing or emitting several photons

Name: Fremdion
Definition: Ions of foreign elements

Name: Halo core
Definition: The nuclear ground state is only a few 100 keV below the break-up threshold. One or more nucleons are very weakly bound to a stable subsystem (the core).

Name: H1 Particle detector
Definition: Particle detector at the HERA storage ring in Hamburg

Name: Squark
Definition: Supersymmetric partner of the quarks

Name: Gaugino
Definition: Supersymmetric partners of vector bosons (subterms: photino, gluino, wino, zino)

Name: LUNA Particle accelerator
Definition: Accelerator plant in central Italy

Name: Teilchenemission
Definition: The particle was previously bound (in contrast to particle generation: particle not previously present)

Name: Dreiteilchenereignis
Definition: Final state of a particle reaction with three identical particles, e.g. muons

Name: Disk unit
Definition: Molecular aggregate composed of dye molecules that can be produced in both a self-assembled and a monolayer form; discovered and described by Scheibe and Jelly in the 1930s.

Name: Chargino
Definition: Supersymmetric partner particle of gauge and Higgs bosons

Name: Slepton
Definition: Supersymmetric partner particle of the leptons

Name: Cold neutron
Definition: Energy between 10 microelectron volts and 10 millielectron volts

Name: Restkern
Definition: the residue remaining from the target nucleus after nuclear reactions (including fusion reactions)

Name: HERMES particle detector
Definition: Teilchendetektor am Speicherring HERA in Hamburg

Name: Quantenteleportation
Definition: The information of a particle X is copied to particle B without time delay via double entanglement via particle A ("Innsbruck experiment")

Name: Kathodenstrahl
Definition: Histor. Designation for low-energy electron beams

Name: Lewis formula
Definition: Representation of the electron structure and bonds in molecules

Name: Phosphor-33
Definition: Artificial phosphorus isotope

Name: Sneutrino
Definition: Supersymmetric partner of neutrinos

Name: Atomlaser
Definition: Analogous to a laser, a device that produces an intense, coherent and monochromatic particle beam through a stimulated process.

Name: Quantenkommunikation
Definition: Communication based exclusively on special effects of quantum mechanics, e.g. quantum teleportation

Name: Mark-J detector
Definition: Particle detector at PETRA

Name: Crystal barrel detector
Definition: Particle detector at CERN 1985-1996, from 1997 at ELSA in Bonn

Name: Clusterphysik
Definition: New branch of physics that deals with clusters

Name: BABAR detector
Definition: Particle detector at the electron-positron storage ring (PEP-II) of the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center (SLAC), California, USA

Name: NOMAD particle detector
Definition: Particle detector at CERN

Name: BESSY II
Alternate Name: Berlin electron storage ring for synchrotron radiation II
Definition: Synchrotron radiation source in Berlin-Adlershof

Name: NA48 detector
Definition: Teilchendetektor am CERN

Name: BOREXINO particle detector
Definition: Particle detector in a tunnel in Gran Sasso (It.)

Name: Teilchenstrahlung
Definition: non-directional - as opposed to particle beam

Name: Nachbarkern
Definition: nucleus with little different charge or mass like the aforementioned

Name: Low-lying condition
Definition: Only for physics

Name: Depleted uranium
Definition: Uranium from which the uranium 235 content has been largely removed

Name: Strahlteleskop
Definition: High-precision reference instrument in particle physics

Name: Artificial radioactivity
Definition: Entdeckt 1934

Name: Szintillometer
Definition: Device for measuring atmospheric turbulence, heat flow and crosswinds (flow measurement)

Name: Zink-59
Definition: Artificial isotope

Name: CRESST particle detector
Alternate Name: Cryogenic Rare Event Search with Superconducting Thermometers
Definition: Dark matter detector in the Gran Sasso laboratory

Name: PHENIX particle detector
Alternate Name: Pioneering High Energy Nuclear Interaction EXperiment
Definition: Experiment and detector at RHIC, Brookhaven National Laboratory, USA

Name: Ramsauer effect
Definition: Discovered in 1920 by Carl Ramsauer

Name: ISABELLE particle accelerator
Definition: Planned particle accelerator at Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton <NY>

Name: Low-energy ion scattering spectroscopy
Definition: The primary energy of the ions is 100 eV to 10 keV

Name: Unbibium
Definition: Name preliminary

Name: Pygmy resonance
Definition: Concept of nuclear physics

Name: Ununbium
Definition: Name vorläufig

Name: Kernresonanzstreuung
Definition: Resonant scattering of synchrotron radiation on atomic nuclei

Name: HESR Storage ring
Definition: High-energy storage ring for antiprotons, sub-project of FAIR (Facility for Antiproton and Ion Research) of GSI

Name: Gravitino
Definition: Hypothetical elementary particle with spin 3/2 as a supersymmetric partner of the graviton.

Name: Isoton
Definition: Nuclides with the same neutron numbers but different proton numbers

Name: ALICE particle detector
Definition: Experiment and detector at the Hadron Particle Accelerator (LHC) of the European Organization for Nuclear Research CERN near Geneva, Switzerland

Name: KATRIN experiment
Definition: Experiment to determine the mass of the electron neutrino

Name: 500 MeV electron synchrotron
Definition: The electron synchrotron went into operation in Bonn on July 17, 1958

Name: Dipolfalle
Definition: In dipole traps, neutral particles are captured by focused laser beams.

Name: Ultracold molecule
Definition: Temperatures around 1 mK and below

Name: Cold molecule
Definition: Temperatures around 1 K and below

Name: Belle-II-Detektor
Definition: Particle detector at the Japanese Research Center for Particle Physics KEK

Name: Tetraquark
Definition: Hypothetical meson made of four quarks.

Name: FAIR Particle accelerator
Alternate Name: Facility for Antiproton and Ion Research
Definition: International accelerator facility for research with antiprotons and ions in Darmstadt, scheduled for completion in 2016

Name: Pierre Auger Observatory
Definition: High Elevation Radiation Observatory in the Pampa Amarilla in Argentina, consisting of the components HEAT (High Elevation Auger Telescopes), AMIGA (Auger Muons and Infill for the Ground Array) and AERA (Auger Engineering Radio Array).

Name: LHCb particle detector
Definition: Experiment and detector at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN. The focus of LHCb is the investigation of beauty hadrons.

Name: OPERA experiment
Alternate Name: Oscillation Project with Emulsion tRacking Apparatus
Definition: Experiment to investigate neutrino oscillations from muon neutrinos to tau neutrinos.

Name: PANDA Experiment
Definition: Experiment to study antiproton-proton collisions at the FAIR accelerator of the GSI in Darmstadt

Name: ISOLDE Physics
Definition: Facility for the generation of radioactive ion beams. Headquarters: Geneva

Name: Double chooz experiment
Definition: Experiment to determine the conversion probability (mixing angle θ13) of electron neutrinos in neutrino oscillations.

Name: HL-LHC
Definition: Project conceived by CERN to upgrade the LHC (Large Hadron Collider)

Name: CBM Experiment
Definition: Experiment to investigate the QCD phase diagram at high baryon densities in the quark-gluon plasma at the FAIR accelerator of the GSI in Darmstadt.

Name: Branenkosmologie
Definition: Designation of several theories of particle physics and cosmology with a relationship to string theory, which assumes the existence of dimensions beyond the 4 spacetime dimensions of classical cosmology

Name: Superconducting Super Collider
Definition: The SSC was a particle accelerator to be built in the USA near Waxahachie, Texas. Construction began in 1991. In October 1993, the Congress of the United States of America canceled further funding for the SSC, so the project was discontinued.

Name: Touschek effect
Definition: The Touschek effect describes scattering and loss mechanisms of charged particles in a storage ring that influence the lifetime of a particle beam.

Name: IceCube particle detector
Definition: Neutrino observation at the Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station in the Antarctic; the precursor to IceCube was the AMANDA detector.

Name: Hagedorn temperature
Definition: The Hagedorn temperature is the temperature at which matter consisting of hadrons is no longer stable and changes into a quark-gluon plasma.

Name: Kielfeld-Beschleuniger
Definition: A keel field accelerator is a special particle accelerator in which electrons are accelerated by a strong electric field, which is generated in a neutral plasma with the help of a laser or a beam of electrons or protons. Behind the beam, a strong electric field forms in the plasma in a kind of keel wave.

Name: CSAC
Definition: Atomic clock in the size range of a die (chip).

Name: Plutonium-242
Definition: Plutonium-242 is the plutonium isotope with the mass number 242.

Name: Weak coupling
Definition: A (sufficiently) weak coupling between two physical subsystems is characterized by the fact that it is possible to first treat the free subsystems separately and then take the coupling into account as part of a perturbation calculation. The weak coupling should not be confused with the weak interaction, which is one of the nuclear forces.

Name: PT transformation
Definition: Transformation of space (parity, physics) and time (time reversal)

Name: Future Circular Collider
Definition: Planned particle accelerator at CERN for the post-LHC era.

Name: Beijing Electron Positron Collider
Definition: The BEPC is an electron-positron storage ring at the Institute of High Energy Physics (IHEP) in Beijing, which was put into operation in 1989. From 2004, an upgrade to higher luminosities took place, so that the accelerator has been in operation as BEPC-II since 2008.

Name: Beijing Spectrometer
Definition: The BES is the main detector of the Beijing Electron Positron Collider (BEPC). Currently (2020), the BES-III is in operation as an upgrade of its predecessors BES and BES-II.

Name: Accelerator driven system
Definition: An accelerator driven system is a combination of a subcritical nuclear reactor, a proton accelerator and a spallation target built into the reactor core. The ADS is a reactor concept that is to be used for the transmutation of nuclear waste. Test facilities are currently under construction.

Name: Askaryanstrahlung
Definition: Coherent radar or microwave radiation generated by the passage of high-energy particles through a dielectric medium at a speed greater than the phase velocity of light.

Name: Iridium-192
Definition: Iridium-192 is a radioactive iridium isotope with a mass number of 192. Iridium-192 emits gamma rays and has a half-life of 74 days.

Name: Becquerel Unit of measurement
Definition: SI-Unit of activity of a certain amount of a radioactive substance, unit symbol: Bq

Name: Elektronentransport
Definition: Used for transportation processes

Name: Interface
Definition: Used for interfaces of condensed matter, i.e. of liquids and solids with each other and with each other

Name: Plasma
Definition: without HZ for physics

Name: Teilchen
Definition: only for macroscop. T. (not for elementary particles)

Name: Crystal surface
Definition: Used only for undefined surfaces that cannot be designated by Miller indices, otherwise use crystal surface

Name: Heavy fermion
Definition: 4f-, 5f-electron in intermetallic compound, gets high effective mass at low temperatures

Name: Superstructure
Definition: Periodic arrangement of groups of dissimilar building blocks in the solid solution

Name: Heterojunction
Definition: pn junction, where the line type and band gap of the two semiconductor zones are different.

Name: Zwischengitteratom
Definition: Used for intrinsic defects and foreign atoms

Name: Liquid metal
Definition: liquid metals at room temperature

Name: Glaszustand
Definition: for the material ben. SW Glass, with the chemical substance is linked if required, e.g. zirconium fluorides; glass

Name: Hubbard model
Definition: Band model with inclusion of Coulomb repulsion

Name: Kontinuumsphysik
Definition: Physic. Research into deformable media

Name: Pincheffekt
Definition: The pinch effect is responsible for the return transport of separated particles from the membrane into the core flow.

Name: Precession method
Definition: Method of X-ray structure analysis

Name: Flow oscillation
Definition: Flow-induced oscillation of the solid bodies through or around which the flow passes

Name: Superfluoreszenz
Definition: Atomic dipoles align themselves after incoherent excitation as a result of spontaneous emission; the result is a different radiation characteristic to that of superradiation

Name: Spectral hole burning
Definition: Generation of a narrow spectral range of reduced absorption by irradiating laser light

Name: Hochtemperatursupraleitung
Definition: Superconductivity at transition temperatures greater than 30 K

Name: Quasikristall
Definition: Created by paving (= tiling) the plane (space) with at least two different polygons (polyhedra). Can also be obtained by projecting a higher-dimensional regular grid

Name: Electronic transportation
Definition: Transport of electrons and defect electrons (holes)

Name: Spectral sensitization
Definition: Increasing the light sensitivity of photoemulsions through dyes

Name: Synthetic semiconductor
Definition: Semiconductors made of synthetic metal

Name: Mehrschichtsystem
Definition: Used in the physics of condensed matter

Name: Grüneisen parameters
Definition: Proportionality control in the calculation of the dependence of phonon frequencies in solids

Name: Kondensationskeim
Definition: Particle that initiates condensation

Name: MAPW method
Definition: Method for calculating energy eigenvalues and wave functions in crystals

Name: Heisenberg-Modell
Definition: Quantum mechan. Model for the explanation of magnetism

Name: Lateraldiffusion
Definition: Diffusion in a membrane

Name: Strukturverfeinerung
Definition: Method for crystal structure determination using neutron and X-ray diffraction; the model is optimized by refining the parameters

Name: Simultaneous structure refinement
Definition: Method of structural investigation by means of X-ray and neutron beam diffraction, whereby the diffraction data originate from the same substance and are obtained under the same external conditions

Name: Gravity fermion system
Definition: Intermetallic compounds with heavy fermions

Name: Quantenpunkt
Definition: Zero-dimensional quantum well

Name: Quantendraht
Definition: One-dimensional quantum well

Name: Kondo system
Definition: Solids with magnetic impurities

Name: Spinmodell
Definition: Idealized model of a phys. System defined by discrete (spin) variables on a lattice

Name: DX-Center
Definition: Point defect in GaAs compounds with n-impurity

Name: Ionenstrahlmischen
Definition: Mixing of a double layer or multilayer system by means of ion beams

Name: Mesoskopisches System
Definition: Systems of the order of 1 nanometer to one micrometer in size. These separate the microscopic atomic range (described by quantum mechanics) from the macroscopic range.

Name: Zwischenschichtkopplung
Definition: Concept of solid state physics

Name: Gitterleerstelle
Definition: Link to the substance

Name: Koadsorbat
Definition: Further adsorbate

Name: Transient magnetic field
Definition: Dynamically generated hyperfine field at the location of the probe core passing through the solid body

Name: Deltadotierung
Definition: Doping profile similar to delta function: only in one atomic layer

Name: Hochfrequenzheizung
Definition: Heating of fusion plasma etc.

Name: Ambipolar charge transport
Definition: Joint transport of positive and an equal number of negative charge carriers, e.g. exciton or electron-hole plasma

Name: Kinke
Definition: No differ. Appointment for solid state physics and macromolecules

Name: OH-Donator
Definition: Impurity of oxygen atom and hydrogen atom

Name: EL2 Center
Definition: Missing As atoms in gallium arsenide; not yet fully clarified

Name: Monostufe
Definition: Step at the surface or interface with the height of a monolayer

Name: Microporous crystal
Definition: Crystal with cavities smaller than 2nm

Name: Hall probe
Definition: Special application of a Hall generator

Name: Incommensurable phase
Definition: Long-range correlated deviation from the grid periodicity

Name: Quench
Definition: Sudden transition to normal conduction with superconductivity

Name: Bariumferrit
Definition: BaFe12019

Name: Strontiumferrit
Definition: SrFe12019

Name: Myonspinresonanz
Definition: Similar to NMR, polarized muons are brought into a magnetic field and a transverse high-frequency magnetic field is applied.

Name: Bremsstrahlung isochromat spectroscopy
Definition: Fixed wavelength of X-rays

Name: Wake potential
Definition: Wake-like potential that arises when a charged particle passes quickly through a solid body

Name: Bauverband
Definition: Part of the lattice (group of atoms) connected by shortest distances

Name: Luftstrom
Definition: Used in physics and technology (also physiology, phonetics); air flow is used for atmospheric currents

Name: Zwischenschicht
Definition: Transition layer between two pure layers, e.g. in semiconductors, colloids, etc.

Name: Low-dimensional electron gas
Definition: 2-, 1- and 0-dimensional electron gas

Name: Nanostructured material
Definition: Substance composed of crystals typically 5-20 nm in size

Name: Defektkaskade
Definition: Grating defects along the track of the damaging particle

Name: Free volume
Definition: In theories of liquids, glasses, polymers, excess volume or unoccupied volume areas compared to the ideal crystallized solid

Name: Rietveld method
Definition: Method of structure refinement (crystal structure analysis)

Name: Guinier method
Definition: A focusing X-ray procedure

Name: Frozen state
Definition: Solid state of substances containing water

Name: Gradientenkristall
Definition: Crystal with constantly changing composition

Name: Calamitic liquid crystal
Definition: Liquid crystal made from rod-shaped molecules

Name: Volatilization
Definition: Summarizing term for sublimation and evaporation

Name: AB2 connections
Definition: No defined crystal structure

Name: TURBO RANK
Definition: Program for calculating material tensors of any order

Name: Pierce diode
Definition: Model for a thermionic discharge

Name: Phasenproblem
Definition: Problem of determining the scattering phases in crystal structure analysis

Name: Mesoporous crystal
Definition: Crystal with cavities of 2-20 nm

Name: GRID method
Definition: Experimental method that uses the Doppler broadening of gamma rays after the capture of thermal neutrons

Name: Magnetoelektronik
Definition: Electronics based on spin-dependent charge transport

Name: Magnetorheological fluid
Definition: A magnetorheological fluid (MRF) is a suspension of magnetically polarizable particles that are finely dispersed in a carrier fluid.

Name: Photonic crystal
Definition: Material whose refractive index varies spatially periodically on the scale of the wavelength of light; periodic arrangement of dielectric scattering centers

Name: Composite fermion
Definition: Term for a quasiparticle of electron and magnetic flux quanta to describe the fractional quantum Hall effect

Name: Soft matter
Definition: Summarizing term for soft materials incl. "complex fluids"

Name: Rutherford Back Scattering
Definition: The primary energy of the ions is a few MeV

Name: Surface melting
Definition: Premature melting on the surface (one of the so-called precursor effects), application in surface treatment

Name: Kristallit
Definition: Single crystal grain

Name: Auger recombination
Definition: Indirect recombination, in which the interactions take place between the charge carriers themselves

Name: Funktionsgel
Definition: Gels that react controllably and reversibly to external stimuli such as the addition of solvents, pH value, temperature or electric fields by absorbing (swelling) or releasing (shrinking) liquids

Name: Induced polarization
Definition: Used for solid state physics and the geoelectric investigation method

Name: Nanolithografie
Definition: Manufacturing process for surface structures in the nanometer range

Name: Gutzwiller track formula
Definition: Semiclass. Expression for the energy density of a quantum system

Name: Hofstadter spectrum
Definition: Fractal energy spectrum of a two-dimensionally modulated two-dimensional electron gas in a magnetic field

Name: Patterson analysis
Definition: Method of crystal structure analysis, developed by A. Lindo Patterson in 1935

Name: Grenzlinie
Definition: In solid state physics, the envelope of a set of slip lines

Name: Gibbs monolayer
Definition: A dense monomolecular layer formed by adsorption of a dissolved substance on the surface of a liquid, whereby a significant amount of the substance is still dissolved in the liquid. In contrast to the insoluble monolayer (spread layer), in which practically no substance is dissolved in the liquid.

Name: Crystallographic Information File
Definition: Standard for the exchange of crystallographic data

Name: Reciprocal grid
Definition: Mathemat. Construction, which is an important conceptual tool in solid state physics and is widely used in crystal structure analysis, e.g. in the evaluation of X-ray diffraction patterns

Name: Luttinger liquid
Definition: Model for describing electrons in a one-dimensional system.

Name: Metamaterial
Definition: Nanostructure with special optical or acoustic properties (negative refractive index)

Name: Nanokristall
Definition: Crystalline nanoparticle, in contrast to amorphous nanoparticles

Name: ITER
Definition: Fusion reactor to be built as a joint international project in Cadarache (southern France). ITER is based on the tokamak principle and will generate a thermonuclear-ignited plasma.

Name: Graphen
Definition: Monoatomically thin layers of sp2-hybridized carbon

Name: Complex plasma
Definition: Plasma, which also contains particles up to about 100 micrometers in size.

Name: Auxetic material
Definition: Property of a material to expand when stretched at right angles to the direction of stretching. Auxetic materials are therefore characterized by a negative Poisson's ratio.

Name: Warm dense matter
Definition: Density like solids, temperature a few 10,000 degrees, pressure a few megabars.

Name: Mott insulator
Definition: Mott insulators are materials that should actually be electrically conductive according to the ribbon model, but prove to be insulators in experiments. The term goes back to the British physicist Sir Nevill F. Mott.

Name: Nanomechanik
Definition: Nanomechanics is a branch of nanoscience that deals with the fundamental mechanical properties, such as elasticity, thermodynamics, kinetics, of systems with dimensions in the nanometer range.

Name: Nanodispersion
Definition: Mixture of modified nanoparticles that are stable in another substance, i.e. do not or hardly dissolve in each other or chemically combine with each other.

Name: Micromechanics Material
Definition: Is the analysis of composite or heterogeneous materials on the level of the individual constituents that constitute these materials.

Name: Kosterlitz-Thouless crossing
Definition: The Kosterlitz-Thouless transition is a topological phase transition in the two-dimensional XY model. John Michael Kosterlitz and David J. Thouless, together with F. Duncan M. Haldane, were awarded the 2016 Nobel Prize in Physics for the discovery of topological phases and phase transitions.

Name: Bogoliubov-de Gennes method
Definition: The Bogoliubov-de Gennes method enables a description of superconductivity. This method is based on the Bardeen-Cooper-Schrieffer theory of superconductivity. However, it also provides a different approach to the Ginzburg-Landau theory.

Name: Silicen
Definition: Two-dimensional allotrope of silicon with a monoatomic hexagonal honeycomb structure, analogous to graphene.

Name: Molekularmechanik
Definition: Molecular mechanics uses classical mechanics to model molecular systems. The potential energy of all systems is calculated in molecular mechanics using force fields.

Name: NLO-Crystal
Definition: Non-linear optical crystals are used for frequency multiplication, frequency mixing and for optical parametric sources. They are used to generate light waves of twice the frequency or half the wavelength or other multiples of the input frequency. Common crystal materials are BBO, LBO, KTP, LiNbO3, KDP, RTP and BiB3O6. They differ, among other things, in the wavelength range that can be used, the crystal structure and the thermal properties

Name: Kagomegitter
Definition: A kagome lattice is a two-dimensional crystal lattice (in a generalized sense with three lattice sites per unit cell), which corresponds to the overlapping of a Euclidean plane by equilateral triangles and hexagons.

Name: Phosphoren
Definition: Two-dimensional allotrope of phosphorus with a monoatomic hexagonal honeycomb structure, analogous to graphene.

Name: Wasserstoffwirtschaft
Definition: Energy industry that mainly or exclusively uses hydrogen as an energy carrier

Name: Plasmonik
Definition: The research field of plasmonics (short for nanoplasmonics) stands for the targeted use of plasmons in nanotechnology based on the resonant interaction between electromagnetic radiation (especially light) and free electrons at the interface between a metal and a dielectric material (e.g. in metallic nanostructures).

Name: Graphdiin
Definition: Nano-carbon fabric, in the hybrid two-dimensional carbon network of graphdiyne two acetylene units (the "diyne" in the name) bridge hexagonal carbon rings.

Name: Turbulenzmodell
Definition: Model for the numerical simulation of turbulence phenomena

Name: Einsteinjahr
Definition: Joint initiative of the federal government, business and culture; Germany's contribution to UNESCO's World Year of Physics

Name: Chemical nomenclature
Definition: No further adjective-noun combinations are used

Name: Chemical evolution
Definition: A partial aspect of evolution, the development of the most complicated organic molecules from simple molecular building blocks.

Name: Rezeptur
Definition: (1) In pharmacy, R. is the term for the preparation of a drug on the basis of a prescription; often the workroom provided for this purpose in the pharmacy is also called "R.". 2. in chemistry, R. is the term for concise instructions for the manufacture of products and in this respect has the same meaning as prescription. Experiment books are often a collection of recipes.

Name: Transition state
Definition: Use only in chemistry

Name: Mathematical chemistry
Definition: Use for topological, graph-theoretical and predicate-logical methods

Name: Inertisierung
Definition: Increase chem. Inertness

Name: Stoffdaten
Definition: Used for data on chem. Substances and materials

Name: Index chemicus
Alternate Name: Current Abstracts of Chemistry and Index Chemicus
Definition: Chemical database

Name: Heterogenisierung
Definition: Breaking up and modifying uniformly structured substances, e.g. complexes or catalysts.

Name: Abbauprodukt
Definition: Used for biology and chemistry

Name: Green chemistry
Definition: Green chemistry aims to use alternative reaction media, synthesis routes or raw materials and highly selective catalysts in order to minimize the formation of residues in the chemical production process.

Name: Chemical-technical assistant
Definition: Training occupation in Germany

Name: Spezialchemikalie
Definition: Products for special applications, often even custom-made

Name: Polymerisation
Definition: Stepless polyreaction without splitting off by-products

Name: Copolymerisation
Definition: Polymerization of two or more structurally non-uniform monomers

Name: Polykondensation
Definition: Stepwise polyreaction with separation of by-products

Name: Inverse Micelle
Definition: Micelle with hydrophilic interior

Name: Clusterverbindungen
Definition: Cage-like metal compounds in which the metal atoms are connected covalently ("naked clusters", metal clusters) or by complex bonding (stabilized by ligands). All other objects designated as clusters by the author are regarded as "physical" and are labeled as clusters (see there). Bare metal clusters show transitional behavior between both types of clusters.

Name: Bioelektrochemie
Definition: Bioelectrochemistry, a branch of electrochemistry that deals with electrochem. processes in biological systems. Examples include electrical phenomena on cell membranes, the electrochem. Oxidation and reduction of biologically important substances, electrochem. Analysis in biological systems (especially in vivo) and the development of electrochem. Sensors based on the bioanalog principle (biosensor).

Name: Chemistry configuration
Definition: Spatial Arrangement of atoms in a molecule without rotation around single bonds

Name: Phasengleichgewicht
Definition: Link to the state, e.g. gas / phase equilibrium / liquid

Name: Radionuklid
Definition: Used for nuclides or isotopes that transform into stable nuclides (atomic species) through single or multiple radioactive conversion

Name: Komplexe
Definition: A composite is usually formed with individual elements

Name: Clathrate
Definition: One type of inclusion connections

Name: Polyaddition
Definition: Stepwise polyreaction without splitting off by-products

Name: Chemistry association
Definition: Aggregation of several similar molecules

Name: Abspalten
Definition: used for the cleavage of small "units" (protecting groups, functional groups, etc.) from organic molecules or for cleavage from the solid phase after solid phase synthesis

Name: Additionsverbindungen
Definition: Compounds formed by the addition of two or more identical or different compounds. The term is generally restricted to compounds in which the product is held together by non-covalent interactions between the individual components.

Name: Adsorbat
Definition: Combination of adsorbent and adsorptive

Name: Batchreaktor
Definition: Non-continuous, closed system in which transport processes are not taken into account, see also Römpp (9th ed.) Batch fermentation

Name: Binary liquid system
Definition: Liquid two-substance system which, in contrast to the liquid-liquid system, does not have to be a two-phase system.

Name: Chemical equilibrium
Definition: Substances are linked, e.g. iron / chemical equilibrium / oxygen

Name: Einschlussverbindungen
Definition: Term for a group of crystalline addition compounds consisting of two different molecules, which are usually bonded together by hydrogen bonding or van der Waals forces. One partner, the host molecule, serves as a structural support, i.e. it embeds the other component, the guest molecule, in the cavities of the crystal lattice.

Name: Hartree-Fock-Slater method
Definition: Approximation for the exchange potential of the HF equations. This is assumed to be proportional to the 3rd root of the particle density.

Name: Hydrotropikum
Definition: Substances that improve the solubility of compounds

Name: Intersystem crossing
Definition: Used for all "spin-prohibited" transitions, even in the atom

Name: Ionengleichgewicht
Definition: The following is linked to fabrics

Name: Kupplungsreaktion
Definition: General term for chem. Reactions that lead to the formation of a bond between carbon atoms or a carbon atom and a heteroatom or between heteroatoms.

Name: Mikrogel
Definition: Polymer networks with an extension of 10-100 nm

Name: Molekülverbindungen
Definition: Molecule compounds are stoichiom. defined but LABILE higher order compounds

Name: Reaktionssystem
Definition: In addition to the reactants, also includes all components involved in a chemical reaction (such as solvent, catalyst, buffer, etc.)

Name: Reinmetall
Definition: Individual metals are linked, e.g. copper ; pure metal

Name: Reinststoff
Definition: Use if the highest achievable purity is addressed. In all other cases, even if a theoretical study on pure substances (equations of state) is available, use pure substance.

Name: Bridged connections
Definition: Compounds are formed with individual substances and bridges, e.g. nitrogen bridge, vinyl bridge, methine bridge

Name: Wasserstoffspeicherung
Definition: Storage of hydrogen in metals

Name: Reaktionsprodukt
Definition: Term used in chemistry and nuclear and elementary particle physics. Link to the resulting substance or to the type of reaction

Name: Supramolekulare Struktur
Definition: Molecular aggregates and molecular assemblies

Name: Startreaktion
Definition: The starting reaction of a chain reaction is a chemical reaction (e.g. molecule cleavage) under energy supply (light irradiation) in which a reactive chain carrier (ion, radical) is formed.

Name: Kern-Overhauser-Effekt
Definition: Resulting from the coupling of two nuclear spins

Name: Dehydratisierung
Definition: Elimination of water from organic compounds

Name: Molar heat
Definition: Heat required to heat one mole of a substance by 1 degree Celsius

Name: Stereoselectivity
Definition: Almost exclusiv. Preference for a specific stereoisomer as reaction product

Name: Inhibition
Definition: Applies to chemical, biochemical and physiological relationships, but see Immunosuppression

Name: Sol-gel process
Definition: The sol-gel process is a method for producing non-metallic inorganic or hybrid polymer materials from colloidal dispersions, known as sols.

Name: Colloidal metal
Definition: Individual metals are combined with colloid, e.g. s gold; s colloid

Name: Computational chemistry
Definition: Branch of science that combines the field of chemistry with computer science methods and vice versa. Numerical treatment of chemical problems; narrower than chemistry / data processing; a general term for molecular design, force field calculation, semi-empirical methods etc.. The term chemoinformatics is relatively new, while the older term computational chemistry and chemical graph theory refer to the same field.

Name: Regiospecificity
Definition: Preference for a specific reaction center

Name: Van der Waals cluster
Definition: Clusters held together by van der Waals forces

Name: Modifizierung
Definition: Unspecified term for changes of any kind to products or processes, whereby their properties or modes of action are changed.

Name: Photostability
Definition: Stability of substances against decomposition through exposure to light

Name: Regioselektivität
Definition: Almost exclusiv. Preference for a specific reaction center

Name: Linear molecule
Definition: Used for non-angled, i.e. rotationally symmetrical molecules

Name: PHIP
Definition: The abbreviation for Para Hydrogen Induced Polarization, coined by Eisenberg et. al., refers to both hydrogen isomers (para- and ortho-hydrogen)

Name: Copolyaddition
Definition: Polyaddition of two or more structurally non-uniform monomers

Name: Copolykondensation
Definition: Polycondensation of two or more structurally non-uniform monomers

Name: Zerfallsreaktion
Definition: Used for the decomposition of chemical compounds

Name: Adsorptionsisotherme
Definition: The relationship between the adsorbed quantity and the pressure or concentration (in the case of adsorption from a solution) is called the adsorption isotherm.

Name: Modellverbindung
Definition: Compound specifically synthesized for certain properties; link to the property or to the compound to be modeled

Name: Primary process chemistry
Definition: The excitation of a molecule by a photon in photochemistry

Name: Aggregate chemistry
Definition: Aggregates are any kind of spatial accumulation of atoms and moles. Accumulation of atoms and moles through cohesion (same type of mole = associates)

Name: Dikation
Definition: Doubly charged cation

Name: Thio-Arbusov reaction
Definition: The Michaelis-Arbusov reaction (phosphorus chemistry) corresponding to the reaction of sulfur-org. compounds.

Name: Fourth subgroup
Definition: Titanium, zirconium, hafnium and kurtschatovium (rutherfordium)

Name: Eisengruppe
Definition: Today, the term stands for the 8th group of the periodic table, which consists of the elements iron, ruthenium, osmium and hassium. In the past, the term was used for the elements iron, cobalt and nickel in groups 8-10 of the fourth period of the periodic table.

Name: Norrish reaction
Definition: Photochemical reactions of carbonyl compounds

Name: Monodisperse system
Definition: System of (colloidal) particles of the same size

Name: Poorly soluble substance
Definition: Substance that dissolves to a small extent in liquid

Name: Key reaction
Definition: Main reaction step in a reaction sequence

Name: Achte Nebengruppe
Definition: Elements of the 8th, 9th and 10th groups

Name: Lactonisierung
Definition: Formation of an inner ester of hydroxycarboxylic acids

Name: Homopolymerisation
Definition: Polymerization with a single monomer

Name: Dianion
Definition: Doubly charged anion

Name: Supramolekül
Definition: Supramoles are ORGANIZED, complex units formed by the association of several mol. Species, which are held together by intermol. forces.

Name: Hydrotreating
Definition: Hydrogenating refining of petroleum products, mainly for desulphurization

Name: Selective reduction
Definition: Reduction of individual groups or parts of chem. compounds

Name: Selective oxidation
Definition: Oxidation of individual groups or parts of chem. compounds

Name: Synkinese
Definition: Targeted synthesis of non-covalent compounds based on molecular recognition

Name: Agostic interaction
Definition: Hydrogen bridge-like bond, especially in metal complexes

Name: Metachromasie
Definition: Color deviation with histolog. staining

Name: Internal oxidation
Definition: Internal oxidation of metals

Name: Aurivillius phase
Definition: Bismuth-based layered perovskites, whose discovery was reported by the Swedish chemist Bengt Aurivillius in 1949 (according to the original)

Name: Seventh subgroup
Definition: Elements manganese, technetium, rhenium

Name: Clathranden
Definition: Host molecules that are only active in the crystalline state and store their guest molecules intermolecularly in cavities in the crystalline structure. structure

Name: Colloid system
Definition: Substance containing colloids

Name: Internal conversion
Definition: Used for all "allowed" transitions, also in the atom

Name: Endohedral arrangement
Definition: Endohedral complexes are fullerenes into whose cavity an atom or a cluster has been introduced.

Name: Mikrosegregation
Definition: Segregation (separation) in the microscopic range due to the chemically incompatible fragments in the overall molecule

Name: NLO chromophore
Definition: Organic molecules with non-linear optical properties (conjugated electron system with one electron donor and one electron acceptor group)

Name: Trianion
Definition: Triple charged anion

Name: Laserionisation
Definition: Ionization by laser

Name: Laserdesorption
Definition: Separation of adsorbate and adsorbent by laser

Name: Meyer-Neldel rule
Definition: Property of many families of thermally activated processes whose process rate is described by a formula analogous to Arrhenius' equation: The activation energy and the pre-factor do not vary independently of each other, but an increase in the process rate due to a reduction in the activation energy is partially compensated for by a reduction in the pre-factor and vice versa

Name: Molecular descriptor
Definition: Molecular descriptors form the basis for the mathem. Modeling relationships between the properties of compounds and their chemical structure. Chemical molecular structures are described with the help of scalars, vectors, matrices or tensors.

Name: Activity Concentration
Definition: Effective concentration as opposed to the true concentration of a substance

Name: Polyampholyte
Definition: Polyelectrolytes with both anionic and cationic groups

Name: Janus-Micelle
Definition: Core-crosslinked star-shaped micelles with a compartmentalized shell consisting of a hydrophilic and a hydrophobic block

Name: Photovernetzung
Definition: Subsequent cross-linking of polymers by visible light, UV, γ- or X-rays

Name: Weak acidity
Definition: in contrast to strong acids, only partially dissociating, e.g. acetic acid, lactic acid

Name: Persistent Radical Effect
Definition: The Persistent Radical Effect (PRE) is a general principle that explains the highly selective formation of the cross-coupling product between two radicals when one is long-lived (persistent) and the other is short-lived (transient) and both are formed in equal amounts. The initial build-up of an excess of persistent radical occurs through termination reactions between transient radicals. This subsequently leads to the fact that cross-coupling is practically the only reaction pathway.

Name: Ionic liquid
Definition: Low-melting salts (Smp. <80°C) with a negligible vapor pressure and relatively freely adjustable solvent properties (usually an organic cation with an inorganic anion)

Name: Organokatalyse
Definition: Catalysis by substoichiometric amounts of organic molecules that do not contain catalytically active metal centers.

Name: Scholl reaction
Definition: Preparation of perylene by heating naphthalene with aluminum chloride or with other Friedel-Crafts catalysts

Name: Two-photon polymerization
Definition: Two-photon polymerization (2PP) is a process for generating three-dimensional polymer microstructures with the aid of focused NIR ultra-short pulse laser radiation.

Name: Fluorous two-phase system
Definition: Application of fluoroorganic/organic two-phase systems in organic synthesis chemistry

Name: Kreuzkupplungsreaktion
Definition: Transition metal catalyzed C,C linkage reactions between carbon electrophiles and organometallic nucleophiles

Name: Glow residue
Definition: The annealing residue is the part of a sample that remains after annealing.

Name: Pincer ligand
Definition: Pincer ligands are structured in such a way that they can bind to the (transition) metal with two donor atoms (e.g. phosphorus, nitrogen or sulphur) and a σ bond.

Name: Layer-by-Layer-Verfahren
Definition: Process for applying monomolecular layers of polyelectrolytes to a substrate. Layer-by-layer (LbL) technology uses the electrostatic attraction of charged polymers (polyelectrolytes) to surfaces.

Name: Loss on ignition
Definition: The loss on ignition is the weight loss of a sample due to ignition; it corresponds to the volatile constituents. As the volatile substances released during annealing are mostly organic in nature, the loss on ignition is a measure of the content of organic compounds.

Name: Reversible polymer network
Definition: "Dynamicity [/Reversibility in polymer networks] has [...] been introduced [...] typically by incorporating dynamic and/or triggerable bonds within the polymer backbone or as reversible or restructurable crosslinks between polymer chains." Webber, M.J., Tibbitt, M.W. Dynamic and reconfigurable materials from reversible network interactions. Nat Rev Mater 7, 541-556 (2022).

Name: Rückstand
Definition: Composites are not formed with individual substances (however, composites such as pesticide residue should be possible)

Name: Quantitative analysis
Definition: Chemical analysis to determine the proportions of the known components (elements, ions, radicals, functional groups, compounds, ...) of a substance (chemical compound, mixture of substances, ...) using various, but not only purely chemical methods.

Name: Bromzahl
Definition: Determination of the unsaturat. character e.g. of mineral oils by bromination

Name: Fluorochromierung
Definition: Introduction of fluorescent dyes into microscopic preparations

Name: Janovsky reaction
Definition: Nachweisreaktion

Name: Komarowsky von Fellenberg reaction
Definition: Reaction for the detection of fusel oils

Name: Nephelometrie
Definition: Integral stray light measurement

Name: Surface analysis
Definition: Summarizing term for procedures such as AES, EXAFS, LEED, SIMS etc.

Name: Sedimentationsanalyse
Definition: Only for the granulometry method

Name: Photoacoustic calorimetry
Definition: Detection of the heat production of photochemical reactions by pulsed excitation and acoustic detection. The strength of the acoustic signal is proportional to the sum of absorbed energy and heat of reaction.

Name: Chiral phase
Definition: Chiral compounds for chromatographic separation material

Name: Niederschlagsmembran
Definition: Membrane with which a chem. precipitation takes place

Name: CCF
Definition: Chromatogr. meth. Combination of exclusion and gradient chromatogr.

Name: Elektrotransformation
Definition: Transformation through electropermeabilization

Name: Lichtstreuelektrophorese
Definition: Measurement of scattered light from suspended or dissolved particles traveling in the electric field

Name: Inverse gas chromatography
Definition: Gas chromatography with the analyte as stationary phase

Name: Multielementanalyse
Definition: Simultaneous determination of several elements

Name: Chemometrie
Definition: Mathematical and statistical methods for planning and selecting optimal measurement procedures and experiments. Also used to obtain maximum chemical information when analyzing chemical data. In addition to statistical-mathematical methods, chemometrics now also includes problems of computer-aided, networked laboratories, methods for managing chemical and spectroscopic databases and artificial intelligence methods. (Tuchbreiter, A.) (22.9.05; dbfwd)

Name: Passivsammler
Definition: Acceptor surface for measuring gaseous immissions

Name: Isoperibolkalorimeter
Definition: Calorimeter operated at constant ambient temperature

Name: Magnetophorese
Definition: Separation process that exploits differences in magnetizability

Name: CILS
Definition: Influencing Raman scattering by collision of the scattering molecules or atoms with each other

Name: Translationsspektroskopie
Definition: Method for determining the energy transfer of atoms, ions and molecules

Name: Ionenbeweglichkeitsspektroskopie
Definition: Separation of a mixture of ions due to different mobility of the ions; not a chromatographic or mass spectrometric method (not: ion mobility mass spectrometry)

Name: Gammaspektrometer
Definition: Measuring device for recording a gamma spectrum

Name: Sephadex LH-20
Definition: Three-dimensionally cross-linked polysaccharide for adsorption and partition chromatography

Name: Burette
Definition: Glass tube with calibrated scale and stopcock for determining volume quantities

Name: Kryoskopie
Definition: Molecular weight determination by means of freezing point determination

Name: Electroanalytical stripping method
Definition: Summarize. Designation of electroanalytical methods such as stripping voltammetry, stripping chronopotentiometry and stripping chronoamperometry

Name: Elektrochromatographie
Definition: Combination of chromatography and electrophoresis

Name: Single molecule spectroscopy
Definition: Spectroscopic determination of individual molecules

Name: Doppelsegmentelektrode
Definition: Two electrodes combined in one arrangement, separated by an insulating layer (indicator and working electrode)

Name: Nanoanalyse
Definition: Chemical analysis at the nanoscale

Name: GMP turbidity test
Definition: Turbidity measurement after protein precipitation and subsequent precipitation of GMP

Name: Lipocaline
Definition: Family of small extracellular proteins that have an 8-stranded ß-barrel as a common supersecondary structure, with the help of which they can bind and transport small hydrophobic molecules

Name: Post-column derivatization
Definition: Detection type in liquid chromatography

Name: Lewatit
Definition: Cation and anion exchangers based on polymerization resins

Name: Dynamic headspace analysis
Definition: Vapor space analysis using GC

Name: Planarchromatographie
Definition: Generic term for thin layer and paper chromatography

Name: Sephadex
Definition: Three-dimensionally cross-linked polysaccharide for ion exchange chromatography

Name: High-pressure atomization system
Alternate Name: High performance flow, hydraulic high-pressure nebulization
Definition: High-pressure flow system with atomizing nozzle for sample introduction

Name: Temperature-pulse voltammetry
Definition: Voltammetry with pulsed heated electrode

Name: Spektrenbibliothek
Definition: Databases in which a large number of spectra of different substances are collected and uniformly archived

Name: On-site analysis
Definition: Quick and easy tests and measurements at the sampling site (water, soil, air)

Name: Microchip electrophoresis
Definition: Electrophoresis in microchannels created with photolithographic techniques in microchips

Name: Cadmiumelektrode
Definition: A third electrode is used as a reference electrode to determine the individual potentials of the positive and negative electrodes in lead cells.

Name: Differential gel electrophoresis
Definition: 2D gel electrophoresis, in which several samples can be analyzed simultaneously.

Name: Flow analysis
Definition: Automated analysis method, including continuous flow analysis (CFA - Continuous Flow Analysis) and flow injection analysis (FIA - Flow Injection Analysis)

Name: Capillary electromigration technology
Definition: According to IUPAC (Pure and Applied Chemistry 76, 443-451, 2004) these include: capillary electrophoresis (CE), capillary affinity electrophoresis (CAE), capillary sieving electrophoresis (CSE), capillary gel electrophoresis (CGE), capillary isoelectric focusing (CIEF), capillary isotachophoresis (CITP), electrokinetic chromatography (EKC), micellar electrokinetic chromatography (MEKC), microemulsion electrokinetic chromatography (MEEKC), capillary electrochromatography (CEC)

Name: Single molecule microscopy
Definition: Microscopic observation of individual labeled molecules and their movement in living cells using an optical microscope. Within a cell, highly fluorescent molecules are tracked on computer screens using highly sensitive digital cameras with a time resolution of milliseconds. Quantum dots (nanocrystals of semiconductor materials) and gold nanoparticles are being investigated as alternatives to fluorescent dyes as labeling agents.

Name: Soxhlet apparatus
Definition: Laboratory apparatus for carrying out solid-liquid extractions

Name: HSCCC
Definition: Hydrodynamic separation technology

Name: Seltenerdmetall
Definition: Lanthanides + Sc + Y

Name: Metallcarbonyle

Name: Borcarbid

Name: Chalkogene

Name: Diphosphan

Name: Distickstoffmonoxid

Name: Grafitverbindungen

Name: Hyponitrite

Name: Intermetallic compounds

In addition to cubic, tetragonal and more complex structures also occur. In addition to metal, atomic and ionic bonds are also present in the lattice, the latter combined with semiconductor properties. In addition to i. V. with a stoichiometric composition corresponding to the valences present, there are those in which this exact composition represents only a special case in a broad homogeneity range.

Name: Isocyanate
Definition: Esters of isocyanic acid

Name: Kohlenstoff

Name: Metallhydride

Name: Parawasserstoff

Name: Platinmetalle
Definition: Collective term for the six elements belonging to the precious metals in the 4d and 5d series of the 8th-10th group of the periodic table: ruthenium, rhodium, palladium, osmium, iridium and platinum.

Name: Rutil

Name: Sialon

Name: Silazane

Name: Siloxane

The hydrogen atoms can be replaced by organic or halogen atoms. If the hydrogen atoms are replaced by organic residues, the compounds are referred to as polyorganosiloxanes (silicone polymers).

Name: Sulfogruppe

Compounds which have a strong heteropolar bonding component and which, in accordance with an ionic formulation, have an anion partial lattice. Formulation in their anion sublattice - possibly after splitting fractional charge numbers into the neighboring integer values - follow the (8-N) rule.

Name: Zirkon

Name: Uranglas
Definition: Fluorescent glass, also used for glass vessels. The two important shades of yellow and green of uranium glass bear the names of the two daughters of Franz Riedel (glass dynasty of Northern Bohemia, 19th century), Anna and Eleonore.

Name: Amminsalze

Name: Four-d element

Name: Aluminatsodalithe

Name: Nichtmetallverbindungen

Name: Clathrasile

Name: Quecksilbertellurid

Name: Stannide

Name: Oxasulfane

Name: Molecular gas

Name: Zinkamid

Name: Fused silica
Definition: Amorphous fused silica

Name: Phosphonic acid

Name: Bromcyan

Name: Rhenate

Name: Polysilin
Definition: (SiH)∞

Name: Bridge ligament

Name: Calciummetaphosphat

Name: Knallgas

Name: Natriumzirconiumphosphate

Name: Lithiumeisenphosphat

Name: Kaliumnatriumniobat

Name: Halotrichit

Name: MAX phases
Definition: Ternary carbides and nitrides of the general formula: M(n+1)AXn, where n = 1, 2, 3, i.e. M4AX3 , M3AX2 , M2AX. M is an early transition metal (Ti, V, Ta,...); A is an A-group (usually IIIA and IVA or groups 13 and 14) element (Al, Ga, Sn,...) and X is either carbon or nitrogen (C,N). MAX phases are nano-layered composite materials. Their hexagonal structure consists of [MX6] octahedra interlaced with A-group element layers. Due to the strong MX bonds, MAX phases exhibit typical ceramic properties and, due to the relatively weak MA bonds, metallic properties and good electrical-thermal conductivity.

Name: Chilesalpeter

Name: Bismuttellurid

Name: Chlorkalk

Name: Secondary aluminum

Name: Calciumorthophosphate

Name: Wolframschmelzcarbid

Name: Aerographit

Name: Pickeringit

Name: Diborine

Name: Kalium-39

Name: Schwarzer Phosphor

Name: Platin-190

Name: Gadolinium-148

The measurement of the Cs-135/Cs-137 isotope ratio is of great relevance for the identification of sources of nuclear contamination in nuclear forensics.

Name: Natriumyttriumfluorid
Definition: NaYF4 or YNaF4

Name: Strontium-88

Name: Alkohol

Name: Fett

Name: Naphthyridine

Name: Cyclische Verbindungen

V. also exist (example: cyclosilanes, cyclosulphur, boranes, cyclo-silicates, cyclo-polyphosphates), the term c. V. is usually associated with the idea of ring-shaped organ. Verb. (see also cyclo...).

Name: Actinomycine

Name: Arylsulfonylverbindungen

Name: Azepine

Oxides containing even higher-ranking groups (IUPAC rules C-316, R-3.2.1, R-5.5.7, R-5.6). (2.) Refers to the ligand O2- in complexes (IUPAC rule I-10.4.5.4; also oxido...) and inorganic oxo acids (rule I-9). oxo acids (rule I-9).

S. include the echinoderm saponins, e.g. the holothurins of sea cucumbers.

Name: Cycloolefin copolymers

Name: Violacein

Name: Homopolypeptide
Definition: Polypeptides that contain only one type of amino acid as a monomer building block

Name: Hydroxytyrosol
Definition: natural antioxidant in olives/olive oil

Name: Neonicotinoide
Definition: used as an insecticide

Name: Ertapenem

Name: Dicyclohexylphthalat

Name: Steviol

Name: Saytzeff rule
Definition: Reaktionsregel

Name: Cassia oil
Definition: Essential oil extracted from parts of the Chinese cinnamon tree

Name: Flavagline
Definition: Class of insecticidal and fungicidal plant constituents from species of the genus Aglaia.

Name: Honokiol

Name: Obidoximchlorid
