Name: Calothrixine
Definition: Calothrixin A or I and calothrixin B or II are metabolites of the cyanobacterium Calothrix with potential antimalarial activity

Name: Photoschalter
Definition: Photoswitches are molecules that undergo structural changes and thus a change in their chemical properties when irradiated with electromagnetic waves, especially in the UV to near IR range

Name: Abemaciclib
Definition: INN

Name: Biogeografie
Definition: Study of the distribution of plants and animals on earth

Name: Organismus
Definition: Concept of biology and natural philosophy

Name: Endocrine regulation
Definition: Regulation by hormones

Name: Hermaphroditismus
Definition: Bisexuality in animals and plants

Name: Artenreichtum
Definition: Diversity of species in a biome

Name: Chronobiologie
Definition: Science of the timing and rhythm of bodily functions

Name: Biologielaborant
Definition: Fachschulausbildung

Name: Biodegradation
Definition: Enzymatic degradation not only by microorganisms, but also by plants, animals and humans.

Name: Biologisch-technischer Assistent
Definition: Ausbildungsberuf

Name: Detritus
Definition: Material from dead animal and plant remains

Name: Ecosystem research
Definition: Benutzt für die Disziplin

Name: Biotopverbund
Definition: Spatial Contact of different biotopes

Name: Gelatinous marine plankton
Definition: Marine plankton without support from a skeleton

Name: Habitat
Definition: Staging area of an animal or plant species within a biotope

Name: Variability
Definition: Used e.g. as a summarizing term for the genetic and environmental variability and diversity of traits in living organisms

Name: Jugendentwicklung
Definition: Not in the sense of developmental psychology, but of ontogeny

Name: Family Biology
Definition: Concept of biological systematics

Name: Unterfamilie
Definition: Concept of biological systematics

Name: Biological activity
Definition: Used mainly for bioactive compounds, not for general biolog. effect

Name: Artificial ecosystem
Definition: Ecosystem e.g. for space flights

Name: Order Biology
Definition: Begriff der biologische Systematik

Name: Tolerance biology
Definition: Also for non-human organisms

Name: Oozyte
Definition: Oocyte before meiosis

Name: Dotter
Definition: Link with narrower SW, e.g. hen's egg ; yolk

Name: Kleinpopulation
Definition: Population with less than 1000 individuals, predominantly extinct organisms

Name: Typusexemplar
Definition: In the biolog. Nomenclature of certain specimens that were present at the time of the first description

Name: Interspecific competition
Definition: Competition between individuals of different species

Name: Intraspecific competition
Definition: Competition between individuals of a species

Name: Patchy distribution
Definition: Distribution of a population over small areas (= patchiness)

Name: Amphibious room
Definition: Transition between terrestr. and aquat. habitat

Name: Vielartenmodell
Definition: Ecological model of the interaction of several species

Name: Untergattung
Definition: Begriff der biologischen Systematik

Name: Autopoiese
Definition: Term coined by the biologist H. Maturana for organizations in which there is no separation between producer and product. Also applicable to social sciences. Self-organization of living systems for self-preservation.

Name: Bodenatmung
Definition: Gas exchange between the soil and the atmosphere near the ground

Name: Hartsubstrat
Definition: Hard ground on which organisms live (e.g. rock)

Name: Secondary biotope
Definition: Biotopes created by human activity (e.g. gravel pits, quarries)

Name: Historical ecology
Definition: Ecology in historical times from a histor. perspective

Name: BIOSIS Previews
Definition: Biolog. Database

Name: Austrian State Prize for Applied Ecosystem Research
Definition: Awarded by the Federal Ministry of Science, Research and the Arts

Name: Biological abstracts
Alternate Name: Bio Sciences Information Service of Biological Abstracts
Definition: Biosciences Database

Name: Makrobenthos
Definition: Benthos over 2 mm in size

Name: Radialsymmetrie
Definition: Radially arranged symmetry elements in biology

Name: Reproductive phase
Definition: Developmental stage of organisms

Name: Temperaturverhalten
Definition: Also for biolog. facts

Name: Mikrobenthos
Definition: Benthos less than 0.2 mm in size

Name: Sexual agglutination
Definition: Aggregation during sexual reproduction

Name: Mikronekton
Definition: Fast-swimming macroplankton organisms in the sea

Name: Hyporheic interstitial
Definition: Gap system of river sediments; "interstitial" according to B1996: also the gap system of the seabed

Name: Jahreszyklus
Definition: Behavioral, metabolic and hormonal adaptations of living organisms to the rhythm of the year

Name: Edaphon
Definition: All soil organisms

Name: Migration Biology
Definition: Migration of animals and plants

Name: Nahrungsangebot
Definition: The amount of organic and inorganic material available to an organism for nutrition. material

Name: Nichtzielorganismus
Definition: Organism that is unintentionally damaged or, in extreme cases, destroyed by plant protection measures

Name: Bioinformatik
Definition: Interdisciplinary research area, which is divided into two areas (computer science in biology and biology in computer science)

Name: Bioprospektion
Definition: Search for biolog. Material with regard to practical applications

Name: Net primary production
Definition: Production of organ. substance, minus the loss through respiration

Name: Revision Systematics
Definition: Scientific work on the systematics of a taxon that is based on new material or new views and critically assesses previous knowledge.

Name: Fire ecology
Definition: Study d. Effect of fire on ecosystems, which is not always destructive; some ecosystems only develop fully through the effect of fire (conifer forests, savannahs, garrigues)

Name: Biology class
Definition: Begriff der biologischen Systematik

Name: Unterklasse
Definition: Begriff der biologischen Systematik

Name: Gattungsgruppe
Definition: Begriff der biologischen Systematik

Name: Thermophilic organism
Definition: Organism that prefers warm habitats or requires them for growth

Name: Biological model
Definition: Model based on biological processes that is created outside of biology

Name: Biology section
Definition: Subdivision in the biological systematics

Name: Biology suborder
Definition: Intermediate category of biological systematics between order (or suborder) and class

Name: Anreicherungsparadoxon
Definition: Species-rich communities often exist in habitats with low production (e.g. nutrient-poor water bodies, nutrient-poor grasslands) or highly productive communities are species-poor even in the presence of major disturbances (e.g. fatty meadows, nutrient-rich water bodies). (Stefan Scheu)

Name: Metapopulation
Definition: Group of subpopulations that interact with each other via the exchange of genes

Name: Predation
Definition: Relationship system between two species in which one species (predator/predator) kills the other species (prey) and uses it as a food resource

Name: Ecosystem service
Definition: Is provided by nature and can be used by humans, e.g. pollination of fruit blossoms by insects

Name: Adult organism
Definition: Organism after sexual maturity, in the zoological field

Name: Holotypus
Definition: The "typical individual" on which the description of a new species is based

Name: Evolutionary developmental biology
Definition: Developmental biology in an evolutionary context, developed in the 1990s

Name: Primary cilia
Definition: Non-motile cilia

Name: LGBT
Definition: Abbreviation for lesbian, gay, bisexual and trans (abbreviation for transgender or transsexual); forms such as LGBTQ, LGBTQI and LGBTQIA* extend the term to include other sexual identities (Q for "queer" or "questioning", I for "intersex"). Forms such as LGBTQ, LGBTQI and LGBTQIA* extend the term to include other sexual identities (Q for "queer" or "questioning", I for intersexuality, A for asexuality; the asterisk stands for people who do not wish to be classified sexually in one of the aforementioned categories).

Name: Lichtfaktor
Definition: Influence of light - intensity, spectral composition, temporal effect - on organisms.

Name: Sklerochronologie
Definition: Methods for analyzing the growth of biogenic hard parts such as exo- and endoskeletons, teeth and otoliths

Name: Alpenrosenrost
Definition: Rust fungus, whose haplophase and regression forms parasitize on spruce, and whose dikaryophases parasitize on alpine rose species

Name: Kohlendioxidsenke
Definition: Areas on earth that absorb more carbon dioxide than they release, e.g. oceans and forests.

Name: Phytodiversity
Definition: plant diversity and the communities they form.

Name: Taxon
Definition: Unit that can be assigned to a group of living beings according to certain criteria. This is usually expressed by giving this group its own name.

Name: Natural system
Definition: Grouping of organisms based on homology and corresponding to their relationships

Name: Biology Virtual Library
Definition: A project of the Johann Christian Senckenberg University Library, Frankfurt am Main, with the participation of several cooperation partners.

Name: Strukturbiologie
Definition: Scientific discipline for determining the structure of biological macromolecules, including structure-function analyses

Name: Wetware computer
Definition: A wetware computer is an organic-based computer (e.g. an artificial organic brain or a neurocomputer) that consists of organic material such as living neurons.

Name: Meeresschnee
Definition: Dying seaweed blooms that cannot be decomposed and form whitish aggregates.

Name: Griffithsin
Definition: Griffithsin is a protein isolated from the red algae Griffithsia

Name: 3 D bioprinting
Definition: 3D printer to produce the tissue from previously cultivated individual cells

Name: Paratypus
Definition: in biology, any specimen of a type series other than the holotype

Name: Genkartierung

Name: Geschlechtsdifferenzierung

Name: Geschlechtsbestimmung
Definition: Determination of gender during individual development through genetic or other factors

Name: Evolutionsbiologie
Definition: Scientific research discipline that covers all aspects of the phylogenetic development (evolution) of organisms.

Name: Phylogenetik
Definition: Phylogeny and development of living organisms in the course of the Earth's history

Name: Psychogenese
Definition: used for the development of the soul life during the evolution of species

Name: Theistic theory of evolution
Definition: Teaching that God created the world through evolution

Name: Meiosis I
Definition: First meiotic division

Name: Meiosis II
Definition: Second meiotic division

Name: Nuklearfaktor 3
Definition: Genet. Factor in the cell nucleus

Name: Isolationsmechanismus
Definition: Prevents a genet. Mixing of different species

Name: Bastardierung
Definition: Mating between conspecifics

Name: Homeobox
Definition: Characterist. DNA sequence of homeotic genes

Name: Telomere molecular genetics
Definition: End sections of eukaryotic chromosomes

Name: Transgenic organism
Definition: Transgenic organisms contain genetic material that has been modified under unnatural conditions (often on a vector)

Name: Retrotransposon
Definition: retrovirus-like, transposable elements of eukaryotes

Name: Replikon
Definition: The replication unit consisting of at least one origin of replication and the DNA or RNA sections covalently linked to it and therefore replicated together.

Name: Gap gene
Definition: Gene class for correct segmentation (Drosophila)

Name: Gene ntrc
Definition: Nitrogen regulation gene

Name: Gentechnisch veränderter Organismus
Definition: Designates transgenic and otherwise modified organisms

Name: Chondroma genetics
Definition: Genetic information localized in the mitochondria

Name: Genetic engineering plant
Definition: Facility in which genetic engineering work is carried out in a closed system

Name: Synthetic theory of evolution
Definition: Theory of evolution based on Darwin's theory of descent, including genetics.

Name: Organism-centered theory of evolution
Definition: Theory mainly further developed by W. F. Gutmann. The central point is the physical foundation of the organism and the evolution of organisms.

Name: Triploidisierung
Definition: Induction of a 3rd set of chromosomes

Name: Genetic imprinting
Definition: the equivalence of the maternal and paternal genome that goes beyond sex chromosomal and cytoplasmic factor-related maternal inheritance

Name: Pair rule gene

Name: Dihaploidie
Definition: Presence of two identical sets of chromosomes

Name: Backcrossing
Definition: Crossing a bastard with its parent type

Name: Homologous recombination
Definition: Recombination between DNA regions due to existing homology.

Name: DNA-typing
Definition: The creation of a genetic fingerprint, biological traces or tissue are examined in order to assign them to a person

Name: Derepression
Definition: Lifting the repression of the gene

Name: Adaptive Radiation

Name: Homoplasie

Name: Nonsensmutation

Name: Corepressor
Definition: Chemical compound for gene regulation

Name: Biological safety
Definition: The aim of all measures aimed at preventing the transfer of recombinant DNA molecules to other organisms

Name: Hedgehog gene

Name: Knockout molecular genetics
Definition: Elimination of genes and their corresponding function by means of recombination or genetic engineering

Name: Evolutionsfaktor
Definition: Factors that are responsible for the change in allele frequencies and thus for adaptation.

Name: Meselson steel experiment

Name: Rudiment
Definition: Remainder, remnants in the sense of evolution

Name: Konstruktionsmorphologie
Definition: Evolutionary biology concept that studies the formation, growth and shape of tissues and organs

Name: Genomik
Definition: Only for the discipline. For the method SW gene analysis is used (note definition)

Name: Molecular evolution

Depending on the living conditions of biological organisms, changes at the molecular level can alter the phenotype.

Name: Human Genome Diversity Project
Definition: A complementary project to the genome project, which aims to identify and distribute alleles of as many different polymorphisms as possible in as many different populations as possible

Name: Epigenetik
Definition: Branch of genetics that investigates how and why genes are switched on and off in different ways without changing the nucleotide sequences of these genes.

Name: Humanized Mouse
Definition: Mice that have been genetically engineered to grow human organs, tissue, etc.

Name: Genotypisierung

Name: Chemical genetics
Definition: Investigation of gene products (proteins) and their functions with low-molecular chemical substances in cells or whole organisms

Name: Gruppenselektion
Definition: Evolutionary concept according to which selection does not act on individuals but on groups of individuals

Name: Polygenie

Name: Shore leave Biology
Definition: Adaptation of aquatic organisms to a terrestrial way of life

Name: Punnett square
Definition: Tool for determining the frequency of different genotypes in the offspring

Name: Chromatinremodellierung

Name: Heterogenie

Name: Prehistoric code

Name: Knockin Molecular Genetics

Name: Microbiome Genetics

Name: Circular RNA

Name: Paleogenetics

Name: Allele Mining

Name: Populationsgenomik

Name: Pax genes

Name: Constraint Evolution

Name: Somatic recombination

Name: Koaleszenztheorie

Name: Fusionsgen

Name: Gene Drive

Name: Biophilie

Name: Biokatalysator

Name: Biomagnetismus

Name: Biomembran

Name: Cytochrome c-553

Name: Molekulargenetik

Name: Proteinbindung
Definition: Binding of substances to proteins

Name: Plasmamembran
Definition: Membrane on the cell surface

Name: Bioenergetik
Definition: Do not use for medical-psychological titles. Title, see bioenergetic analysis

Name: Motility
Definition: Only in the sense of the definition in M; for mobility of joints as motor. ability, mobility <motor skills> is used

Name: Genklonierung

Name: Russupteridine-s-three

Name: Biomolecule

Name: Enzymatic regulation

Name: Ionenkanal

Name: Actomyosin

Name: Adeninnucleotide

Name: Bioenergie

Name: Biotinenzym

Name: Cholinergic system

Name: Cytochrome P-450

Name: Dehydrogenasen
Definition: Hydrogen-transferring enzymes

Name: Ferrichromsynthetase

Name: Fermentation

Name: Guar flour

Name: Histidyl-Transfer-RNS-Synthetase

Name: Hybridzelle

Name: Hydroxymethylglutaryl-Coenzym A

Name: Immobilized enzyme

Name: Kollagenasen

Name: Phytochemie

Name: Prothrombin

Name: Protein p53

Name: Sorbitdehydrogenase

Name: Tuberkulin
Definition: For use on humans in purified form

Name: Urokinase
Definition: INN

Name: Valyl-tRNA synthetase

Name: Wuchsstoff

Name: Zellfusion

Name: Klonierung

Name: Elektronentransportinhibitor

Name: Exonuclease III
Definition: Enzym

Name: Atmungskette

Name: Anchoress CII
Definition: Membranprotein

Name: Periplasmic amylase
Definition: Enzym

Name: Kohlendioxidfixierung
Definition: Absorption and reduction of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the organism

Name: Gene mglB
Definition: coded for galactose binding protein

Name: Operon possible
Definition: coded for methyl galactoside

Name: Phycobiliproteine

Name: Sensorrhodopsin
Definition: bacterial retinal protein

Name: Insertionselement

Name: Gene nif
Definition: nitrogene fixing genes

Name: Transposon

Name: Adhesin

Name: Endothelium-derived contracting factor

Name: Ammoniumassimilation

Name: Thyroxine L-

Definition: INN

Name: Gene GBP-1

Name: Mil

Definition: According to the template, liaison refers to the equivalence relation of subschemata in projective space; term in algebraic geometry

Name: Derivative equivalence
Definition: Concept of category theory

Name: Salem quantity
Definition: Compact set whose Hausdorff and Fourier dimensions coincide

Name: My-Calculus
Definition: A logic in which predicates can be defined recursively.

Name: Permanent room
Definition: A topological space is called projective if it is the projective limit of finite discrete spaces.

Name: Prox regularization
Definition: Method used to perturb convex minimization problems in order to increase their stability

Name: Hypergruppe
Definition: Hypergroups are a generalization of locally compact groups. In contrast to deterministic group operations, the result of linking two elements of a locally compact space depends on chance

Name: Mahler measure
Definition: Concept in the theory of transcendental numbers

Name: Hemivariationsungleichung
Definition: Hemivariational inequalities are a generalization of variational inequalities and occur in mechanics, engineering and economics in connection with non-convex energy functionals and other non-monotonic multivalued laws

Name: NEC Group
Definition: Discrete subgroup of the isometry group of hyperbolic space

Name: Punkttransformation
Definition: Transformation that transforms the underlying point set and not overlying functions or similar.

Name: Categorical logic
Definition: Branch of algebraic logic that works with the means of category theory

Name: Discrete element method
Definition: Mathematical model for discontinua, e.g. rock, consisting of individual block elements with discrete consideration of the interface structure

Name: hp method
Definition: hp-FEM is a general version of the finite element method (FEM), a numerical calculation method for solving partial differential equations based on the piecewise approximation with elements of different sizes (h) and polynomials of different degrees (p).

Name: Local analytical geometry
Definition: The theory of analytic spaces has two aspects: the local and the global aspect (Enc. math.)

Name: Permutationsmenge
Definition: Term in combinatorics

Name: Eigenraum
Definition: Eigenspace denotes the subvector space spanned by the eigenvectors for a particular eigenvalue of an endomorphism. (Wikipedia)

Name: Partial geometric design
Definition: P.g.D. form a generalization of designs and partial geometries

Name: Wahlfolge
Definition: A term in intuitionistic mathematics that expresses the potential infinity of the continuum by interpreting the decimal fractional expansion of a real number as a free and infinite choice of its sequence members.

Name: Billiards mathematics
Definition: Two-dimensional model system of chaos theory

Name: Hurwitz room
Definition: Hurwitz spaces are moduli spaces for finitely branched superpositions of curves

Name: Oseen equation
Definition: Oseen's glide can be used as a model for the flow around bodies with viscous non-compressible fluids (Meyer, S.)

Name: Yetter-Drinfeld-Hopf algebra
Definition: Yetter-Dr.-H.-Alg. are Hopf algebras in a certain quasisymmetric monoidal category, namely the category of Yetter-Drinfeld modules (Y. Sommerhäuser)

Name: Daubechies wavelet
Definition: Orthogonal wavelets with compact carrier

Name: Wigner equation
Definition: Integrodifferential equation witch describes the motion of a particle ensemble. Quantum counterpart of the classical Liouville equation (You, Luyu).

Name: Discrete logarithm
Definition: The inverse problem to the modulo exponentiation is finding the discr. Log. (Find x for a to the power of x = b (mod n)). A mathematically hard problem. The security of many asymmetric encryption methods is based on this problem.

Name: Mathematics style
Definition: The intersection form in the most important invariant of a 4-dim manifold (Enc. Math.).

Name: Automatic sequence
Definition: Sequences with values in a finite set that satisfy certain, by no means obvious regularities

Name: Partial plane
Definition: A system of points, straight lines and an incidence relation

Name: Commutativity-preserving mapping
Definition: Mappings that map pairs of commutating elements to pairs with the same properties

Name: Markov extension
Definition: TT from the theory of dynamic systems

Name: Lorenz illustration
Definition: TT aus der Theorie der dynamischen Systeme

Name: AF-Algebra
Definition: A C*-algebra is called AF-algebra if A is the inductive limit of an inductively directed system of finite-dimensional C*-algebra.

Name: Kähler Differents
Definition: Fitting ideal of the differential module of a ring extension

Name: Time-frequency analysis
Definition: Subfield of harmonic analysis

Name: Zyklenraum
Definition: Each graph has a pair of mutually orthogonal vector spaces associated with it, the cycle space and the cocycle space; these determine the structure of the graph as a binary matroid.

Name: Lie-Algebroid
Definition: A Lie algebroid is a vector bundle A (smooth, real and finite dimensional unless otherwise specified), the module of sections of which has a Lie algebra structure over R which interacts with the module structure via a Leibniz rule with respect to a bracket-preserving vector bundle map (the anchor) from A to the tangent bundle of the base. The term Lie algebroid was introduced in 1966 by Pradines. There is an alternative usage in algebraic geometry; but this rarely causes confusion.

Name: Channel area
Definition: Enveloping surface created by a movable sphere with variable radius (with constant radius: tube surface)

Name: Tube area
Definition: Enveloping surface of a moving sphere with constant radius

Name: Element-free Galerkin method
Definition: A spec. netless (numerical) method. Mesh-free (= element-free) methods do not require an element structure for the num. No element structure is required for the numerical solution of a partial DGl. but a set of nodes is used to approximate the solution.

Name: Differential equation without initial values
Alternate Name: Differential equation on the real axis
Definition: Differential equations of 1st and 2nd order for which no boundary or initial value conditions are given (S. Schweiker)

Name: Bisector operator
Definition: The spectrum of these operators is contained in a double sector

Name: Orr-Sommerfeld equation
Definition: A central equation in the stability theory of incompressible, friction-bound flows

Name: Regulated variety
Definition: Ruled varieties are unions of a family of linear spaces

Name: Wigner distribution
Definition: The W.-V. is a time-frequency representation that was originally developed for quantum physics (Wigner 1932). In the meantime, it has also found its way into signal analysis (Ville 1948).

Name: AT-freier Graph
Definition: A class of graphs

Name: Zehn
Definition: Zahlzeichen 10

Name: Discrete tomography
Definition: Field of applied mathematics, concerned with the reconstruction of three-dim. Objects from information about projections of the objects

Name: Dialgebra
Definition: Generalization of associative algebras: Instead of a link, a left-hand and a right-hand link are defined between the elements

Name: Ornamentgruppe
Definition: 1. the 17 plane symmetry groups that are created by linking translation, rotation and reflection. Describe mathematically exactly the symmetry of twofold periodic plane patterns (=plane ornaments). 2. discrete motion groups of the plane, which contain translations in two linearly independent directions. 3. the 17 plane crystallographic groups (=2D space groups).

Name: Switch communication technology
Definition: Coupling elements between several segments of a network (Voss 2001)

Name: Positive solution
Definition: Lösung von Gleichungen

Name: Implikationsgraph
Definition: A directed graph describing the logic value dependencies among the line values in a circuit

Name: Euclidean algorithm
Definition: Calculation method for determining the greatest common divisor

Name: Resolventenprinzip
Definition: Theorem of predicate logic 1st level

Name: Splitdekomposition
Definition: Method for decomposing discrete structures

Name: Smolyak algorithm
Definition: Method of numerical integration

Name: BDF procedure
Definition: Linear multi-step method with implicit, backward differentiation formulas

Name: Smith normal form
Definition: Diagonal matrix D uniquely determined by the m*n matrix A. It is obtained from A by unimodular row and column operations.

Name: Mortar element method
Definition: In numerical analysis, Mortar methods are discretization methods for partial differential equations that use separate finite element discretizations for non-overlapping subdomains.

Name: Quantenkohomologie
Definition: Mathematical theory whose origins lie in quantum field theory

Name: Ausdehnungslehre
Definition: First representation of n-dimensional Euclidean geometry from 1844

Name: Miquel plane
Definition: A classic Benz level

Name: Dominanzzahl
Definition: Term from graph theory

Name: Aggregationsoperator
Definition: Aggregation is the summarizing of data or values by means of a calculation rule. This rule is called an aggregation op.

Name: Trapezzerlegung
Definition: Decomposition of the plane, important problem from the field of algorithmic geometry

Name: Church-Rosser theorem
Definition: The Church-Rosser theorem states that the relation R, with E1 R E2 g.d.w. E2 was created from E1 by beta-reduction, has the diamond property.

Name: Level set method
Definition: 1. mathematical method for the numerical calculation of geometric objects and their movement. 2. numerical methods with which the temporal development of boundary surfaces such as the surface of a soap bubble can be described.

Name: Euler-Lagrange-Gleichung
Alternate Name: Euler differential equations, calculus of variations
Definition: Non-linear differential equation associated with a variational problem. Depending on the circumstances, an ordinary, a partial or a system of differential equations is obtained (abc mathematics under Euler's differential equation).

Name: Stable level
Definition: One particularly nice class of topological planes are the so called stable planes (Internet: Anke Wich).

Name: Hierarchical matrix
Definition: Representation of a matrix in a product-index tree structure with rank-k matrices in the admissible blocks and fully populated matrices in small non-admissible blocks. (Lars Grasedyck)

Name: Binomial formula
Definition: Special cases of the binomial theorem

Name: Zsigmondy element
Definition: element (g) of a group such that a power of g is an element of prime order acting irreducibly on a subspace (author).

Name: Primzahltest
Definition: A test to determine whether or not a given number is prime

Name: Network graph theory
Definition: A connected directed graph with exactly one source, exactly one sink and one capacity function

Name: QR algorithm
Definition: Method for solving eigenvalue problems

Name: GR algorithm
Definition: Decomposition algorithm for calculating eigenvalues of matrices

Name: Smoothed Particle Hydrodynamics
Definition: A grid-free simulation method for solving hydrodynamic equations of motion, Langrange method, to simulate fluids (in the broadest sense).

Name: Multibread quantity
Definition: Multibrot sets have all of the same features and properties of the Mandelbrot set including Juli sets.

Name: Partition set theory
Definition: Decomposition of a set into disjoint, non-empty subsets.

Name: Rechenscheibe
Definition: Slide rule calculator with circular, concentrically arranged scales

Name: Trigonometric moment problem
Definition: Terminologically unclear whether synonymous with Markov moment problem

Name: Straubing-Thérien hierarchy
Definition: A special concatenation hierarchy

Name: Dot-depth hierarchy
Definition: Eine spez. Konkatenationshierarchie

Name: Mathematics flag
Definition: Ascending sequence of subspaces of a vector space

Name: Sexagesimalsystem
Definition: Place value system based on 60, developed in Babylonia

Name: Nef polyhedron
Definition: Nef polyhedra are the most general model for rectilinearly bounded subsets of affine space. Any set that can be obtained from the open halfspaces by afinite number of set complement and intersection operations. The set otf Nef-P. ist closed unter the Boolean set operations.

Name: Normal circle area
Definition: A one-parameter circular array in which the center points pass through a C-3 curve, the central curve (Ebeling, F.)

Name: Bewachte Logik
Definition: Guarded logics are a more recent generalization of modal logics and are fragments of predicate logic, fixed point logic or second level logic

Name: Milliken room
Definition: Space of all ascending infinite sequences of pairwise disjoint, non-empty subsets of the set of natural numbers (author)

Name: Staffelwalzenmaschine
Definition: Mechanical rake, consisting of several rollers with axis-parallel ribs of different lengths.

Name: Stangenzirkel
Definition: Aid for drawing very large circles. A stick with an attached tip, lead or drawing pen.

Name: Differential Galois theory
Definition: A generalization of ordinary Galois theory to differential equations

Name: Square number
Definition: A natural number is called "square-full" if each of its prime divisors occurs at least twice in it, i.e. if p2n necessarily follows from p/n for each prime number p.

Name: Theodorsen integral equation
Definition: The Th.-Integralgl. is useful to compute the conformal mapping of the unit disk onto the interior of a simple connected domain ... (MATH).

Name: Flat graph
Definition: The intersection-free embedding of a planar graph in the plane

Name: Qualokationsverfahren
Definition: Method for the numerical treatment of boundary integral equations

Name: Statistical linearization
Definition: Approximation methods for non-linear systems with random disturbances

Name: Stratified space
Definition: Stratif. Spaces are collections of differentiable manifolds that are "glued together" in a suitable way. Due to this characteristic, the original names were "Complexes of Manifolds" or "Manifold collections" (Pflaum, M.).

Name: Spiral type surface
Definition: Spiral type surfaces are highly symmetric minimal surfaces. They (and their complex homotheticals) are the only minimal surfaces that can be unrolled on spiral surfaces. Special spiral surfaces are the Bour surface, the spiral minimal surface, the catenoid (chain surface) and the Enneper minimal surface (P. Staab)

Name: Barbašin equation
Alternate Name: Integrodifferential equation of the Barbashin type
Definition: Special integro-differential equation whose right-hand side contains both a multiplication operator and an integral operator

Name: Schlussregel
Definition: Transformation rule (transformation rule) in a logical calculus, i.e. a rule that allows existing expressions of a formal language to be transformed in such a way that new expressions are created that follow from the existing expressions. (Wikipedia)

Name: Planimeter
Definition: Device for mechan. Measurement of curvilinear flat surfaces

Name: Mixed graph
Definition: Graph that contains both directed and undirected edges. Graph that contains both arrows and edges

Name: Degenerate bilinear form
Definition: Method of mathematical physics

Name: Cayley graph
Definition: The Cayley graph of a group is a directed graph whose node set is the elements of the group.

Name: Hessian matrix
Definition: The matrix of second-order partial derivatives

Name: Golden Compass
Definition: Instrument for calculating the golden ratio

Name: Unterteilungsalgorithmus
Definition: Subdivision algorithms are very simple and fast algorithms for generating a sequence of increasingly finer polygons from a polygon, which converges very quickly towards a curve or surface.

Name: Simplex overlap
Definition: Overlapping of a simplex, where the elements are again simplices

Name: Achievable category
Definition: Generalization of the locally presentable categories

Name: Locally presentable category
Definition: Special case of the achievable category

Name: Dominating game theory
Definition: Strategy in game theory

Name: Wavelet analysis
Definition: Application of the wavelet transform to a function or a discrete signal

Name: Bivariate spline
Definition: Splines, which are defined with respect to suitable triangulations of a given two-dimensional base area (Zeilfelder, University of Stuttgart).

Name: Proportionalzirkel
Definition: Math. instrument for drawing similar figures and performing simple calculations

Name: Binomialbaum
Definition: A binomial tree is a directed tree with a sorting condition

Name: Hölder room
Definition: Banach space of bounded continuous functions defined on an n-dimensional Euclidean space and satisfying the Hölder condition

Name: Stokes phenomenon
Definition: The property of a complex function to have different asymptotic representations in different regions of the complex plane

Name: Linienelement
Definition: Line elements clearly define the properties of manifolds in differential geometry.

Name: Lattice Boltzmann method
Definition: Numerical method for simulating flow and transport processes. The simulation is carried out at the particle level. In contrast to the lattice gas method, continuous particle densities are used instead of binary particles.

Name: TVD procedure
Alternate Name: Difference method with vanishing total variation
Definition: Difference method with TVD property

Name: Dualraum
Definition: The dual space V * of a vector space V over a body K is defined as the set of all linear functions from V to K. The elements of V * are also referred to as linear forms. (Wikipedia)

Name: Operator splitting procedure
Definition: Method that breaks down complex equations into various partial equations.

Name: Sylvester Medal
Definition: Awarded since 1901 for outstanding achievements in pure mathematics

Name: Solution space
Definition: Vector space of the solutions of a homogeneous LGS

Name: Levi problem
Definition: The Levi problem consists of the question: Is every pseudo-convex domain a holomorphic domain?

Name: Ansatzfunktion
Definition: Function which is still dependent on parameters, but which is assumed to already correspond to the type of solution sought

Name: Vektorextrapolationsmethode
Definition: Vector extrapolation methods are used to accelerate the convergence of vector sequences.

Name: Logarithmic spiral
Definition: Spiral that increases the distance from its center, the pole, by the same factor with each revolution. In the opposite direction of rotation, the curve loops ever more tightly around the pole as the radius decreases. Every straight line through the pole always intersects the logarithmic spiral at the same angle.  (Net lexicon)

Name: T-standard
Definition: The main purpose of t-conorms in fuzzy theory is to construct the union of fuzzy sets (union operator). However, it can also be seen as a generalization of addition. (J.Siedekum)

Name: T-standard
Definition: The main purpose of t-norms in fuzzy theory is to construct the average of fuzzy sets (average operator). However, they can also be seen as a generalization of multiplication. (J.Siedekum)

Name: Affine arithmetic
Definition: A special set arithmetic, generalization of interval arithmetic. In affine arithmetic, a quantity x is described by an affine form.

Name: Blunt quantity
Definition: A set M of points of the plane is called obtuse if every three points of M are always the vertices of an obtuse triangle. (Federal Mathematics Competition 1990)

Name: Kleene algebra
Definition: An algebraic structure that generalizes the operations known from regular expressions. An idempotent semiring with an additional unary operator, called the Kleene star. Effective tool for the formal treatment of various areas of computer science. Related system: Relational calculus.  AMS MSC: 68Q70;20M35

Name: Gaussian function
Definition: Probability density of the normal distribution

Name: Exponentially modified Gaussian function
Definition: A proven model function for "curve fitting of chromatographic peaks", description of emission spectra, etc. It is obtained by convolving a Gaussian function with an exponential function

Name: Kepler conjecture
Definition: Kepler assumed that the densest way of stacking spheres was to arrange them on top of each other in a pyramid shape

Name: Panel Clustering
Definition: An efficient algorithmic tool for the numerical approximation of matrix-vector products in boundary element methods for the weak formulation of boundary integral equations (Internet)

Name: Computermathematik
Definition: New degree program at the interface between mathematics and computer science

Name: NCP Functions
Definition: NCP functions are mainly used to convert non-linear complementarity inequalities into an equivalent system of equations (Internet).

Name: Lagrange relaxation
Definition: This type of relaxation of a complex optimization model results from the fact that constraints of the model are omitted, but the extent of their violations is weighted (penalized) in the objective function using suitable (Lagrange) multipliers.

Name: Konstruktion mit Zirkel und Lineal
Definition: Geometric construction using only a compass and ruler

Name: Primitive element
Definition: Generating element of a body or group.

Name: Nichols algebra
Definition: A Hopf algebra with additional properties. Generalization of the symmetric algebra.

Name: Bowen series illustration
Definition: The orbit-equivalent Markov map of the boundary circle of a Fuchsian group, whose existence Bowen and Series proved for every finitely generated Fuchsian group of 1st kind.

Name: Uniformes Polychor
Definition: A four-dimensional analog of the uniform polyhedra. (MathWorld)

Name: Polychor
Definition: A polytope in four dimensions. (Weisstein / MathWorld)

Name: Fractal dimension
Definition: Measure of the irregularity of a fractal, a factor for the increase in its length, surface area or volume. (Internet, M.Schreier)

Name: Fourier transform
Definition: The image function created by Fourier transformation.

Name: Gleichungslogik
Definition: G. examines how new equations can be logically deduced from given equations.

Name: Resultantenverfahren
Definition: Method for solving polynomial systems of equations in several variables

Name: Nachbarschaftsgraph
Definition: In neighborhood graphs, similar or neighboring points are connected with an edge. They are used wherever the shape and structure of point sets are of interest (e.g. computer vision, pattern recognition, algorithmic morphology, cartography, geography, biology). (K. H. Anders)

Name: Butlergruppe
Definition: Pure subgroups of fully decomposable torsion-free abelian groups

Name: Central path
Definition: A curve that is important when solving optimization problems using an interior point method.

Name: P-Matrix
Definition: A matrix is called a P-matrix if all main minors are positive

Name: Linguistic variable
Definition: A variable whose characteristics are linguistic variables, i.e. words of everyday language. Linguistic variables can be formalized using the theory of fuzzy sets.

Name: Merkmalsraum
Definition: A feature space is the n-dimensional space that can be spanned if n features are used for a classification. (Lex. Geoinformatics - online)

Name: Bargmann room
Definition: Space of all analytical functions above the complex plane.

Name: Multifraktal
Definition: Fractals with location-dependent fractal dimension

Name: Richard Lieben Prize for Mathematics
Definition: 1912-1928 triennial prize awarded by the Austrian Academy of Sciences

Name: Konjugationsproblem
Definition: Problem which concerns conjugate elements of a group (def. in spectrum lex. mathematics). Used for the security of asymmetric encryption methods.  Under best. Under certain conditions, the conjugation problem is reduced to a word problem.

Name: Wavelet-Transformation
Definition: Integral transformation of a function with respect to a fixed wavelet.  Representation of a signal in terms of both frequency and time.

Name: Buchberger algorithm
Definition: Algorithm for calculating Gröbner bases.

Name: Inzidenzmatrix
Definition: An incidence matrix is a way of representing a graph in a computer. The incidence matrix is an n-by-m matrix, where n is the number of nodes and m is the number of edges of a graph (Wikipedia).

Name: Invariant quantity
Definition: A special non-empty and compact subset of a dynamic system

Name: Distribution Multiplicity
Definition: Subbundles of tangent bundles of manifolds

Name: Angel structure mathematics
Definition: A special rank-2 distribution on a 4-manifold

Name: Forest graph theory
Definition: a graph without circles

Name: Real analytical function
Definition: function, which can be represented locally by its Taylor series.

Name: Immersed Interface Method
Definition: Numerical methods based on a regular, non-edge-adapted grid.

Name: Navier-Lamé equations
Definition: Second-order differential equation system describing the vibrations in an elastic material

Name: Monadic logic
Definition: Logic that only allows single-digit (monadic) predicates (only contains single-digit predicate symbols).

Name: Matrixoperator
Definition: Operators that are characterized by matrices.

Name: Technical mathematics
Definition: A collective term for all mathematical methods used specifically in the technical sciences. Technical mathematics, technomathematics or engineering mathematics are, depending on the university, designations for mathematics courses with an in-depth engineering minor.

Name: Gaussian calculator
Definition: Mechanical calculating machine, built in 1904/1905

Name: Special linear group
Definition: The special linear group of degree n over a body F (or more generally a unitary ring), SL(n,F), is the group of all n×n matrices with coefficients from F whose determinant is 1. Group linking is the matrix multiplication. A normal subgroup of the general linear group GL(n,F). (Wikipedia)

Name: Discrete root
Definition: The discrete root of a natural number n is the largest natural number k for which the following applies: k squared less than or equal to n

Name: Closed manifold
Definition: A compact manifold without an edge

Name: Quasimetrik
Definition: The distance function of a quasimetric is not symmetrical

Name: Quasi-pseudo-metrics
Definition: A quasi-pseudo-metric fulfills the axioms of a metric except for the requirement of positivity and symmetry

Name: Presburger arithmetic
Definition: 1. first level theory of natural numbers without multiplication. 2 Presburger arithmetic axiomatizes the properties of addition of natural numbers. 3. the Presburger arithmetic corresponds to the Peano arithmetic without the two axioms for defining multiplication.

Name: Matching graph theory
Definition: A set of edges M in a graph G is called matching if M contains no loops and no two edges in M have a common end node. (Prof. Dr. M. Grötschel)

Name: Cantor room
Definition: 1. topological space that is homeomorphic to the Cantor set.  2. the Cantor space consists of all infinite binary sequences. 3. product space of countably many copies of {0, 1}.

Name: Automaton Theory
Definition: 1. abstract models of machines. They are used in theoretical computer science as a construct to analyze and prove certain properties of problems and algorithms (Wikipedia). 2. an automaton is a general term for any formal model of computation (PlanetMath).

Name: Disturbance index
Definition: The central term in the classification of DAEs is the so-called index, which occurs in various variants: disturbance index (differentiability index, global index, treatability index, strandedness index). (Dr. R. Stöver, University of Bremen)

Name: Morlet wavelet
Definition: A modulated Gaussian function

Name: Venn diagram
Definition: Topological representations of set relationships

Name: Cauchy-Kowalewski existence theorem
Definition: Ensures on a small scale the existence and uniqueness of an analytical solution of Cauchy's initial value problem in the analytical case

Name: Biharmonic function
Definition: Any four times continuously differentiable function that satisfies the biopotential equation.

Name: Unterhalbverband
Definition: A subset of a complete lattice that is closed with respect to either the infimum formation or the supremum formation. If the subset is closed to both suprema and infima, it is called a complete sub-assembly.

Name: Locally finite graph
Definition: An infinite graph where the neighborhood of each node is finite.

Name: Derived subgraph
Definition: Induced subgraphs that have no isolated nodes.

Name: Adjazenzmatrix
Definition: A graph with n nodes can be represented by an n-by-n matrix. To do this, the nodes are numbered from 1 to n and the relationships between the nodes are entered in the matrix. (Wikipedia)

Name: Willmore area
Definition: Generalization of minimum areas

Name: Universal logic
Definition: Analogous to universal algebra, universal logic is a general theory of logical structures

Name: Association product Mathematics
Definition: Abstract versions of special subdirect products

Name: Monte Carlo integration
Definition: 1. stochastic integration method for high-dimensional integrals or irregular integration domains.  2. most important application of Monte Carlo methods for the numerical calculation of high-dimensional integrals

Name: Fluent calculus
Definition: Formalism for modeling actions and changes

Name: Schrödinger-Poisson system
Definition: System of partial differential equations for the description of quantum mechanical effects in semiconductors.

Name: Discrete model
Definition: Discrete variables are used instead of continuous variables

Name: Normalgleichung
Definition: The equation whose solution is precisely the solution to the linear balancing problem frequently encountered in balancing calculations.

Name: Neutral Action-Methode
Definition: Method for the construction of conservation laws, also suitable for such systems for the Lagrange function exists.

Name: Ricci River
Definition: Geometric evolution equation

Name: Sattelpunktmethode
Definition: Numerical method for the approximate calculation of special integrals

Name: Dynamic geometry
Definition: The interactive creation of geometric constructions on the computer. Mainly used in geometry lessons.

Name: GEONExT
Definition: Geonext is a very powerful program for elementary geometric constructions

Name: Kerr-Newman metric
Definition: The Kerr-Newman metric (after Roy Patrick Kerr and Ezra T. Newman) is an exact, asymptotically flat, stationary and axially symmetric solution of the Einstein equations for electrically charged, rotating black holes. In the case of an electrically neutral black hole, the Kerr-Newman metric simplifies to the Kerr metric. (Wikipedia)

Name: Vedic mathematics
Definition: Rules of calculation which were worked out from the Veda by Bharati Krishna Tirthaji between 1911 and 1918. They were published posthumously in 1965 and are said to be based on a lost appendix of the Atharvaveda. However, various authors doubt the traceability to the Veda. This type of arithmetic is based on 16 rules. It has similarities with the Trachtenberg system, as it speeds up some arithmetic calculations (Wikipedia).

Name: Souslin tree
Definition: Tree of height N1 that has no uncountable branches and no uncountable sets of pairwise incomparable elements

Name: Fast-Marching-Method
Definition: Numerical method for calculating nonlinear eikonal equations and static Hamilton-Jacobi equations

Name: TI-Nspire CAS
Definition: Taschenrechner

Name: Standardmonomentheorie
Definition: Some special results and methods of representation theory are summarized under the term standard monomial theory (STM). (From Appel, Katrin: Standard monomials for wonderful compactifications of groups)

Name: Fuzzy logic type 2
Definition: Generalization of conventional fuzzy logic (type 1)

Name: Sangaku
Definition: Wooden panel depicting geometric problems during the Edo period

Name: Extended finite element method
Definition: Numerical calculation method that extends the solution space of the classical finite element method by the solution of the differential equation for discontinuous functions.

Name: Ausnahmealgebra
Definition: The simple Lie groups can be classified according to their root systems and are divided into the classical and the exceptional Lie algebras

Name: Jordan curve set
Definition: Theorem of topology

Name: Mada's brand
Definition: Markenname

Name: Adix calculator
Definition: Mechan. Calculating machine, built from 1903

Name: Smith chart
Definition: Tools for complex alternating current calculation

Name: Rhombus Mathematics
Definition: Equilateral parallelogram

Name: Spira calculator
Definition: Mechanical calculating machine, produced 1910-1912

Name: Pilgrim step transformation
Definition: Method for finding one-parameter subgroups of topological groups

Name: Geodesic triangle
Definition: Triangle whose sides are geodesic lines. lines are

Name: Quantitative logic
Definition: Combination of mathematical logic and probability calculation (according to template)

Name: Baker-Campbell-Hausdorff formula
Definition: Equation that specifies a permutation law for certain linear operators

Name: Kegelstumpf
Definition: Cone without tip

Name: Dacometer
Definition: Calculating machine d. Company Dacorema

Name: Pólya-Szegö principle
Definition: Integral equation from functional analysis

Name: Quantity-oriented method
Definition: Calculation of invariant sets, manifolds or measures for the analysis of the long-term behavior of dynamic systems

Name: Fast-growing function
Definition: Algorithm of theoretical computer science

Name: Ore algebra
Definition: Ore algebra is an algebra of noncommutative polynomials representing linear operators for functional equations such as linear differential or difference equations. Ore polynomials satisfy particular commutation relations.

Name: Abel Prize
Definition: Prize named after N. H. Abel, comparable to the Nobel Prize, awarded annually by the Norwegian Academy of Sciences for outstanding achievements in mathematics.

Name: Facta calculator
Definition: Small mechanical calculating machine for multiplication, built 1925-1930 in Vienna by the company Facta Rechenmaschinenwerk Leo Borger

Name: Sehnenviereck
Definition: Quadrilateral whose vertices lie on a circle, the circumcircle. All sides are therefore chords of the circle.

Name: Catalan figures
Definition: named after the Belgian mathematician Eugène Charles Catalan; sequence of natural numbers that appears in many combinatorics problems

Name: Kepler equation
Definition: M=E-e*sinE

Name: New Year's Eve matrix
Definition: In algebra, the Sylvester matrix for two polynomials is a special matrix populated with the coefficients of the polynomials, whose determinant gives the resultant of the polynomials. It is named after the British mathematician James J. Sylvester.

Name: Kelvin Cell
Definition: Generally used as a mathematical model for the numerical simulation of polycrystalline and cellular materials, foams.

Name: Hilbert's problem 5
Definition: Can coordinates be chosen for an arbitrary, locally Euclidean, topological group in such a way that they have the structure of a Lie group? Andrew Gleason, Deane Montgomery and Leo Zippin finally solved the problem in the 1950s.

Name: Concavity
Definition: concave nature, inward curvature, negative curvature, analytical functions

Name: Müller matrix
Definition: The concept of the Müller matrix allows the transformation of Stokes vectors. Stokes vectors describe the polarization of an electromagnetic wave.

Name: Wielandt subgroup
Definition: The Wielandt subgroup of a group G is the average of all subnormal subgroups of G.

Name: Connected-component labeling
Definition: Connected-component labeling is a heuristic based on graph theory to summarize regions with graphically common features in images.

Name: Coklasse
Definition: The coclass of a finite p-group of order p^n is the difference n - c of its composition length n and its nilpotent class c. The concept of a coclass can also be defined in a similar way for nilpotent associative algebras.

Name: Quadratgitter
Definition: The square grid is a grid that fills the two-dimensional Euclidean space by arranging squares of the same size edge to edge and corner to corner.  The corners are the grid squares. The square lattice plays a role as a model system in geometry, crystallography and solid state physics, among others.

Name: Finite cell method
Definition: The FCM is a fictitious domain approach based on high-order finite elements.

Name: Fictitious domain method
Definition: In mathematics, the Fictitious domain method is a method to find the solution of a partial differential equations on a complicated domain D, by substituting a given problem posed on a domain D, with a new problem posed on a simple domain Omega  containing domain D.

Name: Gompertz function
Definition: Asymmetrical saturation function

Name: Frobenius method
Definition: The Frobenius method is a method for solving second-order ordinary differential equations.

Name: Orthogonales Wavelet
Definition: An orthogonal wavelet is a wavelet whose associated wavelet transform is orthogonal.

Name: Hair wavelet
Definition: The Haar wavelet is the simplest known wavelet, named after Alfréd Haar, and can be formed from the combination of two rectangular functions.

Name: Topological conjugation
Definition: In mathematics, one speaks of topological conjugation when there is a homeomorphism that conjugates one continuous mapping to another. The concept is of greater importance in the analysis of dynamic systems, especially when considering discrete systems.

Name: k-Jet Mathematics
Definition: Class of mappings of the touch order k

Name: Kontaktgeometrie
Definition: "The mathematical field of contact geometry is a subfield of differential geometry that deals with certain geometric structures on differentiable manifolds, namely with completely non-integrable fields of hyperplanes in the tangent bundle, so-called contact structures." (Wikipedia: Contact geometry)

Name: Numerical linear algebra
Definition: "Numerical linear algebra is a central subfield of numerical mathematics. It deals with the development and analysis of calculation methods (algorithms) for problems of linear algebra, in particular the solution of linear systems of equations and eigenvalue problems." (Wikipedia: Numerical linear algebra)

Name: Algebraic linguistics
Definition: "Algebraic linguistics is a branch of mathematical linguistics that uses formal methods (algebra, theoretical computer science, formal logic/mathematical logic, set theory) to formalize grammars[.]" (Wikipedia: Algebraic linguistics)

Name: Kakeya problem
Definition: Kakeya's needle problem asks for the minimum area in the plane on which a needle of unit length can be completely rotated 360 degrees. It goes back to the Japanese mathematician Sōichi Kakeya.

Name: Kakeya quantity
Definition: A Kakeya or Besicovitch set is a set of points in Euclidean space that contains a unit line segment in each direction.

Name: Large cardinal number
Definition: "In set theory, a cardinal number is called a large cardinal number if its existence cannot be proven with the usual axioms of Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory (ZFC)." (Wikipedia: Large cardinal number)

Name: Mouse set theory
Definition: In set theory, a mouse is a small model of a fragment of Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory.

Name: ALE method
Definition: The Arbitrary Lagrangian Eulerian method (ALE method) is a possibility in computational fluid dynamics to couple an Eulerian formulation with a Lagrangian formulation in order to solve free-surface problems, multiphase flow problems or fluid-structure coupling problems.

Name: Frobeniusnorm
Definition: "In mathematics, the Frobenius norm or Schur norm (named after Ferdinand Georg Frobenius or Issai Schur) is a matrix norm based on the Euclidean norm. It is defined as the root of the sum of the absolute squares of all matrix elements." (Wikipedia: Frobenius norm)

Name: Euklidische Norm
Definition: "The Euclidean norm, standard norm or 2-norm is a vector norm frequently used in mathematics. In two- and three-dimensional Euclidean space, the Euclidean norm corresponds to the visual length or magnitude of a vector and can be calculated using the Pythagorean theorem. More generally, the Euclidean norm is also defined for real and complex vector spaces of arbitrary finite dimension and is then the norm derived from the standard scalar product." (Wikipedia: Euclidean norm)

Name: Conclusion on the best explanation
Definition: Conclusion with which a certain hypothesis is distinguished from other hypotheses

Name: Motivational integration
Definition: "Motivic integration is a notion in algebraic geometry that was introduced by Maxim Kontsevich in 1995 and was developed by Jan Denef and François Loeser. Since its introduction it has proven to be quite useful in various branches of algebraic geometry, most notably birational geometry and singularity theory. Roughly speaking, motivic integration assigns to subsets of the arc space of an algebraic geometry, a volume living in the Grothendieck ring of algebraic varieties. The naming 'motivic' mirrors the fact that unlike ordinary integration, for which the values are real numbers, in motivic integration the values are geometric in nature." (Wikipedia: Motivic integration)

Name: Poincaré-Bendixson theorem
Definition: Theorem for proving the existence of limit cycles in two-dimensional non-linear differential equation systems; used primarily in mathematical business cycle theory. Named after the French mathematician Henri Poincaré (1854-1912) and the Swedish mathematician Ivar Bendixson (1861-1935)

Name: Lissajous figure
Definition: Superposition curves of two mutually perpendicular oscillations

Name: Vigesimalsystem
Definition: A number system based on the base number 20

Name: Brachistochrone
Definition: Curve between two points P1 and P2, on which a smoothly sliding mass point moves from P1 to P2 in the shortest possible time under the influence of gravity, which is assumed to be constant

Name: Replikatorgleichung
Definition: System of ordinary differential equations used in mathematical biology

Name: Morsetheorie
Definition: "Die Morsetheorie aus dem Bereich der Differentialtopologie gibt einen sehr direkten Zugang zur Analyse der Topologie einer Mannigfaltigkeit über das Studium differenzierbarer Funktionen auf dieser Mannigfaltigkeit." (Wikipedia: Morsetheorie)

Name: Hilbert's problem 17
Definition: Formulation: Can any rational function that takes non-negative values everywhere it is defined be represented as the sum of squares of rational functions?

Name: Neutrosophic logic
Definition: Note: Neutrosophic logic is not a scientifically verified or recognized theory in mathematics.

Name: Sekante
Definition: A straight line that passes through two points on a curve. Concept from plane geometry and analysis.

Name: Lie system
Definition: "Lie systems form a class of systems of first-order ordinary differential equations[...]" (Quelle: https://arxiv.org/abs/1103.4166)

Name: Topological data analysis
Definition: Application of topological methods to problems of data analysis, in particular the quantification of the geometric shape of a data cloud

Name: Persistent homology
Definition: Algebraic method to recognize topological properties of data

Name: Non-commutative function
Definition: Function that is an element of a non-commutative algebra

Name: Commutative diagram
Definition: In mathematics, a commutative diagram describes how different concatenations of mappings produce the same result.

Name: Topological full group
Definition: Object in topological dynamics

Name: Matrix completion
Definition: Filling in the missing entries of a matrix that is only partially observed. Matrix completion is equivalent to solving an imputation problem and occurs, for example, in machine language processing.

Name: Zylinderkoordinaten
Definition: Plane polar coordinates supplemented by a third coordinate

Name: Sub-Riemannian manifold
Definition: Type of a generalized Cauchy-Riemann manifold

Name: p-Laplace operator
Definition: Generalization of the Laplace operator

Name: flat module
Definition: Flatness of modules is a generalization of the term "free module".

Name: Asymptotic geometric analysis
Definition: Mathematical field of research that deals with the properties of high-dimensional normalized spaces and convex bodies.

Name: Metric entropy of a dynamic system
Definition: An important invariant in ergodic theory

Name: Mixed finite element method
Definition: Finite element method in which additional fields (boundary conditions) are taken into account by Lagrange multipliers.

Name: Coconvex quantity
Definition: Complement of a convex, closed set which has a finite volume

Name: Set of Fuglede
Definition: Theorem from operator theory proved by B. Fuglede and generalized by C. R. Putnam

Name: Arrangement of hyperplanes
Definition: An arrangement of hyperplanes is a finite set of hyperplanes in a vector space.

Name: Holomorphic dynamics
Definition: Theory of dynamic systems defined by iteration of a holomorphic mapping

Name: Subgrid model
Definition: Representation of important small-scale physical processes that cannot be adequately resolved in a numerical grid.

Name: String diagram
Definition: Formal graphical representation, especially in applied category theory

Name: Kommakategorie
Definition: Construction in mathematical category theory

Name: Adjunct radio operator
Definition: In category theory, adjunction describes that functors mediate a relation between sets of morphisms.

Name: Cartan subalgebra
Definition: A subalgebra of a Lie algebra is called a Cartan subalgebra if it is nilpotent and self-normalizing.

Name: Split Lie Algebra
Definition: Term from Lie theory

Name: homogeneous graph
Definition: A graph for which each isomorphism between two induced subgraphs results in an automorphism of the entire graph that maps them to each other

Name: ordered graph
Definition: A graph with an order relation on the nodes

Name: Topological recursion
Definition: Construction from algebraic geometry with applications e.g. in mathematical physics

Name: Set of Mazur-Ulam
Definition: Mathematical theorem stating that every surjective isometry of normalized spaces is an affine mapping.

Name: injective metric space
Definition: Metric space that fulfills certain tightened convexity conditions

Name: Mathematics lamination
Definition: Generalization of the topological concept of scrolling

Name: Jensen's inequality
Definition: Significant inequality for convex functions

Name: Simplicial quantity
Definition: Konstruktion in der mathematischen Kategorientheorie

Name: Atomic measure theory
Definition: In terms of a generalized concept of volume, a set is an atom if each subset has the same volume or zero volume.

Name: Alternating group
Definition: The alternating group A_n is a subgroup of the symmetric group S_n, which contains all even permutations.

Name: Quadratic binary optimization without constraints
Definition: Combinatorial optimization model with a wide range of applications

Name: Limited cohomology
Definition: Mathematical concept with applications in group theory and topology of manifolds

Name: Quantum Walk
Definition: Quantum information analog to the random walk

Name: Regularity structure
Definition: The theory of regularity structures developed by Martin Hairer allows the study of certain classes of stochastic partial differential equations from quantum field theory.

Name: Barnes integral
Definition: Curve integral over a product of gamma functions that is closely related to generalized hypergeometric functions.

Name: Distanzmatrix
Definition: Symmetrical matrix that specifies the distances between the points of a set

Name: Richtungsfeld
Definition: Graphical representation of the solution set of a differential equation

Name: Factor Functional Analysis
Definition: Von Neumann algebra with trivial center

Name: Subfactor Functional Analysis
Definition: In the theory of Von Neumann algebras, a subalgebra is a subalgebra that is a factor and contains the one-element.

Name: Spectral curve Integrables system
Definition: Concept in the theory of integrable systems

Name: Bratteli diagram
Definition: Graph used in functional analysis for the study of AF algebras

Name: Messraum
Definition: Basic concept of measure theory, consisting of a basic set and a sigma algebra. A measure space can be extended with a measure to form a measure space.

Name: Weierstrass polynomial
Definition: Polynomial of holomorphic functions; subject of Weierstrass' preparatory theorem in function theory.

Name: Cardinality
Definition: The concept of cardinality generalizes the number of elements of a set to infinite sets.

Name: Countable quantity
Definition: On the one hand, the term "countable set" can refer to countably infinite sets of the same power as the natural numbers. On the other hand, it can also refer to finite, at most countable sets.

Name: Zorn's lemma
Definition: Theorem of Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory, which states that every inductively ordered set has at least one maximal element.

Name: p-variation
Definition: Measure for the smoothness of a function in analysis

Name: Rectifiable quantity
Definition: Central concept of geometric measure theory, which generalizes differentiable manifolds.

Name: Varifaltigkeit
Definition: Measure in geometric measure theory. Varifolds allow the generalization of differentiable manifolds

Name: Differential Transform Method
Definition: Method developed by J. K. Zhou (1986) for solving in particular non-linear differential equations

Name: Knotenpolynom
Definition: Invariant in node theory, which assigns a polynomial to each node

Name: Khovanov homology
Definition: Homology in knot theory with close relationship to knot polynomials

Name: Hexadezimalsystem
Definition: Place value system for base 16

Name: Hilbert's problem 19
Definition: Formulation: Are all solutions of regular variational problems analytic? Answered positively by De Giorgi and Nash in the 1950s.

Name: Parallel-in-time integration
Definition: Numerical method for solving differential equations by parallelizing over the time axis.

Name: Algebraic stack
Definition: In mathematics, algebraic stacks generalize the notions of algebraic spaces and algebraic schemes.

Name: Non-Newtonian Calculus
Definition: (Marginal) mathematical systems designed by Michael Grossman and Robert Katz 1967-1970, in analogy to the usual differential and integral calculus

Name: Fokas method
Definition: Solution method for boundary value problems

Name: Smale horseshoe illustration
Definition: Nonlinear mapping; model system in chaos theory

Name: Oloid
Definition: Convex envelope of two circles of equal size that intersect perpendicularly and whose centers are at a distance from each other that is equal to their radius.

Name: Planar algebra
Definition: In mathematics, planar algebras are a subject of research in category theory.

Name: Cubic Threefold
Definition: In algebraic geometry, cubic threefold denotes a hypersurface of degree three in four-dimensional projective space.

Name: Height function
Definition: Height functions quantify the complexity of mathematical objects and thus allow them to be counted.

Name: Manin conjecture
Definition: The Manin conjecture about the distribution of rational points on an algebraic variety is an open research question in mathematics. It is different from the (proven) Manin-Mumford conjecture.

Name: Turning point analysis
Definition: Regular curve point with tangent touching at least three points

Name: Weighted projective straight line
Definition: Object in the mathematical discipline of representation theory

Name: Spiralwelle
Definition: Two-dimensional wave in which a center emits a wave front that propagates in a spiral.

Name: Modularity set
Definition: Mathematical theorem that establishes a relationship between elliptic curves over the body of rational numbers and modular forms.

Name: McShane identity
Definition: Mathematical theorem on the lengths of closed geodesics on hyperbolic surfaces

Name: Graphon Mathematics
Definition: Measurable function used in graph theory as a tool for studying dense graphs

Name: Quasi-isometry
Definition: Mapping between metric spaces that preserves their rough geometry.

Name: Carleman estimate
Definition: Estimation for solutions of partial differential equations

Name: Evolutionsstrategie
Definition: Method that mimics the mechanisms of biological evolution as an iteration rule for optimizing decision problems

Name: GLIM
Definition: Social science program package and statistical programming language

Name: Log-linear model
Definition: Model for multivariate analysis of discrete variables in the social sciences

Name: Optimal test planning
Definition: Statistical experimental design

Name: Optimierung
Definition: The theory and practice of maximizing (or minimizing) a function (objective function) subject to a set of constraints - sub-discipline of applied mathematics.

Name: Availability
Definition: Probability of finding a system in a functional state at a given time (availability)

Name: Cluster analysis
Definition: Various data analysis methods for determining groups (clusters) of related objects from a basic set of numerically described objects. The objects can be, for example, data sets of measured values or pixels in which ordered collections or hierarchies are to be found. Cluster analysis methods can be used for automatic classification, for recognizing patterns in image processing and for data mining. (Wikipedia)

Name: Varianz
Definition: Mean square deviation of a random variable from its expected value.

Name: Linear ordering problem
Definition: A special NP-hard problem of combinatorial optimization

Name: Entartungsgraph
Definition: For mathem. Optimization

Name: Stochastik
Definition: Summarizing term for all methods for the mathem. Treatment of random phenomena.

Name: LISREL
Definition: Stoch. Equation system and computer program for the analysis of causal models with latent variables

Name: Generalized linear model
Definition: Multivariate statistical method

Name: Mathematisches Spiel
Definition: Only used for game theory; in the sense of entertainment mathematics see entertainment mathematics and for mathematical educational game use arithmetic game

Name: Bernoulli principle
Definition: Decision-making principle in the case of risk, at the same time normative theory of decision-making behavior in the case of risk.

Name: Orderly game
Definition: Power relation in the game results in a linear order. The player group is called ordinally bequeathed

Name: Interactive optimization
Definition: Optimization process in which the decision-maker specifies his (preference) specifications step by step with the solution of the optimization task (in interaction)

Name: Scattering Stochastics
Definition: Dispersion is an expression of the variability of a characteristic in a population and is quantified by measures of dispersion.

Name: Linear complementarity problem
Definition: Problem of non-lin. Optimization

Name: Statistical database
Definition: Databases that represent statistical or summary information and are used for statistical analysis

Name: NETRASS
Definition: Network Reliability Analysis Support System

Name: Statistical measure
Definition: Characteristic numerical values as a function of available data, which quantitatively characterize a certain fact. Characteristic numerical values as a function of available data that quantitatively characterize a certain fact (Kriz: Methoden-Lex.)

Name: Warteschlangennetz
Definition: Network of operating systems

Name: Steiner problem
Definition: Optimization problem of routing or location selection of (traffic) routes

Name: Wartesystem
Definition: Operating system in which all requests that are not operated immediately can wait.

Name: Warteschlangentheorie
Definition: Areas of application of probability theory in which stochastic models for operating situations (operating systems) are examined. Examples are the operation at counters or in stores, the switching of long-distance calls, repair of broken down machines or devices.

Name: Apex game
Definition: Game with one apex player (strong player) and several base players (weak players). Coalition between apex and 1 base player or coalition of all base players

Name: Maximum Clique Problem
Definition: Graph Theoret. Model of location planning

Name: SPSS-X Tables
Definition: Module of the SPSS-X program system for table display

Name: SPSS-X Trends
Definition: Module of the SPSS-X program system for time series analysis

Name: Two-armed bandit
Definition: Naming after a slot machine

Name: Covering location problem
Definition: Problem of nationwide distribution of supply facilities

Name: Byzantine unification
Definition: Byzantine agreement deals with the problem of realizing a reliable broadcast in a distributed system, even if some of the participants (including the sender) are arbitrarily faulty. In particular, this includes malicious behavior.

Name: Circular statistics
Definition: Sub-discipline of statistics that deals with directions (unit vectors in Rn), axes (lines through the origin in Rn) or rotations in Rn. In general, directional statistics deals with observations on compact Riemannian manifolds

Name: Gestaltoptimierung
Definition: Optimal shaping and optimal progressions of shape-describing functions

Name: Greedy algorithm
Definition: Class of algorithms that gradually select the subsequent state that promises the greatest gain or the best result at the time of selection (e.g. gradient method). (Wikipedia)

Name: P-median model
Definition: Combinatorial model of location planning

Name: PRELIS
Definition: Preprocessor for LISREL

Name: PARAFAC
Definition: Principal component analysis method

Name: Complete binding
Definition: Property stochast. Systems, e.g. Markov chains

Name: Nearest neighbor problem
Definition: Distance problem in algorithmic geometry: determine a nearest neighbor for all points in a set

Name: Longest path problem
Definition: Classical problem of graph theory, equivalent to shortest path problem

Name: Optimierungsproblem
Definition: OB for problems such as the traveling salesman problem, backpack problem, etc.

Name: Wegeproblem
Definition: Problem of graph theory

Name: LMS (LS)
Definition: Method for analyzing latent multimoderated structural equation models using corrected least squares estimation.

Name: Tabusuche
Definition: Search procedure in which already accepted solutions are eliminated as "taboo"

Name: Penalty method
Definition: Penalty methods are procedures for solving optimization problems

Name: Sequential quadratic optimization
Definition: Currently regarded as the most efficient universally applicable method for solving nonlinear optimization problems

Name: Randomized polynomial
Definition: A randomized polynomial over the integers is a multi-valued polynomial whose coefficients are integer random variables

Name: Lévy process
Definition: Markov process with independent increments (MSC 60J30)

Name: SETARMA model
Definition: Extension of the ARMA models for non-linear processes

Name: Schatteneckenalgorithmus
Definition: A variant of the simplex method

Name: Bisektionsproblem
Definition: Optimization problem from graph theory: Dividing a graph into two equal parts so that the number of edges is optimal.

Name: Edge process
Definition: Belongs to the class of stochastic processes used to describe phenomena in stationary physics and biology

Name: Dantzig-Wolfe decomposition
Definition: Solution principle for optimization tasks

Name: Graphical chain model
Definition: Generalization of the regression models. Special stat. Models in which an additional graphical representation contributes to better visualization.

Name: Tower of Hanoi
Definition: Mathematical puzzle dealing with the restacking of stacks of disks of different sizes.

Name: Copula mathematics
Definition: A function is called a copula if it is a two-dim. distribution function with a best. marginal distribution.

Name: Karhunen-Loève transformation
Definition: Term in the spectral theory of stochastic processes

Name: Intervallwahrscheinlichkeit
Definition: Generalization of the class. Generalization of the classical concept of probability, in which each event is no longer assigned a single real number, but an interval as a probability component (Th. Augustin).

Name: Feedback-vertex-set problem
Definition: A combinatorial optimization problem on graphs

Name: Bayesian network
Definition: Bayesian networks are used to represent uncertain knowledge and possible conclusions. A Bayesian network is a directed acyclic graph (DAG)

Name: Rhineland-Palatinate State Statistical Office Anniversary 1998
Definition: Celebration of the 50th anniversary of the State Office

Name: Graphical model
Definition: Statistical models with graphs

Name: Verlustsystem
Definition: Operating system in which all requests that are not immediately served are immediately rejected.

Name: Robbins-Monro process
Definition: General model of a stochastic approximation algorithm

Name: Extended Lagrange method
Definition: Method for solving non-lin. optimization tasks

Name: Bedienungssystem
Definition: Stochastic model for describing queues. It contains the components arrival flow (source), waiting room, control point, departure flow (sink).

Name: Rubinstein game
Definition: A dynamic 2-player game with an infinite time horizon

Name: Relative risk
Definition: Quotient (ratio) of the incidence rates among exposed persons (exposed group, e.g. smokers) and non-exposed persons (control group, e.g. non-smokers).

Name: Odds ratio
