Definition: Quotient (ratio) of two odds. Odds: Ratio of the probability that an event will occur to the probability that the event will not occur. A specific measure of risk (statistical measure)

Name: Branch-and-Cut-Methode
Definition: Special branch-and-bound methods in which the relaxation is solved using a cutting plane method. (GTS Systems & Consulting GmbH).  A hybrid of branch and bound and cutting plane methods

Name: Bayesian inference
Definition: Statistical inference using a Bayesian decision function

Name: EM algorithm
Definition: A general method for determining maximum likelihood estimates of probabilistic models.

Name: Buffon's needle problem
Definition: Determination of the probability P

Name: Statistical consulting
Definition: Advice on the application of statistical methods

Name: Rainflow process
Definition: Two-parameter statistical counting method

Name: Fat tail distribution
Definition: Fat tails are the so-called "fat ends" at the end of a probability distribution that are caused by extreme events

Name: Panjer recursion
Definition: Efficient algorithm for the calculation of cumulative distributions

Name: Intraklassenkorrelation
Definition: Measure of observation agreement and thus an indicator of the reliability of the underlying observation system

Name: Testmenge
Definition: Term in optimization

Name: Biostatistik
Definition: Application of methods of mathematical statistics in the biological and related sciences

Name: Lower partial moment
Definition: A measure of downside risk computed as the average of the squared deviations below a target return. This measure is more general than semi-variance, which is computed as the average of the squared deviations below the mean return.(Dict. Fin. Risk Man.)

Name: Non-parametric regression
Definition: In non-parametric regression, it is assumed that an observation Y at t has the form Y=f(t)+Z, where Z is an error and f is an unknown function. The aim is to estimate the unknown regression function f using observations at t1, ..., tN. While in parametric regression the function f is known down to a finite number of parameters, much less is known about f in non-parametric regression. For example, it is sometimes only assumed that f is Lipschitz-continuous.

Name: Crossover test
Definition: Areas of application for cross-over plans are nutritional studies, therapy studies for chronic diseases and bioavailability studies. diseases and bioavailability studies.

Name: Heavy-tailed distribution
Definition: This distribution is characterized by the fact that a few random numbers represent outlier values which result in the variance of the distribution being infinite. (Internet)

Name: Minority game
Definition: The minority game is a game theory model in which an odd number of N players have to make a decision (+1 or -1, buy or sell...) independently of each other at each time step and those who are in the minority win.

Name: Random mosaic
Definition: A random mosaic is a model from stochastic geometry that describes a random decomposition of the plane or space into non-overlapping, bounded convex polytopes called mosaic cells.

Name: Poisson hyperplane mosaic
Definition: Decomposition of Rn by (n - 1)-dimensional hyperplanes into convex polytopes

Name: U-Statistics
Definition: Statistics with asymptotic normal distribution

Name: Hausdorff moment problem
Definition: specific moment problem

Name: QQ plot
Definition: Scatter plot of the percentiles of a theoretical distribution over the percentiles of an empirical distribution or data set

Name: Standardabweichung
Definition: Positive square root of the variance, an important measure of dispersion

Name: Broken Brownian motion
Definition: Generalization of Brownian motion (Hurst parameter H between 0 and 1)

Name: Dunnett test
Definition: Comparison of several treatments against one control (many-to-one situation)

Name: Machtindex
Definition: Describes the decision-making weight of individual partners in majority decisions. The "classic" power indices are the Shapley-Shubik index and the Banzhaf index.

Name: Pursuit-Evasion Game
Definition: In Pursuit-Evasion Games, an agent (Predator) pursues his victim (Evader). The Predator's aim is to catch the other agent. The Evader, in turn, tries to evade its hunter as much as possible.

Name: Fuzzy cluster analysis
Definition: Unlike classical cluster analysis, fuzzy cluster analysis does not create sharp boundaries between classes and their objects, but allows fuzzy assignments, whereby classes may overlap in border areas. Objects can be simultaneously assigned to two classes that are not clearly separated from each other; they belong to different classes with different degrees of affiliation (Internet).

Name: Randomized Branch Sampling
Definition: A multistage sampling method that uses the natural branching within a tree to take incremental samples with the aim of estimating one or more target variables on the tree. Developed in 1955 to estimate the number of fruits on fruit trees, used e.g. to estimate needle/leaf biomass or needle/leaf area

Name: Maximum cut problem
Definition: Combinatorial optimization problem

Name: Letter carrier problem
Definition: Special route planning problem in which the shortest possible route through the entire street network has to be found from a given location.  In practice, this problem arises when delivering mail to the houses in a district, but also when carrying out refuse collection, street cleaning or reading electricity and water meters in households. Mathematically exact: For a given connected graph, find a closed edge set consisting of as few edges as possible, but containing each edge at least once.

Name: Capacitated Arc Routing Problem
Definition: Problem from the class of edge-oriented route planning problems (arc routing)

Name: Cluster data analysis
Definition: A set of objects that have a high similarity to each other with regard to (some of) their characteristics and a low similarity to objects outside the cluster.

Name: Dichtebasiertes Clusterverfahren
Definition: In this method, those areas in d-dimensional space in which data points are close together are regarded as clusters. The clusters are then separated by areas of lower data density.

Name: Super Brownian motion
Definition: A measure-valued Markov process that plays an important role as a limit value of systems of branching Brownian particles or other interacting particle systems. (Mörters, TU Berlin)

Name: Independent component analysis
Definition: Method of statistical data analysis and signal processing for decomposing multivariate signals into their source components

Name: Bin packing problem
Definition: The problem is to pack objects into as few containers as possible. ("bin" means box, bucket or container)

Name: Metaheuristik
Definition: Metaheuristics are general strategies that support other heuristics in the search for optimal solutions. They are characterized by the fact that they use simple principles, often borrowed from nature or physics (nature-inspired). Algorithms that are used in combinatorial optimization.

Name: Branch-and-Price-Methode
Definition: Special branch-and-bound methods in which the relaxations are solved using the column generation technique. (GTS Systems & Consulting GmbH)

Name: Likelihood quotient test
Definition: Procedure for comparing models based on the maximum likelihood estimation method. Two models are compared in each case: an initial model, which generally contains several model parameters, and a comparison model in which restrictions are imposed on one or more of these parameters. The comparison is always used to check whether the unrestricted model is significantly "better" than the restricted model, i.e. has a better fit. If this is not the case, the restricted model is preferable because it is simpler (and yet not worse in terms of explanatory power). (ILMES - Internet-Lexikon der Methoden der empirischen Sozialforschung)

Name: Nadaraya-Watson estimator
Definition: Kernel estimator, estimator for kernel regressions, belongs to the non-parametric regression smoothers, statistical smoothing method, method of non-parametric regression analysis.

Name: Stochastic particle system
Definition: Area of mathematics that deals with the stochastic description of models of many interacting components.   Areas of application: Models in statistical mechanics and mathematical biology, e.g. modeling of lattice gases, dynamics of interfaces, biological evolution, description of cell behavior or traffic flows.

Name: Transferoperator
Definition: Transfer operators assign an initial distribution of states (more generally: a measure) to the corresponding distribution at a later point in time. Essential statistical information about the system can be obtained from their spectral properties and associated invariant measures (Prof. Dr. W.-J. Beyn). Frequently used in the fields of dynamical systems, statistical mechanics, quantum chaos and fractals.

Name: Kaplan-Meier estimate
Definition: Nonparametric estimation of the survival function in the presence of right-censored data.

Name: Korrelationsmatrix
Definition: Quadratic table of all correlations between several variables

Name: WinRATS 6.1
Definition: The statistical-econometric computer program WinRATS was developed from program predecessors (SPECTRE) by Tom Doan and further developed by the company he founded, ESTIMA (Evanston, Illinois, USA). RATS stands for Regression Analysis of Time Series. It has been programmed in C since 1991 and has since been available for Windows (WinRATS), Macintosh (MacRATS) and UNIX (UNIX RATS).

Name: Classification and regression tree
Definition: Method of statistical classification

Name: EDA Optimization
Definition: Generalization of genetic algorithms ( Wikipedia)

Name: Concentration Probability distribution
Definition: Method for generating discrete distributions

Name: Stone estimation
Definition: Special point estimate introduced by W. James and C. Special point estimate for the expected value (vector) of random variables introduced by W. James and C. Stein

Name: Fisher information
Definition: Parameter from math. Statistics; provides information on the best possible quality of parameter estimates

Name: Gnuplot
Definition: Function plotter, a script- or command line-controlled computer program for the graphical representation of functions and data

Name: Datentiefe
Definition: Measures for the centrality of an object

Name: Particle swarm optimization
Definition: Population-based stochastic optimization method

Name: Derivative-free optimization
Definition: Derivation-free methods of optimization

Name: Minimalkostenflussproblem
Definition: Kombinatorisches Optimierungsproblem

Name: Robust optimization
Definition: Subfield of optimization for dealing with uncertainties due to tolerances in the input parameters of the problem

Name: Tabletop game
Definition: Strategy game system in which miniature figures are played on any surface (especially tables).

Name: Forschungsdaten
Definition: Data generated in the course of scientific projects, e.g. through digitization, source research, experiments, measurements, surveys or interviews.

Name: Allan variance
Definition: The Allan variance, named after David W. Allan, also known as the two-value variance, is a measure of the frequency stability of clocks and oscillators.

Name: Direct simulation Monte-Carlo-Methode
Definition: The "Direct simulation Monte Carlo method" uses stochastic simulation (Monte Carlo simulation) to solve the Boltzmann equation for defined Knudsen numbers of flows. Developed in the early sixties of the 20th century by G. A. Bird for the simulation of highly diluted gases, extended and improved by the developer in 1994

Name: WinBUGS
Definition: WinBUGS is a software program that is used for questions of Bayesian statistics with the aid of Monte Carlo simulation. The name WinBUGS is made up of BUGS (Bayesian inference Using Gibbs Sampling) and Microsoft Windows as the only directly compatible operating system.

Name: IBM SPSS Statistics 25
Definition: Statistics program. Up to version 17 with the following name form: SPSS 17 for WINDOWS.

Name: Miles equation
Definition: The Miles equation is derived using a single degree of freedom system (SDOF), i.e. a single-mass oscillator with light damping, consisting of a mass, a spring and a damper, which is excited by a random oscillation in the range 0 Hz to infinity. The Miles equation is technically applicable for pure SDOF systems. As a rule, the Miles equation is used to calculate the root mean square (r.m.s.) of the vibration response of elastic structures subjected to random loads.

Name: Koordinationsspiel
Definition: Coordination games are a class of games with multiple Nash equilibria in pure strategies in which the players choose the same or corresponding strategies. Coordination games describe the coordination problem, which is widely used in social sciences and economics, i.e. that all participants can achieve joint gains, but only if they make uniform decisions. A well-known application is the choice of technical standards

Name: FHP model
Definition: "The FHP model is an elementary lattice gas model and a cellular automaton for the simulation of gases and liquids. It is also known as Lattice Gas Cellular Automata (LGCA)." (Wikipedia: FHP model)

Name: MM algorithm
Definition: The MM algorithm is an iterative optimization method that uses the convexity of a function to determine its maxima or minima.

Name: Mehrebenenanalyse
Definition: "Multilevel modeling[1], also known as hierarchical linear modeling[2], is a group of multivariate statistical methods for the analysis of hierarchically structured data (nested data), which are mainly used in empirical social research." (Wikipedia: Multilevel analysis)

Name: Censored data
Definition: Data of which a part is only incompletely known (e.g. of which it is known that they are greater than a certain limit value, but the exact values are unknown)

Name: Stichprobenverzerrung
Definition: A bias in the sample whereby some elements of the target population have a higher or lower probability of selection than others.

Name: Approximate Bayesian Computation
Definition: Bayesian statistical methods for models without analytical expression of the likelihood function

Name: Probabilistic programming
Definition: A programming paradigm in which probabilistic models are specified and inference for these models is performed automatically. Probabilistic programming languages are used.

Name: Bayesian model
Definition: Probabilistic model applied in a Bayesian process

Name: Verteilungskonvergenz
Definition: Convergence concept in statistics, which corresponds to weak convergence in the sense of measure theory

Name: Latin Hypercube Sampling
Definition: Statistical method for generating samples from a multivariate probability distribution

Name: spike-and-slab regression
Definition: Bayesian linear regression method in which the a priori distribution is made up of a narrow (spike) and broad (slab) component

Name: Bayesian Model Averaging
Definition: Bayesian method, which explicitly includes the uncertainty resulting from the choice of model in the analysis.

Name: Energiedistanz
Definition: Measure of the similarity of probability distributions

Name: Unsicherheitsquantifizierung
Definition: Quantitative characterization and estimation of uncertainties, in particular in and by means of numerical models

Name: Empirical measure
Definition: In probability theory, an empirical measure is a random measure that results from a particular realization of a (usually finite) sequence of random variables.

Name: Markov additive process
Definition: A class of two-component stochastic processes

Name: Compositional data analysis
Definition: Statistical analysis of compositional data, taking into account their mathematical characteristics such as non-negative values and relative frequencies of different components that add up to 100%.

Name: Maximum a posteriori estimate
Definition: Bayesian estimation method that estimates an unknown parameter using the modal value of the a posteriori distribution

Name: Transition core
Definition: Mapping between measurement spaces in probability theory that fulfills certain conditions.

Name: Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution
Definition: Two-parameter generalization of the Poisson distribution

Name: IBM SPSS Statistics 29
Definition: Statistikprogramm. Bis zur Version 17 mit folgender Namensform angesetzt: SPSS 17 für WINDOWS.

Name: Turnpike theory
Definition: Describes systems in which the "optimal route" depends only insignificantly on the exact choice of the start and end points.

Name: Datenmanagementplan
Definition: Instrument for structuring research data in scientific projects projects

Name: Skorochod embedding
Definition: Representation of random variables using Wiener processes

Name: Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel tests
Definition: Non-parametric test method for categorical data. The related approaches of Cochran on the one hand and Mantel and Haenszel on the other are summarized by some authors.

Name: Automat
Definition: 1. devices that execute a process without direct human involvement (lex. cybernetics). 2. machines, devices, appliances, etc. in which a programmed process runs automatically after an input (Brockhaus). 3. systems that receive, process and output information (Brockhaus).

Name: Benutzerfreundlichkeit
Definition: a criterion of ergonomics, which means that a computer system is tailored to the needs of the user. In the case of hardware, the main criteria are low-radiation screens, low noise levels, well-designed keyboards and a mouse that is comfortable to use. Software is user-friendly if it is error-tolerant, behaves in line with expectations and offers a clear user interface (software ergonomics)

Name: Berechnungstheorie
Definition: Mathem. Logic, Theoret. computer science

Name: Bildverarbeitung
Definition: 1. analysis of the information contained in images using generally digital signals. 2. modification of a digitized image with a specialized program.

Name: Biosignalverarbeitung
Definition: Biosignal plus signal processing or signal transduction used in medicine and the life sciences

Name: Code
Definition: Rule for assignment during coding

Name: Computer crime
Definition: All criminal or punishable acts committed using or against information and communication technology (ICT).

Name: Datenbank
Definition: Organized collection of electronic data that are logically related (RDA AH-007).

Name: Datenverarbeitung
Definition: General term for the acquisition, modification, structuring and output of data in any system. In most cases, however, DV refers to automated processing in electronic DV systems.

Name: Datenverwaltung
Definition: 1. in the broad sense: the management of all data stored in a system in terms of order, access, updating (lex. DV) 2. in the narrow sense: data management (esp. in connection with programs) mainly used for the management and expansion of data stocks of a very special structure (e.g. management of addresses). Data management programs are simple application programs for semi-professional use. More powerful programs are referred to as database programs or database systems (dtv-Comp.-Lex.).

Name: Dialogverarbeitung
Definition: Operating mode of a computer system in which the system responds to individual input values and guides the user (operator) in the form of a dialog

Name: Digital system
Definition: A system that assigns binary output values (or sequences of output values) to binary input values (or sequences of input values) in a defined manner (Wuttke, H.D.).

Name: Kontrolltheorie
Definition: Math. theory of the "control" of systems. Important field of application of mathematics. The subject of K. is the targeted influencing (control) of dynamic systems, which arise in various forms in the (mathematical) modeling of practical problems from the natural, technical, economic and social sciences.

Name: Artificial intelligence
Definition: Branch of computer science concerned with the automation of intelligent behavior. (Luger)

Name: Mehrprozessorsystem
Definition: Closely coupled, parallel systems with shared memory. (TB computer science)

Name: Mikroprozessor
Definition: 1. miniaturized processor housed on one or a few integrated components (chip). (Brockhaus) 2. a highly integrated circuit (IC) that performs the function of a processor. ( M+T Computer Lexicon)

Name: Natural language
Definition: Only used in computer science and information and documentation, not in linguistics

Name: Roboter
Definition: In engineering and computer science, preferably SW robotics, industrial robots or narrower TT.

Name: Schaltwerk
Definition: used for digital technology

Name: Software
Definition: 1. any intangible component of a computer system. 2. collective term for programs, data and associated documentation (RDA AH-007).

Name: Syntactic analysis
Definition: Used for natural and formal languages

Name: System Dynamics
Definition: Method for the representation, analysis and dynamic simulation of complex systems, whereby the structure of the developed models is essentially formed by feedback relationships.

Name: Systemtheorie
Definition: Interdisciplinary science that deals with the comparative study of systems. The main systems considered are: organisms (animals, humans, especially cognitive mechanisms in organisms), machines (especially computers), physical systems, psychological and social systems.

Name: CAD
Definition: A method of designing and constructing objects using appropriate computer systems and specialized software with special graphics capabilities. (B Computer)

Name: Rechnernetz
Definition: A data network in which at least two data stations are independent operational computers and in which every data station can communicate with every data station (Wirtschaftsinformatik-Lex.)

Name: Minicomputer
Definition: Computer group between PC or workstation and mainframe or supercomputer

Name: Hacker
Definition: 1. computer professionals dedicated to finding and publishing security holes and information. 2. individuals who are totally absorbed by computer technology and computer programming. 3. individuals who break into systems and networks to steal, alter or delete data.

Name: Mailbox
Definition: Originally the term for an electronic mailbox on a computer for storing messages (e-mail). Today also (in German-speaking countries) the term for special computers that are accessible via telecommunications networks and offer bulletin boards, files for downloading and some Internet services. In English-speaking countries: Bulletin Board System.

Name: Programmpaket
Definition: Coordinated individual programs for different areas of application that can be operated according to the same scheme. As a rule, existing program packages should be indexed with the subject-SWW for the application areas and the form-SW program.

Name: Software Engineering
Definition: Practical application of scient. Knowledge for program development

Name: Termersetzungssystem
Definition: Reduction systems that reduce terms to a minimal form

Name: In-house network
Definition: 1)Generic term for private branch exchanges, local networks (LAN) and manufacturer-specific DV networks (Gabler). 2)Now (as of 2002) obsolete term for local networks (Lipinski)

Name: Datenbanksprache
Definition: Quasisynonym

Name: Infinite word
Definition: Algorithmentheorie

Name: Biometrie
Definition: Automatic identification / verification of persons based on personal characteristics (voice, fingerprints, etc.). Personal identification through unchangeable physical characteristics.

Name: Datenverarbeitungssystem
Definition: The entirety of hardware, software and the organization of data processing, in more recent times especially for large-scale DV, in contrast to SW computers

Name: Maschinelles Sehen
Definition: The computer-aided solution of tasks based on the capabilities of the human visual system.

Name: Algorithmic geometry
Definition: Subfield between (not necessarily algorithmically interested) discrete geometry on the one hand and numerous applications ranging from visualization and computer graphics to optimization on the other.

Name: Pyramidal multiprocessor system
Definition: Pyramid-shaped arrangement of the processors of a multiprocessor system

Name: User interface
Definition: Part of the human-machine interface that is recognizable to the user. Screen display of the computer/software function that enables the user (in the simplest possible way) to communicate with the operating system or application program.

Name: Flussdiagramm
Definition: not used as a keyword; here see diagram. Representation technique for illustrating complex statements about the functioning and dynamic properties of a system.

Name: Programmierumgebung
Definition: Summary of all tools for program development in one system and their operability from a menu-driven user interface (B Computer)

Name: EDV-Expert
Definition: Without legal notice USW

Name: Softwareproduktionsumgebung
Definition: The combination of software development principles, design methods and tools into an integrated system to support the development of software systems.

Name: Desktop publishing
Definition: Creating a printable layout on the workstation computer

Name: Algebraic coding
Definition: Error-detecting and correcting codes

Name: Automatic programming
Definition: Automatic generation of program code by a generator. Programming paradigm in methodical software development (Wikipedia).

Name: Computersimulation
Definition: Computer simulation is the execution of a simulation with the help of a computer, or more precisely: a computer program. This program describes or defines the simulation model.

Name: Dreidimensionale Rekonstruktion
Definition: Method for computer-internal modeling and visualization of solid objects from a sequence of sections or projections.

Name: ESPRIT research program
Alternate Name: First European strategic program for research and development in the field of information technology
European strategic programme for research and development in information technology
Definition: Program adopted by the EG Council of Ministers in 1984

Name: Geometrische Modellierung
Definition: Design, calculation and representation of curved objects by computer

Name: Graphensprache
Definition: Language whose sentences are represented in the form of graphs

Name: Kolmogorov complexity
Definition: The Kolmogorov complexity is a measure of the structure of a character string and is given by the length of the shortest computer program that generates this character string. This shortest computer program thus gives the best compression of the string without losing information. (Wikipedia)

Name: Listenprogrammgenerator
Definition: A generator for the automatic creation of programs with which reports can be created; in this sense a higher programming language (Witschaftsinformatik Lex.)

Name: Maschinencode
Definition: The representation of a compute program which is actually read and interpreted by the computer. A program in machine code consist of a sequenz of machine instructions (FOLFOD).

Name: Message transmission system
Definition: CCITT recommendation d. X-Series

Name: Mittlere Datentechnik
Definition: Term for the (outdated) data technology of the 60s and 70s. Therefore, do not use it for current documents.

Name: Rechenwerk
Definition: Functional unit of a processor that performs arithmetic operations

Name: Systemprogrammierung
Definition: Programming used to create system programs, operating systems and integrated application packages (Schulze: PC-Lex.)

Name: Virtual machine
Definition: 1. an abstract (imaginary) machine 2. a software emulation (simulated machine)

Name: Wissenstechnik
Definition: Knowledge modeling (knowledge engineering) is used to map knowledge in knowledge-based systems. It is a sub-area of knowledge management and artificial intelligence.

Name: Structural complexity
Definition: Complexity of algorithms

Name: Tischcomputer
Definition: outdated term

Name: Local high-speed network
Definition: Networks with transmission speed < 100 Mbit/s

Name: Realistic computer graphics
Definition: Realistic representation of 3D scenes (e.g. shading)

Name: Prototyping
Definition: A software development process in which prototypes (preliminary versions of application systems) are designed, constructed, evaluated and revised (computer science-HB)

Name: Ersetzungsregel
Definition: Formal language, grammar

Name: Computervision
Definition: Not to be confused with computer vision

Name: Programming on a large scale
Definition: Development of large software systems by several programmers

Name: Hilfebefehl
Definition: Help command for computers for further information

Name: Dokumentanalyse
Definition: Automatic analysis of documents, which can consist of images and text

Name: Non-monotonic closing
Definition: Conclusions that can be revised if a value changes in the course of a consultation (expert systems)

Name: Scientific database
Definition: Databases that include scientific data, most of which result from experiments and simulations (experimental data)

Name: Requirements engineering
Definition: Development, specification and formulation of the requirements for a (software) system.

Name: Register transfer level
Definition: Abstraction method for describing hardware

Name: Goppa code
Definition: a new class of linear block codes introduced by V. D. Goppa in 1970/1971

Name: Volumenmodell
Definition: A 3D model that uniquely represents volumetric objects.

Name: Internetworking
Definition: 1. the combination of several (local) networks to form a network over a geographically extended area (internetwork).  2. communication between physically separated networks (internetworking).  3. products, processes and technologies that interconnect networks (routers, gateways, bridges, hubs).

Name: Softfont
Definition: Softfont Fonts that are not permanently installed in the respective printer, but are loaded from the computer into the printer memory as required before the actual printing process begins

Name: Font
Definition: Complete character set of a font

Name: Default logic
Definition: Non-monotonic logic that works with default assumptions.

Name: Data Dictionary
Definition: A catalog of metadata that contains the definitions and display rules of data elements. It describes all application data of a company and the relationships between the various data objects with the aim of a redundancy-free and central definition of the data structures and thus corresponds to a representation of the application-specific data model (Wikipedia)

Name: Neural network
Definition: A network whose architecture of individual processors is modeled on the structure of a brain.

Name: Card-controlled payment system
Definition: Chip card is not pleonastic

Name: Datenaustausch
Definition: Forwarding of data from one user (company) to another - regardless of the transmission technology

Name: Electronic data exchange
Definition: The electronic (paperless) exchange of (business) documents

Name: Ordered logic
Definition: Term from the field of reduction systems (artificial intelligence)

Name: Approximate reasoning
Definition: Field of KI, which attempts to reproduce (model) the human ability to draw (logical) conclusions despite imperfect information

Name: Hilfsprogramm
Definition: Small, useful programs that only perform a very specific task.

Name: Spatial database system
Definition: Related to Spatial data management in Wirtschaftsinformatik-Lex.

Name: TSR Programming
Definition: Working with a resident program

Name: CD-I
Definition: Optical storage system for multimedia information (audio, video and text data)

Name: Multicastingverfahren
Definition: Def. in ABC d. Data communication

Name: Verteiltes System
Definition: Combination of autonomous processor-memory systems that execute programs independently of each other but cooperate by exchanging messages. Examples of v. S. are computer networks, multi-computer systems, mobile devices communicating via wireless networks or grid computing. (Computer Science Handbook)

Name: Bondgraph
Definition: A bond diagram is a graphical representation of a dynamic physical system, e.g. a spring-mass oscillator.

Name: Semantic network
Definition: Formal model of concepts and their relationships (relations). Used in computer science and artificial intelligence for the formal representation of knowledge. A semantic network is represented by graphs whose nodes represent the terms and whose edges represent the relationships between the terms.

Name: EDIFACT
Alternate Name: Electronic data interchange for administration, commerce and transport
Definition: International regulations for the electronic exchange of trade data

Name: Transaktionsverarbeitung
Definition: 1. operating mode of a computer in which operation takes place in dialog. 2. a processing method in which transactions are executed immediately after they are received by the system (Microsoft-Comp.-Lex.).

Name: RPC
Definition: Betriebssystemdienst

Name: Client-Server-Konzept
Definition: An important architectural principle of networks (and data processing systems) in which each computer takes on specific tasks. Contrast: Peer-to-peer concept (each computer has equal rights and can take on all tasks for the network).

Name: Update
Definition: Updating, modernization of a software or hardware product

Name: Geoinformationssystem
Definition: System for recording, storing and displaying geographical (=spatial) information

Name: Konnektionismus
Definition: Modeling of cognitive and biological processes on the basis of distributed representation and parallel processing, i.e. with neural networks. In KI an alternative approach to the classical paradigm of symbol processing (symbolic KI).

Name: Cyberspace
Definition: 1. the possibility of placing users in computer-generated three-dimensional environments and allowing them to interact with simulated objects. 2. the world of computer and telecommunications networks and the culture that prevails in this world. 3. largely synonymous with the Internet.

Name: MRP II
Definition: MRP II extends MRP I with a capacity planning module.

Name: Electronic signature
Definition: Link with jurist. USW

Name: Biocomputer
Definition: Biocomputers use systems of biologically derived molecules - such as DNA, RNA and proteins - to perform computations that store, retrieve and process data.

Name: Multikopienproblem
Definition: The problem created by data replication of keeping different copies consistent

Name: Computersicherheit
Definition: Def. in Wirtschaftsinformatiklex. under computer protection

Name: Industry-PC
Definition: an PC specially developed for industrial environments with, for example, an extra stable, dustproof or acid-proof housing.

Name: Integrated information system
Definition: Summary of a range of different applications

Name: Directory system
Definition: Distributed system that manages data for other distributed systems

Name: Connection machine
Definition: Mainframe for parallel processing

Name: Symbolverarbeitung
Definition: Information processing approach/paradigm of the classical (symbolic) KI

Name: Undocumented function
Definition: Function of a program that is not described in the official documentation

Name: Natural language system
Definition: Natural language according to DIN 1463 and DIN 51623

Name: Notepad computer
Definition: Designation for all small PCs that can be held in the hand during use.

Name: Graphikrechner
Definition: Special computers for graphical data processing

Name: Wortgleichung
Definition: SW from the section "Word problem for groups"

Name: Programmsynthese
Definition: Fully automatic derivation of programs from formal specifications

Name: Schleifentest
Definition: Test using a program loop in the EDV

Name: Transportschicht
Definition: Application analogous to application layer

Name: Computer science repository
Definition: Managed directory for the storage and description of digital objects (Wikipedia)

Name: Kommunikationsdesign
Definition: Used for the design of classic media, especially print media

Name: Self-organizing card
Definition: A special form of artificial neural network that has far-reaching significance in the analysis and presentation of high-dimensional data sets.

Name: Monitoring computer
Definition: Computer unit for troubleshooting

Name: Artificial life
Definition: New research (since ca. 1987). Subject d. KL are artificial creatures created by scientists in the computer

Name: VLIW architecture
Definition: Computer architecture with long command words (combining several commands into one super command). An approach to increase the performance of single processor systems with the help of parallel structures (other approaches: superscalar, superpipeline technology)

Name: Hash algorithm
Definition: A hash function is a mathematical function in which the input value is reduced to a smaller, more manageable value.

Name: Sequenzielle Logik
Definition: Switching functions whose functional value depends both on the input signals and on the internal (memory) states of the system. S.L. is realized by sequential circuits (Lex. Computertechn.).

Name: Disk array
Alternate Name: Redundant interconnection of independent hard disks
Definition: Disk arrays are tightly or loosely coupled collections of small, inexpensive magnetic disks or hard disks

Name: Teilauswertung
Definition: Specialization of a program for (partially) known input data (HB computer science)

Name: Blockchiffre
Definition: A block cipher encrypts a message block by block

Name: Functional-logical programming language
Definition: New class of declarative languages resulting from the integration of functional and logical programming languages

Name: Blochlinienspeicher
Definition: According to the template, stable substructures in the domain walls, so-called vertical Bloch line pairs (VBL), with dimensions in the sub-micrometer range, represent the logical states "O" and "1" in the Bloch line memory. It is a further development of the magnetic bubble memory.

Name: Radiosity
Definition: Lighting algorithm based on the physics of radiation

Name: Erfahrungsdatenbank
Definition: Database system for recording experience with projects of a certain category, e.g. software projects

Name: Peer-to-Peer-Netz
Definition: Network architecture in which every computer has equal rights and can perform all tasks for the network. Contrast: Client-server concept (each computer has specific tasks).

Name: Protocol data processing system
Definition: Ben. for the recording of processes that run on DV systems.

Name: Unicode
Definition: Standard for encoding any characters

Name: Testdiskette
Definition: Diskette with test data or programs

Name: Klauselgrammatik
Definition: Formalism for the representation of linguistic and extra-linguistic knowledge

Name: Logiksynthese
Definition: Automatic conversion of the behavioral description (circuit specification) into a derived structure description

Name: Nuprl
Definition: Version "Nu" of the "Proof Refinement Logic"

Name: Online-Dienst
Definition: electronic information and communication services that are offered on the Internet and are neither telecommunications services nor broadcasting (cf. § 1 sentence 1 TMG), e.g. online stores, online banking, electronic press, chat rooms and Internet search engines

Name: Web page
Definition: A hypertext document (multimedia document, HTML document) created according to the HTML standard in WWW. Corresponds to an HTML file on a web server that can be loaded and displayed by the display program (browser) via HTTP.

Name: Symmetrical multiprocessor system
Definition: Two or more similar processors connected via a high-bandwidth link and managed by one operating system, where each processor has equal access to I/O devices. (FOLDOC)

Name: Terminological logic
Definition: Methods for the representation and processing of conceptual descriptions in the area of knowledge representation

Name: XTP
Definition: End-to-end protocol on the network and transport layer of the OSI model for greater bandwidths and higher speeds

Name: PRAM Computer science
Definition: Machine model for parallel algorithms

Name: Recursive descent
Definition: Special syntax analysis method

Name: Entscheidungsgraph
Definition: A directed, acyclic graph (with additional properties), used as a standard data structure in computer-aided circuit design.

Name: Cache memory
Definition: Use in accordance with the B-1986-Def. i.e.

Name: Evolutionärer Algorithmus
Definition: Imitation of biological principles in mathematical optimization

Name: Evolutionary programming
Definition: Heuristic optimization method

Name: Differential cryptanalysis
Definition: Cryptanalytical method for decrypting the DES and related cipher systems

Name: ANSI Z39.50-1992
Definition: US-american. Standard for the definition of application services and the specification of protocols for information retrieval in open communication systems

Name: Visual database system
Definition: Expansion of database technology to include visual aspects such as indexing and query techniques for image information, data structures for image and multimedia information, etc.

Name: Einchip-Computer
Definition: Integration of a complete computer system on a single chip. The implementation of such a system on a chip (SOC) includes both the selection and design of hardware modules - e.g. suitable computing units and interface components - as well as the development of suitable software for this system.

Name: Densest pair of points problem
Definition: One of the fundamental distance problems in algorithmic (computational) geometry: finding a pair of points with the smallest possible distance in a set of points

Name: Hilfesystem
Definition: Program that offers explicit explanations when using an interactive application system

Name: Recursive neural network
Definition: Neural network in which the threshold functions are applied recursively to the output functions

Name: Aktionssemantik
Definition: Formal semantics, which is developed from functional semantics based on the simpler concept of action

Name: Spatial join
Definition: Processor for spatial connection Connection (e.g. between two maps) in the geodatabase system

Name: Reservierungssystem
Definition: Computerized Process for data exchange between airlines, theaters, etc. and their contractually affiliated (travel) agencies, etc.

Name: Bereichstheorie
Definition: Mathem. Theory of semantic domains

Name: Firewall
Definition: Areas on a computer that are protected against unauthorized access by web users.

Name: Ray casting
Definition: In contrast to ray tracing (light rays from the source to the eye), the rays that are "thrown" from the eye onto objects are calculated here.

Name: Mehragentensystem
Definition: A collection of several information processing units (agents) that interact in such a way that they fulfill a jointly processed task through distributed problem solving (term from the field of distributed KI).

Name: OBDD
Definition: Efficient graph-based data structures for the representation and manipulation of Boolean functions

Name: Datenbankverwaltung
Definition: Maintenance, backup and operation of a database system to be carried out by the database administrator or (automatically) by DBMS.

Name: Benutzerorientierung
Definition: Approach to the design of computer and information systems that meets the user's requirements for the system in a special way.

Name: Reverse engineering
Definition: 1. engineering analysis process that goes backwards through the synthesis or design process. (Du. Informatik) 2. dissection of the range of services offered by competitors in order to analyze their functional, design and manufacturing principles as well as their value creation structure (Gabler)

Name: Anwendungsprogramm
Definition: To be used in the broadest sense for all programs that make it possible to use a computer to perform certain tasks (= applications).

Name: Fuzzy control
Definition: Control engineering applications of fuzzy logic

Name: Serviceroboter
Definition: Service robots are robots that provide services for humans semi-autonomously or fully autonomously.

Name: OWL Computer science
Definition: Language for knowledge representation in the Semantic Web. Used to define ontologies. Based on XML and RDF.

Name: Embedded system
Definition: Computer embedded in another system, software, etc.

Name: SAGIS
Definition: System for recording, storing and displaying geographic information in Salzburg

Name: Virtuelle Realität
Definition: A synthetic three-dimensional world that can be interactively perceived and manipulated by the user in real time with the help of a graphics computer and special input and output devices. The effect of immersion gives the user the feeling of being immersed in the virtual environment and participating in it (Mr. Krapichler, 1999)

Name: Common sense reasoning
Definition: Reasoning with common sense when modeling everyday knowledge in artificial intelligence

Name: Kiosksystem
Definition: Information system at publicly accessible locations (a public computer, a public terminal), from which information can be called up or transactions initiated by frequently changing and usually unknown users within a short period of time via simple user interfaces (with multimedia display)

Name: EDIF
Definition: International set of rules for data exchange in IC design and production

Name: Temporal database system
Definition: Integration of temporal (time-based) information in conventional database systems

Name: Klammergrammatik
Definition: Natural extension of context-free grammars

Name: Switching communication technology
Definition: Process that enables communication between two network nodes in a large network (Voss 2001).

Name: Filterautomat
Definition: In contrast to cellular automata, the entry of a cell is dependent on the entries of a finite number of cells from the previous and current point in time

Name: Browsing
Definition: The quick search (browsing) for documents, files or data records for the purpose of a rough overview of stored information (Bertelsmann-Lex. Informatik).

Name: Middleware
Definition: Software layer between application programs and system software. Also: software that supports the developer in the integration of software systems.

Name: Hierarchical simulation
Definition: Decomposition of simulation models into components with a hierarchical model structure that correspond to current physical building blocks

Name: Geoinformation
Definition: Geoscientific (e.g. geographical or spatial) data that is recorded, stored and displayed using information technology

Name: Electronic voting
Definition: Elections with computer networks

Name: Model Checking
Definition: Model checking is a technique for the automatic verification of hardware and software systems. It is used industrially for the verification of components and protocols.

Name: Software component
Definition: Functionally and constructively related component of a system in programming technology. An executable software module with identity and well-defined interface.

Name: Mobile agent
Definition: Mobile agents are programs that execute jobs for a user. They are able to act autonomously and migrate from one computer to another or be transferred to a remote computer and executed there.

Name: POM processor
Definition: Processor with periodic operation model (POM), a programmable image processing processor model

Name: Soft Computing
Definition: The research field of soft computing or computational intelligence encompasses methods of sub-symbolic (numerical) knowledge processing. Today, this primarily includes the three sub-areas of fuzzy logic, neural networks and evolutionary algorithms, but also other interdisciplinary approaches to information processing that consciously tolerate and exploit vagueness and uncertainty.

Name: Information technology agent
Definition: Hardware or software-based systems (e.g. autonomous robots or software agents) that act as more or less independent units within larger systems (HB KI)

Name: Tamagotchi
Definition: "Virtual pet" developed by the Bandai company

Name: Tiefenbild
Definition: Image that contains a measure of the distance between the image plane and the object point in each pixel (image data processing)

Name: Plastikkarte
Definition: Data carrier in credit card format. Magnetic strips or chips are used as memory.

Name: Universal product code
Definition: US standard for product labeling, since approx. 1970

Name: OKFDD
Definition: Data structure for the representation and manipulation of Boolean functions

Name: Genetic programming
Definition: Branch of evolutionary algorithms with the goal of automatic program generation. In contrast to conv. gen. Algorith. computer programs are evolved in Gen. Progr. computer programs are evolved.

Name: DVD
Definition: Optical data carrier for video, audio and computer data with the dimensions of the compact disc (CD), but considerably larger storage capacity

Name: RFID
Definition: Identifikationssystem

Name: Animated cursor
Definition: Mouse pointer that can display a sequence of individual images.

Name: Hybrides System
Definition: Systems consisting of components with discrete and continuous behavior or of digital and analog components

Name: HyTime
Definition: An advanced ISO standard based on SGML, which enables the management of hypermedia documents.

Name: Nonlinear diffusion
Definition: Image processing method based on the mathem. It is based on the mathematical principles of physical diffusion.

Name: Electronic publication
Definition: As a keyword for existing thematically indexable electronic publications that do not fall under one of the permitted subheadings or a combination of at least two different data carriers. Also to be used as a subject keyword for electronic documents.

Name: Push technology
Definition: Automatic information delivery: predefined topics by the user, periodic delivery of updates

Name: Zeichensatz
Definition: The set (character set) of characters that can be displayed on keyboards, printers or screens at any writing position. (You. Computer science)

Name: Pulse processing neural network
Definition: Summarizing term for neural networks in which the pulse describes the unit of information used.

Name: Electronic forum
Definition: Public discussion areas in online networks, e.g. bulletin board (BBS), newsgroups, moderated conference, mailing list

Name: Punktwolke
Definition: Digitized surfaces can be available and processed in the form of point clouds

Name: 3COM brand
Definition: Marke

Name: Binäres Entscheidungsdiagramm
Definition: A data structure for the compact representation of Boolean functions. BDDs are mainly used in the field of hardware synthesis and verification.

Name: Superposition calculus
Definition: A spec. proof (proof calculus: def. in Görz: introduction to artificial intelligence)

Name: Digital data
Definition: Data from characters only

Name: Computer-aided communication
Definition: Communication that takes place through or is facilitated by computers (FOLDOC). Beispiele: asynchron (E-Mail, Mailinglisten, Usenet), synchron (Chat, MUD, Videokonferenzen)

Name: Online-Medien
Definition: Generic term for the subset of new media that are used digitally, interactively and online (e.g. Internet, online services, mailboxes, video on demand, etc.). Contrasting term to offline media (e.g. DCs, digital cassettes, etc.)

Name: Zoom
Definition: Neckline alteration

Name: Videobearbeitung
Definition: Editing video recordings on the computer

Name: Internationalization Programming
Definition: Techniques and standards for different operating systems to enable an application program to automatically adapt user interfaces to different languages, etc.

Name: Preprocessor
Definition: Programs or program components that process data, esp. subprograms of a compiler program (translates source code into intermediate code)

Name: Motion Capturing
Definition: Realistic real-time simulation and recording of motion sequences of real people and/or objects and transfer of the motion data obtained to animated figures/objects

Name: Wissensextraktion
Definition: Discovery of knowledge in large unstructured data sets (text mining in Word documents or web pages) and in structured data sets (data mining in databases)

Name: Cascade correlation network
Definition: Neural network based on gradient descent in weight space

Name: Steuerzeichen
Definition: Character that is not actually used for DV, but for controlling certain functions. functions

Name: Mixed Reality
Definition: Merging telepresence with VR systems

Name: Neuro-fuzzy system
Definition: used for the integration of neural networks in fuzzy systems

Name: Groupware
Definition: Software for group work

Name: Auszeichnungssprache
Definition: Special form of a description language that contains a set of commands that can be used for the logical structuring of a text file and thus for its formatting (visual display) by printer or screen. (B Computer)

Name: Constraint programming
Definition: Programming method for searching for solutions to problems (esp. optimization problems). To solve a problem, only conditions that describe the problem are formulated instead of an algorithm for the calculation.

Name: Passwort
Definition: Controls access to the computer or files

Name: Electronic watermark
Definition: Copyright signature

Name: RMI
Definition: RMI allows developers to write programs that address objects on remote computers in exactly the same way as objects on the same computer

Name: Track data technology
Definition: Area on a data carrier on which data is stored serially.

Name: Spurtheorie
Definition: Semantic theory for concurrent systems

Name: Supervised learning
Definition: Special learning methods of (artificial) neural networks

Name: Unsupervised learning
Definition: Special learning processes of (artificial) neural networks

Name: Linear cryptanalysis
Definition: Algebraic tool for cryptanalysis of block ciphers

Name: Multidatenbanksystem
Definition: Similar to federated database systems, a special form of a multi-computer database system with largely independent database management systems

Name: Possibility theory
Definition: The task and aim of Possibility Theory is to quantify such fuzzy statements whose possible values are subjectively assessed and not empirically determined or formally calculated.

Name: Multidimensional database system
Definition: Database system that stores the data multi-dimensionally

Name: Datenfusion
Definition: 1. process that deals with the automat. Detection, association, combination and estimation of data. 2. combination of data from different, possibly heterogeneous sources.

Name: Online algorithm
Definition: Algorithm that makes decisions based on previous information without having reliable information about the future input.

Name: DVD-Video
Definition: DVD application and standard for the distribution and playback of moving images

Name: DVD-Audio
Definition: DVD application and standard for distributing and playing audio data

Name: DVD-ROM
Definition: DVD application and standard for distributing and playing back data

Name: Multi-level chart
Definition: A directed, acyclic hypergraph with edge labels. Special data structure for incremental language processing.

Name: Wortgraph
Definition: A directed, acyclic graph with edge labels and edge weights. The edge labels denote words, the edge weights acoustic ratings.

Name: Fluid stochastic Petri net
Definition: Stochastic Petri net with fluid point

Name: Multimenge
Definition: Multisets or bags are unordered collections in which - in contrast to normal sets - the same elements may occur more than once.

Name: Rapid prototyping
Definition: The prototype is only used as a "disposable prototype" to gather experience.

Name: Thin client
Definition: In a client-server architecture, a client system that performs little or no data processing of its own. Processing takes place on the server instead.

Name: Website
Definition: Complete offer of a participant on the Internet. Entirety of related web documents and associated files, databases and scripts. A website generally has a starting point from which all areas of the offering can be accessed (RDA AH-007). Predominantly (and restrictively) used for the entirety of all web pages that relate to a specific topic or are used to present a company. The term is primarily (and restrictively) used for all web pages that relate to a specific topic or serve to represent a company, organization or individual. Web site is to be used when the presence on the Internet is the subject. Web page (or server, etc.) is primarily used for the technical or creative realization of such Internet presences.

Name: Softwarelokalisation
Definition: Adaptation of a software product to regional markets, i.e. to different language and cultural areas (involves much more than just translating the documentation texts!)

Name: Metacomputing
Definition: The coupling of several very powerful and distributed computers and instruments, which are linked via fast networks in such a way that they appear to the user as a single resource (Resch, University of Stuttgart).

Name: 3D graphics software
Definition: Special software for creating three-dimensional scenes or objects for computer animation and computer graphics

Name: ART network
Definition: Model class for self-organizing neural network structures with adaptive behavior

Name: Parallelisierung
Definition: Creation of a parallel program to solve a task on a parallel computer or computer network

Name: Unicode 3.0
Definition: Standard for character encoding

Name: Plot Graphical representation
Definition: The drawing produced by a plotter. Graphical representation of the relationship between two or more variables in a coordinate system.

Name: Streaming communication technology
Definition: Technology that allows films, voice or music to be played in real time directly from the internet or intranet

Name: Read/write head
Definition: Component for reading data from hard disks, floppy disks and tapes

Name: Büchi vending machine
Definition: A non-deterministic finite automaton that accepts infinite words (from: Glossary TPG, Uni-Hamburg)

Name: Semantic-preserving transformation
Definition: This method transforms the initial specification of a system into a refined specification that is still functionally correct (Do, Huu Trung).

Name: Resource-limited reducibility
Definition: Concept of complexity theory

Name: Circumscription Logic
Definition: A non-monotonic method for modeling everyday reasoning (in artificial intelligence).

Name: Extreme programming
Definition: Agile software development process. Here, a strict catalog of customer requirements is dispensed with, but customer wishes that arise during software development are also taken into account. Instead of the classic waterfall model, the development process repeatedly runs through all the disciplines of classic software development (requirements analysis, design, implementation, testing) in short cycles (typically one week). Only the features required in the current iteration step are implemented (Wikipedia).

Name: Texture mapping
Definition: In computer graphics, a process in which a surface is overlaid with a pattern, including perspective correction.

Name: Connectionless server
Definition: System unit within ATM networks for the operation of connectionless services

Name: Connectionless data transmission
Definition: Data transmission method in which there is no explicit (neither physical nor logical) connection between sender and receiver. Communication without prior connection establishment

Name: Connectionless service
Definition: Term for services over networks based on connectionless data transmission (Lex. Comm. Infotechn.)

Name: Heterogeneous network
Definition: Connection of dissimilar systems (computers, end devices, etc.). Network that has different elements

Name: Iterative array
Definition: Model for massively parallel computers with sequential input

Name: Abrechnungsmanagement
Definition: Functional area of network management for recording and allocating costs arising from the use of network resources (Rosenbaum : ISDN-Fachlex.)

Name: Memetic algorithm
Definition: Combination of the methods "Evolutionary Algorithms" and "Local Search" in order to use their advantages with regard to optimization.

Name: Semi-structured data
Definition: Data with implicit and irregular structure

Name: Message sequence chart
Definition: Description language or standard for the graphical representation of signal sequences

Name: Resource-limited genericity
Definition: Concept of resource-constrained complexity theory

Name: Reactive system
Definition: A reactive system communicates continuously with its environment during its execution, so that a permanent exchange of data takes place. The system reacts to events from its environment, the system environment determines the speed.

Name: Abstract state machine
Definition: Specification language for describing software and hardware systems

Name: Dynamic logic
Definition: An extension of predicate logic to include program formulas

Name: Convex decomposition
Definition: Method for stability and robustness analysis

Name: SICOMP
Definition: Industrial computer

Name: Social Media
Definition: Social media refers to Internet applications that are used collectively, are designed for the exchange of content provided by users and are largely characterized by group formation and reputation in the form of recommendations or ratings by other users (see Hohlfeld, in: Rechtshandbuch Social Media, p. 13)

Name: Time-delay network
Definition: TD networks are a special type of feedforward network. Neural network with delayed siganl transmission

Name: Coocurrence matrix
Definition: Texture analysis tool. Describes the gray value ratios in the immediate vicinity of the current pixel.

Name: Subsymbolische Verarbeitung
Definition: Information processing approach/paradigm of the "new" KI (in contrast to the classical, symbol-processing KI). Subsymb. Systems work on num. Values to which meaning cannot be readily ascribed.

Name: Neuronal field
Definition: Continuum model of neural networks or nerve networks

Name: Interactive media
Definition: Used for documents on (new) media in which the form of access to information is emphasized in which the user determines the scope, selection and sequence of the information presented in the context of a two-way communication with the medium at any time (Brauner, Multimedia-Lex.).

Name: Portable object adapter
Definition: A CORBA standard for building server-side applications that are portable across heterogeneous ORBs (Object Request Broker). A powerful object adapter introduced in CORBA 2.2

Name: Objektadapter
Definition: An object that adapts the interface of another object to the interface expected by the caller. In CORBA, it adapts the programming language concept of servants to that of CORBA objects. It can be found in the architecture between the ORB core and the skeletons.

Name: MUD
Definition: Game and communication spaces on the Internet originally based on fantasy role-playing games, characterized by snychronous communication modalities (G. Götzenbrucker).

Name: Neuronal gas
Definition: A self-organizing neural network. It is trained using supervised learning methods. In contrast to the coherence maps, the neighborhood connections between the individual neurons are only formed during the learning phase

Name: Patch Software
Definition: Patching or adapting a machine program by replacing individual bits in the machine code. Software change that is introduced during operation.

Name: Gruppenbewusstsein
Definition: Knowing what is currently going on in the group or what has been done in the past. In computer-supported collaboration (CSCW), group awareness is of particular importance, as this must be "artificially generated" in order to enable an obstacle-free workflow.

Name: Deforestation Informatics
Definition: Class of optimizing program transformations that convert a program into an equivalent program

Name: Kerberos cryptology
Definition: Authentication mechanism and security system based on symmetric, cryptographic encryption methods

Name: Benutzerprofil
Definition: The entirety of a user's requirements for computers and programs or a compilation of the individually selected settings. On the Internet, all information that the user provides voluntarily and that can be deduced from his behavior on the Internet

Name: Receptive grouping
Definition: Model of visual information processing / shape perception

Name: Neuroinformatik
Definition: Research into biological information processing using the methods of computer science and information technology

Name: Fitnessfunktion
Definition: Term from the field of "evolutionary methods for optimization"

Name: Ubiquitous computing
Definition: Ubiquity of information processing and the associated access to data from any location at any time (anytime, anywhere - information available at any time, any place, in any form). Disappearance or embedding of IT components in everyday objects.

Name: Datentransformation
Definition: Convert the appearance or format of data without changing the content.

Name: Speicherbereichsnetzwerk
Definition: Network in which only data storage devices are networked

Name: Fuzzy-logisches Schließen
Definition: Fuzzy-logical reasoning is used when knowledge is uncertain or vague.

Name: Secret sharing
Definition: Procedure for dividing secret information among several people so that only certain subgroups can reconstruct this information.

Name: n-tuple
Definition: Entity or data set with n attributes

Name: Separation of Concerns
Definition: Principle of software engineering with skills of labeling, encapsulating and manipulating interest/aspect relevant software parts

Name: Wavetable
Definition: Method of sound synthesis using stored waveforms

Name: Diagrammatic closing
Definition: Subfield of knowledge representation. It deals with inferences based on information represented in diagrams (symbolic descriptions that can be interpreted pictorially)

Name: Evolutionary system development
Definition: Strategy of (software) development for coping with rapidly changing requirements. The guiding principle of initially having complete requirements is abandoned. Instead, the entire development process is seen as a sequence of design/implementation/evaluation cycles (Internet: HERMES).

Name: Content Management
Definition: Software system with which content (e.g. text, graphics, audio data) is managed and made available for a presentation. The principle of separation of content and form applies here.

Name: Test-first approach
Definition: Agile method for developing a computer program in which the programmers develop software tests before the components to be tested.

Name: Komponententest
Definition: Test of subroutines, procedures (general manageable units)

Name: Remote Access
Definition: Use of a remote computer

Name: Cracker Computer crime
Definition: Targeted and professional hacking with criminal energy

Name: Content Internet
Definition: 1. the interactive content of a website that is independent of structure and technology. 2. media content of all formats (text, image, sound, moving image), especially on the Internet. (Wikipedia)

Name: Content Syndication
Definition: Exchange and trade (in the sense of multiple use) of digital content for use in various areas of the media industry (e.g. print; TV, cinema; web)

Name: Content provider
Definition: Service provider who provides content for a website. In contrast to a service provider, who takes care of the technical infrastructure of a website.

Name: Weblog
Definition: A diary kept on the Internet in which individual users, interest groups, organizations or companies list information chronologically and update it regularly with the aim of sharing it with other Internet users (RDA AH-007).

Name: HMS Manufacturing
Definition: Production taking into account complex information through IT, cooperation and self-organization of individual autonomous production units (holons)

Name: Cooperative information system
Definition: Several independent systems that together provide the desired performance

Name: Lindström-Quantor
Definition: Generalized logical quantifiers

Name: Jukebox data technology
Definition: Mass storage system that manages several data carriers (e.g. CD-ROMs)

Name: Tertiärspeicher
Definition: External storage, preferably for backup copies.

Name: Fachportal
Definition: Structured database or comprehensive collection of links to search for specialist resources on the Internet

Name: Semantic Web
Definition: 1. the Semantic Web is a W3C activity for the computer-readable representation of information on the World Wide Web in such a way that it can be used by machines not only for presentation purposes, but also for automation, integration and reuse across applications. Technologies relevant to the Semantic Web include description logics, ontologies, metadata, rule systems and information extraction. 2. an extension of today's web to include metadata for meaning enrichment. 3. a concrete implementation of a distributed semantic network that is currently under development.

Name: Mutual information
Definition: Similarity measure, information measure, measure of the interdependence of two variables, correlation measure mainly used in information theory, image processing, etc.

Name: Assistenzsystem
Definition: Components of technical systems that support people in interacting with these systems by offering suggestions for action and/or performing subtasks largely independently. Assistance systems stand between help systems (product-related application aids) and expert systems (knowledge-based systems that carry out problem-solving or decision-making processes). systems that solve problems or carry out decision-making processes).

Name: Domaingrabbing
Definition: The unlawful registration/blocking of a domain solely for the purpose of selling it

Name: Type-safe language
Definition: Language property that is essential at source or bytecode level. It states that no runtime errors can occur in well-typed programs such that operations receive arguments of an incorrect type. Sufficient condition: Correctness (soundness) of the type system.

Name: Web Services
Definition: 1. web services are software modules that link programs running on different network computers via the Internet to form an application. (FAZ, October 14, 2003) 2. web services are not intended for human users, but for software systems that automatically exchange data and/or call up functions on remote computers.

Name: Bilddatenbank
Definition: Database that mainly comprises image data

Name: Electronic program guide
Definition: Interactive tool that guides the viewer through the digital television offering, combining the function of a user interface (of the digital receiver) and a ("built-in") TV guide

Name: Mobile Computing
Definition: Data communication of a mobile computer with other mobile or stationary computers using wireless network technologies. Also in the sense of: Access to the Internet with cell phones/handheld computers or: Working on the move using small (laptops) or very small (handheld) computers.

Name: Mobile program
Definition: Model for distributed processing. In this model, instead of or in addition to data, program code is exchanged between computer nodes and executed remotely (another model is mobile agents)

Name: BMEcat
Definition: Standard based on the XML markup language for the exchange of multimedia product catalog data

Name: Belief function
Definition: Term from Dempster-Shafer theory. Used instead of the probability function to numerically represent the uncertainty of the truth of various statements

Name: Hoax
Definition: Warnings distributed by e-mail about (alleged) viruses in e-mails.

Name: Join operation
Definition: Operation that combines data from one or more tables into a single result table.

Name: Tetraedergitter
Definition: Unstructured volume grids of tetrahedral cells

Name: Traffic Engineering
Definition: 1. design, planning and operation of communication networks under quality and performance aspects (TB Telekom.). 2. influencing the (data) traffic of a network through targeted traffic control (Detken, K.-O.)

Name: Algorithmic learning theory
Definition: Research area between KI and theoretical computer science in which the learning behavior of algorithms is defined and theoretically investigated (in contrast to empirically oriented machine learning). The most important models are PAC learning, online learning, learning from questions.

Name: Volume rendering
Definition: 1. special method for volume visualization, whereby 2-D images are generated directly without any intermediate geometric representation (e.g. triangle lists). 2. a direct technique for visualizing volume primitives without any intermediate conversion of the volumetric dataset to surface representation.

Name: Abstract syntax tree
Definition: A tree-like representation of programs

Name: Byte code
Definition: A coding of a computer program generated by the compiler during the processing of the source code.

Name: Softwareplattform
Definition: Software layer that provides the applications with the functionality required for the specific application

Name: Culling computer graphics
Definition: Term from computer graphics/virtual reality: Currently invisible areas of the 3D model are excluded from the visualization process (Lex. Geoinformatics)

Name: Verdeckungsrechnung
Definition: Suppression of those parts of a computer graphic that are obscured (= invisible) at a given viewer location

Name: Sichtbarkeitsverfahren
Definition: In computer graphics, procedures that decide/calculate whether a graphic element is displayed or not

Name: Ameisenalgorithmus
Definition: Nature-analogous optimization methods that make use of solution strategies that ants use, for example, when searching for food

Name: ACID-Properties
Definition: The ACID-E. describe the conditions that parallel transactions must fulfill.

Name: Computer science isolation
Definition: Concurrently executed transactions must not influence each other

Name: Atomicity computer science
Definition: A transaction is executed in full or not at all

Name: Serialisierbarkeit
Definition: Property of parallel transactions

Name: Network Graphical representation
Definition: A diagram for the clear representation of complex structures, e.g. network diagram, Petri net, etc.

Name: Nebenläufigkeitskontrolle
Definition: The aim of N. is to keep shared databases consistent. To this end, write access by several users to one and the same data object is coordinated.

Name: Algorithmic group theory
Definition: The problem of A.G. is to solve fundamental problems of group theory using algorithms. (The implementation in software falls into the field of computer algebra)

Name: Relevance feedback
Definition: Method for improving retrieval results based on the user's relevance judgment

Name: Quanteninformatik
Definition: Field of information processing and data transmission based on quantum theory

Name: Front-end software
Definition: Software that provides an interface to another program "behind" it, which may not be as user-friendly (FOLDOC).

Name: Graphenzeichnen
Definition: Area of computer science (computer graphics) that deals with the visualization of graphs, which frequently occur in circuit diagrams or diagrams, for example. The aim is to arrange nodes, edges and subgraphs as clearly as possible.

Name: Eindringerkennung
Definition: Sub-area from the IT security field. Methods and (software) systems that can be used to detect attacks on computer systems.

Name: Suffix array
Definition: A full-text index data structure for text searches

Name: Collage grammar
Definition: Method for rule-based image generation (computer graphics). A set of hyperedge substitution rules, an alphabet and an output collage form a system called collage grammar.

Name: Unified Software Development Process
Definition: Procedure concept for system development

Name: Object-Process-Model
Definition: object-oriented data model, object-oriented modeling

Name: Custom Computing Machine
Definition: A computer, where the hardware is optimized to speed up specific applications

Name: Model generation Artificial intelligence
Definition: Methods of automatic proof, with which the satisfiability of a logical specification is shown by calculating models of the specification (Karsten Konrad).

Name: CMMI
Definition: Procedure model for the development of software, systems and the integrated development of processes and products. Successor to the CMM model

Name: Star-free language
Definition: Subclass of regular languages defined by formulas of 1st level logic

Name: Avatar Computer Science
Definition: Animated representation in virtual worlds

Name: RTP
Definition: Internet protocol for the real-time transmission of audio and video data, which works with unicasting and multicasting services

Name: Mail server
Definition: A server (program and computer) that stores, manages and distributes e-mails.

Name: Timed vending machine
Definition: A finite automaton with clock variables and time restrictions

Name: RTSP
Definition: Efficient protocol for real-time transmission of multimedia data streams via IP networks

Name: Augmented reality computer science
Definition: Overlaying virtual objects over a real scene

Name: SPQR-tree
Definition: SPQR-trees represent the decomposition of a two-connected graph into three-connected components. They are used to enumerate all embeddings of a graph (author)

Name: Fail-safe system
Definition: A safety-critical system is "fail-safe" if it remains in a safe state or transitions to a safe state ("safe") when certain damage occurs ("fail").

Name: Login
Definition: The process of a user logging into a computer system. The process of entering a user name and password. Also the term for the user ID itself.

Name: Single Sign-On
Definition: SSO gives the user of a (computer) system the option of accessing all the systems, applications and resources authorized for him with just a single login, e.g. by entering a user name and password once.

Name: Mensch-Maschine-Schnittstelle
Definition: The means of communication between a human user and a computer.

Name: Image-based rendering
Definition: In contrast to geometry-based computer graphics, IBR uses 2D image data as the source material for generating new views of a scene.

Name: Plenoptic function
Definition: The pl. function describes the information that can be visually perceived by a (human) observer at any place and at any time.

Name: Partikelsystem
Definition: Physical model for modeling, simulating or animating natural phenomena such as grass, fire, plants or forests.

Name: Text Mining
Definition: The field of T.M. encompasses a wide range of methods for extracting information from natural language texts. The methods originate from the research areas of knowledge representation, machine learning, computational linguistics, information extraction, information retrieval and pattern recognition. Learning, Computational Linguistics, Information Extraction, Information Retrieval, Pattern Recognition.
