Name: Fuzzy control system
Definition: A set of fuzzy rules that are evaluated by a reasoning mechanism.

Name: Socket
Definition: Endpoints for communication connections

Name: Multi-tier architecture
Definition: Client/server. Architectures are based on a division into individual software layers (tier). The software components are distributed across several computers.

Name: Inverted list
Definition: List index by inverting texts / documents for text searches in document collections for specific terms etc.

Name: Non-volatile memory
Definition: Storage system that does not lose data even when the power supply is switched off.

Name: Proxy server
Definition: Substitute server on the Internet

Name: DiffServ
Definition: Quality of service mechanism for handling traffic flows in one or more networks

Name: MDA Procedure model
Definition: MDA describes an approach to the development of IT solutions that is based on a clear separation of functionality and technology.

Name: Programmcode
Definition: The computer program formulated in a programming language

Name: UB-tree
Definition: The UB tree is an index structure specially developed for multidimensional range queries.

Name: Location-based service
Definition: Value-added service for cell phone subscribers that provides information tailored to the user's location (local weather forecasts, location-adapted city maps, location information for emergency calls).

Name: Pre-transmission communication technology
Definition: Transfer of information to mobile end devices as long as a good network connection is available, so that it is already available on the end device when it is needed later in a weakly coupled or decoupled operation.

Name: Deadline Scheduling
Definition: Special strategy for (processor) scheduling

Name: Assoziationsanalyse
Definition: The term association analysis refers to the identification and description of regions or data areas in a database in which several values are highly likely to occur simultaneously. Association analysis involves searching for association rules that can be used to display the results. As the association rules in the database are identified using algorithms, association analysis is located in the border area between statistics and computer science. In computer science, this method belongs to the field of data mining and KDD (Knowledge Discovery in Databases)

Name: Digital divide
Definition: The division of society into those who know how to use computers and speak their language (computer literacy) and those who do not. Digital divide refers to the resulting growing gap between different educational levels, income brackets and population groups. (Duden - Dictionary of the New Economy)

Name: Volltext
Definition: An electronic resource that provides the entire text of a single work or a bibliographic database that provides the entire text of a significant proportion of the works indexed in it, in addition to the citation and (in most cases) an abstract of each work (ODLIS)

Name: Active document
Definition: Active documents consist not only of passive data containers, but also contain active components. (Schimkat, R.-D.)

Name: Koordinationssprache
Definition: A coordination language is to be understood as a class in which the primitives of the language are defined as methods

Name: Datenreplikation
Definition: In the database context, copying a dataset

Name: Grid computing
Definition: Networking of processor resources via the Internet for parallel data processing

Name: NL-complete problem
Definition: Problem that is complete for non-deterministic logarithmic space

Name: Freeware
Definition: Software that can be used free of charge. These are usually small tools or light versions of shareware programs with a limited range of functions that are intended to advertise the paid version. With freeware, the programmer usually retains the copyright and the source code for himself.

Name: Buffer overflow
Definition: A buffer overflow occurs when a program attempts to store more data in a memory buffer than it has space for.

Name: Format string vulnerability
Definition: A format string vulnerability allows a server or attacker to send arbitrary character strings to clients and cause them to crash. An attacker can also potentially inject and execute arbitrary code via the vulnerability.

Name: Softwareschwachstelle
Definition: Security gap in a program. Such gaps allow hackers or crackers to access other people's computers. Programs or instructions that exploit such a gap are called exploits.

Name: Exploit
Definition: 1. a routine, script, program or tool that can fully or semi-automatically exploit an existing vulnerability. 2. the demonstration of a vulnerability using a sample program. 3. the active "exploration" of a vulnerability.

Name: URL
Definition: Address for a document (a file) on the Internet. Structure: Protocol type://Net address (of the computer to be addressed)/Storage location

Name: ANSI Z39.50-1995
Definition: US-american. Standard for the definition of application services and the specification of protocols for information retrieval in open communication systems, update of ANSI Z39.50-1992

Name: Large database system
Definition: Large database systems hold large amounts of data (terabyte range), process them very quickly, have fast response times, are transaction-proof in critical areas (Internet)

Name: Legacy system
Definition: Legacy systems. IT- Jargon for hardware or software systems or components that comply with obsolete standards but are still used for reasons of compatibility or cost.

Name: Metasuchmaschine
Definition: A meta search engine is a search engine whose main feature is that it forwards a search query to several other search engines, collects the results and processes them. This is done by eliminating duplicates, the results are then displayed as in a search engine. (Wikipedia)

Name: Deformable object
Definition: Computer graphics/virtual reality/visualization/animation: Objects in virtual environments that can be changed by the influence of other objects (e.g. collision) or by users. Applications: Clothing design, cartoons, facial expressions, human tissue, surgical simulation and training systems

Name: Active object
Definition: Object in a parallel object-oriented program that has its own control process (thread) and thus not only reacts to messages, but can also execute actions and send messages independently. (University of Oldenburg FB Computer Science)

Name: Wearable computer
Definition: PC, which is worn on the body (also integrated into clothing or as glasses or a watch) and is currently primarily intended for mobile use in the maintenance and service sector

Name: OISC
Definition: Computer with command set reduced to one command

Name: Datenhandschuh
Definition: Interaction medium with sensor-controlled movement transaction in virtual space and tactile feedback via programmable stimulators

Name: Shear warp method
Definition: Method of volume visualization. A hybrid method for perspective projection, which is comparably fast to parallel projection.

Name: Spurmonoid
Definition: Generalization of the free monoid. Set of all traces with a concatenation operation (sequential composition of process sequences). Common term in computer science for free partial commutative monoid.

Name: Spurersetzungssystem
Definition: Replacement systems via track monoids (in short: track replacement systems) generalize both semi-thue systems and vector replacement systems.

Name: IT track
Definition: A term introduced into theoretical computer science by Mazurkiewicz in 1977 to describe concurrent processes that are made up of atomic actions. Traces can be understood as a generalization of words, but can also be described in terms of graph theory or understood as a semi-order. Traces are the elements of a trace monoid.

Name: Ablaufverfolgung
Definition: The step-by-step observation of a program sequence

Name: Sicherheitskritisches System
Definition: System/installation whose faulty behavior can lead to the following consequences: Loss of life or health, serious damage to the environment, significant loss of system characteristics or system destruction, failure to perform important tasks or major economic loss.

Name: Mietserver
Definition: A web server rented by the customer from a provider, which is exclusively and solely available to this individual customer. The customer has administrator rights (under Unix/Linux: root rights) and can configure the system according to their own requirements.

Name: Instant messaging
Definition: Service that allows you to chat in real time or send short messages to other participants. Known IM services: AIM, ICQ, Microsoft MSN Messenger, Yahoo! Messenger, Jabber. IM software: Trillian, Miranda. (Wikipedia)

Name: Bounded Model Checking
Definition: Verification technology for circuits, configuration problems or planning problems.

Name: Turing test
Definition: Test for machine intelligence designed by the English mathematician Alan Mathison Turing

Name: COTS
Definition: Commercially available, inexpensive, non-specialized standard components (parts, products) from the mass market

Name: Oktalbaum
Definition: Extension of Quadtrees to three dimensions

Name: Digital Rights Management
Definition: 1. a process by which the copyrights to films, sound recordings or software on electronic data processing systems are protected and pirated copies are prevented (Wikipedia). 2. electronic distribution systems for digital content. These enable the secure distribution and exploitation of digital content online and offline (via the Internet, CDs, DVDs, mobile players or mobile phones). They also enable efficient rights management and thus open up new business models for digital content (e.g. paid downloads, content subscriptions, pay-per-view). To this end, DRMS make use of various protection mechanisms such as encryption, copy protection procedures or digital watermarks (Inst.f. Wirtschaftsinformatik, Uni. Bern)

Name: Konnektor
Definition: Connectors encapsulate the technological breaks between systems. They offer the calling system the functionalities of the called system via an interface. Other tasks include communication, data transformation and error handling (Internet).

Name: Burning Data processing
Definition: 1. writing data to an optical storage medium (CD, DVD) with the aid of a laser. 2. writing programs to an PROM or EPROM

Name: Registration Image processing
Definition: 1. the process of geometrically aligning images or maps so that objects or cells that are related to each other match. (Lex. Geoinformatics) 2. the calculation of a transformation that maps two corresponding image contents in two different coordinate systems onto each other.

Name: Transinformation
Definition: Correlation measure of information theory. Mean information content of the transmitted information. Statistical mean value of the information measure

Name: Textursynthese
Definition: Creation of synthetic digital images of textures that come as close as possible to natural textures

Name: Message passing
Definition: A method with which processes running in parallel can communicate with each other (www.netconcept24.de)

Name: Division operation
Definition: Operation of relational algebra, corresponds to the allquantor in relational calculus. Operations for finding data.

Name: Refactoring
Definition: Refactoring improves the readability and structure (architecture) of a computer program while retaining its functionality (Wikipedia). Refactoring is used intensively in extreme programming.

Name: Konkatenationscode
Definition: A concatenation code is a finite sequence or linking of known codes or character sequences to construct new codes

Name: Translation memory
Definition: Database in which a source text is stored in the form of translation units with the corresponding target text (aligned bilingual text collection). As the basis of translation support software, this memory offers the translator existing ("human") translations for reuse. Not only can identical sentences be recognized, but similar sentences can also be found. (translation recycling). Translation memory programs include Trados, Transit, XSDL and Déjà Vu

Name: Mobile database system
Definition: Database system that can manage databases on stationary and mobile computers

Name: IntServ
Definition: Quality of service model (sends data with regard to bandwidth and delay), see also SW DiffServ

Name: Information quality
Definition: 1. totality of the requirements for information (information product), which refer to its suitability for the fulfillment of given information needs (H.Nohr) 2. content, meaning and sense of information (largely determined by the environment) (Wikipedia) 3. information quality is determined by: Problem relevance, validity, topicality, conciseness, consistency, verifiability, etc.(F.Riedel)

Name: Virtual Home Environment
Definition: Sub-concept of the UMTS standard, which provides users with their individually configured working environment on different end devices and in different (mobile) networks

Name: Systembereichsnetz
Definition: Network with high bandwidth and low latency that connects computers within a cluster.

Name: Qualified electronic signature
Definition: The Digital Signature Act distinguishes between simple, advanced and qualified electronic signatures (SigG, §2). The qualified signature enables electronic communication and transactions with full legal force and maximum security and therefore has the same effect in legal transactions as a handwritten signature following the adaptation of private law legislation (e.g. § 126a BGB).

Name: Business Object
Definition: Representation of an object from real business life. In addition to the type name and description, the representation includes information on attributes, behavior, relationships and rules. In terms of content, these are business objects; typical examples of objects represented by business objects are products, invoices, employees, etc.

Name: LOWER AUSTRIA GIS
Definition: System for recording, storing and displaying Lower Austrian geographic information

Name: Progressive coding
Definition: Image coding in several passes. This allows an image to be continuously built up from coarse to fine, especially when used on the web, as the image is already visible during the loading process.

Name: Program Slicing
Definition: Method for extracting properties of a program

Name: Integrity IT
Definition: State of a system that does not allow unauthorized modification of its components.

Name: Common source and channel coding
Definition: Common source and channel coding allows more data or the same amount of data to be transmitted with a lower error rate under the same channel conditions.

Name: Agile Softwareentwicklung
Definition: Generic term for various software development methods that aim to make the development process more effective and advantageous with lean and flexible "low-tech" approaches and by taking greater account of human aspects. These approaches are based on the fact that they attempt to reduce the pure design phase to a minimum and to achieve executable software as early as possible in the development process, which can then be presented to the customer at regular short intervals for joint coordination. In this way, it should be possible to respond flexibly to customer requests at any time in order to increase overall customer satisfaction. There are now a large number of agile methods. Among the best known are Extreme Programming (XP)

Name: Wiki
Definition: Collectively created and maintained Internet offering in which every user can contribute (e.g. for online encyclopedias)

Name: Check digit
Definition: 1. a digit that is appended to a number during encoding to confirm error-free encoding. 2. a digit that is added to an account number or other identification key and recalculated when the number is used. This can be used to detect errors that may have occurred when the number was entered. (Microsoft-Comp.-Lex.) 3. a one-digit checksum (FOLDOC)

Name: Corner Cutting
Definition: Corner-cutting algorithms make it possible to refine and smooth curves and surfaces by successively cutting off corners of a given polygon.

Name: Adaptive programming
Definition: Extension of object-oriented programming through class hierarchy encapsulation

Name: Inductive logic programming
Definition: 1. ILP combines logical programming with machine learning. 2. ILP is an approach that combines inductive learning with first-level predicate logic.

Name: Snake image processing
Definition: The snake concept is based on the description of the object contour by a parametric curve

Name: Rich media content
Definition: Term for "living content" such as video, audio, Flash animations, i.e. everything that goes beyond static text and images

Name: Speicherschutz
Definition: The ability of operating systems to divide the available working memory and separate running programs from each other in such a way that a programming error/crash of a single program does not affect the stability of other programs or the overall system. (Wikipedia)

Name: Keller Information Technology
Definition: A cellar is a special data structure (linear list) in which the insertion and removal of elements only ever takes place at one end.

Name: Overhead communication technology
Definition: Additional data attached to the actual information to ensure the reliability of the information

Name: Displacement mapping
Definition: 1. technique in computer graphics that is used to give a surface of a three-dimensional object a higher level of detail and thus achieve a more realistic representation. 2. the generation of geometric data from textures.  3. method of creating surface irregularities without having to model them explicitly.

Name: Mapping computer graphics
Definition: 1. the application of a texture to an object.(Computer Science-HB) 2. in general, the projection of a bitmap graphic onto a geometric object. (Computer Graphics Glossary (Internet))

Name: Tesselation
Definition: 1. first step in the calculation of a 3D image. All objects are divided into polygons (B Computer). 2. subdivision of a 2-D plane or a 3-D volume into discrete, contiguous spatial elements that completely cover the plane or volume (GI-Lex.). 3. discretization of surfaces (Lex.Geography).

Name: PCI-Express
Definition: Further development of the PCI bus for higher data transfer rates, also as a successor to the AGP standard for graphics cards; standardization by the PCI Special Interest Group

Name: WebDAV
Definition: Extension of the HTTP communication protocol; enables users to jointly edit and manage files on remote web servers; standardization through IETF

Name: iSCSI
Alternate Name: Internet Small Computer Systems Interface over IP
Internet Small Computer System Interface over IP
Definition: Communication protocol for storage area networks; iSCSI, adopted as a standard by IETF in 2003, combines the SCSI protocol with TCP/IP and thus enables the cost-effective construction of storage networks based on common Ethernet network components.

Name: Graphiktablett
Definition: A rectangular, sensor-equipped, plastic-coated drawing board (graphic input device) that uses a special pen or a puck (magnifying glass with integrated crosshairs) to determine and register the exact position of a point or series of points (lines).

Name: Digitalisierer
Definition: 1. device that converts analog signals into digital signals. 2. graphic input device

Name: Digital certificate
Definition: A digital certificate is a digitally signed authentication of security-critical information by a trustworthy authority (Z. Nochta).

Name: Pop-up window
Definition: Browser windows that open in addition to the current main window and overlay the main window. Additional information, e.g. product descriptions or advertising, is displayed in a pop-up.

Name: Live wire process
Definition: An interactive, semi-automatic, edge-oriented method for image segmentation. To segment objects in the image, a characteristic object on the image is roughly outlined by specifying a few points with the mouse, LiveWire then searches for characteristic edges between these points. The problem of edge detection is reduced to the search for an optimal path within a weighted graph.

Name: Warping
Definition: A technique related to morphing in which images are changed step by step, working only with a source image but not with a target image.

Name: Tone mapping
Definition: The final step of a photorealistic image generation process (color transformation, tone mapping). Visualization of the lighting solution on output devices.

Name: Just-in-time compiler
Definition: Compiler that translates the byte code of a Java program into machine code during runtime.

Name: Disassembler
Definition: Program that can be used to generate code in assembly language from machine code (counterpart of an assembler)

Name: Parameterized complexity
Definition: The essential idea of parameterized complexity is to find a clever way of splitting the input into a main part x and a parameter y, so that the runtime is polynomial in x and exponential in y. This limits the combinatorial explosion to the parameter y. This limits the combinatorial explosion to the parameter y. As a result, parameterized algorithms have a polynomial runtime for inputs with fixed parameters (University of Würzburg).

Name: ANSI Z39.50-2003
Definition: US-american. Standard for the definition of application services and the specification of protocols for information retrieval in open communication systems, revision of ANSI Z39.50-1995

Name: Autonomic Computing
Definition: Autonomic computing is an approach to achieving self-managed computer systems that require a minimum of human intervention. (IBM)

Name: Semantic caching
Definition: In addition to the data, a description of the data is stored in the cache: Simplification of the interpretation of information, more efficient processing of queries, etc. (D.v.Verschuer)

Name: Ambient Intelligence
Definition: Massive networking of sensors, wireless modules and computer processors to improve everyday life

Name: EPIC architecture
Definition: 1. further development of VLIW technology, combining it with the advantages of dynamic scheduling.  2. a modern, modified implementation of the VLIW architecture is Intel's Itanium CPU, which in this case is called EPIC. (Wikipedia)

Name: Unicode 4.0
Definition: Standard zur Schriftzeichencodierung

Name: Representational user interface
Definition: Direct interaction between humans and computers with the help of physical objects. These are everyday objects equipped with sensors and/or actuators or specially designed interaction objects that trigger processes in the superimposed virtual level through physical manipulation ("grasping"). Touchable user interfaces can be used to manipulate digital information (in the literal sense).

Name: Prefetching
Definition: Access in advance. Premature, speculative fetching or provision of data, instruction links, etc., e.g. a machine instruction, while the predecessor is still in progress. Increases the processing speed.

Name: Caching
Definition: A method of accelerating access to a hard disk using a cache.

Name: Sequenzdiagramm
Definition: An interaction diagram that shows the objects involved in a particular interaction and the messages exchanged by them in a chronological sequence. (http://www.infocopter.com/know-how)

Name: Dynamic propositional logic
Definition: A variant of dynamic logic that only allows Boolean variables as program variables.

Name: Klassendiagramm
Definition: A class diagram is used to represent the static design view of a system. (http://www.galileocomputing.de/glossar)

Name: Reinforcement learning Artificial intelligence
Definition: Learning method (machine learning) that does not give an agent (artificial intelligence) or an artificial neural network to be trained an explicit learning goal, but only tells the agent/network after each action whether this action is considered good or bad.

Name: Penetrationstest
Definition: The controlled attempt ("directed hacking") to penetrate a specific computer system or network from the outside in order to identify vulnerabilities. The same or similar techniques that are used in a real attack are used for this purpose. (Federal Office for Information Security)

Name: Metamodell
Definition: Models that serve the specific purpose of specifying a set of models.

Name: Ontology knowledge processing
Definition: 1. an explicit, formal specification of a common conceptualization. 2. a formally defined system of things and/or concepts and relations between these things (Wikipedia). 3. explicit conceptual formalizations of a field of application (knowledge domain). 4. the representation and formalization of knowledge. 5. hierarchical ordering of concepts (W cognitive science). 6. a set of concepts that are related to each other.

Name: Captcha
Alternate Name: Completely automated public Turing-Test to tell computers and human apart
Definition: Fully automated Turing test to distinguish between computers and humans

Name: Smoothed Complexity
Definition: The smoothed complexity is a hybrid of worst-case and average-case complexity

Name: Dijkstra algorithm
Definition: The Dijkstra algorithm finds the shortest path from one node to another in a graph

Name: Wearable Computing
Definition: Research area for the development of wearable computer systems (wearable computers)

Name: Kryptoanalyse
Definition: 1. analysis of cryptographic procedures and encrypted messages with the aim of obtaining keys or plaintext, identifying security vulnerabilities or testing one's own cryptographic procedures.  2. the study of attacks on cryptosystems (an attempted cryptanalysis by a third party is referred to as an attack).

Name: Composite Applications
Definition: Reusing and linking the functionality of existing applications

Name: Multimodal system
Definition: 1. systems that can use several modalities of information transmission (e.g. auditory, gestures, facial expressions and haptics or speech, eye movements, writing, images, etc.) (simultaneously).  2. systems that use or enable (simultaneous) access via different sensory modalities or communication channels.

Name: Vertex Computer Graphics
Definition: In 3D computer graphics, a vertex is the apex of a primitive

Name: Modellgetriebene Entwicklung
Definition: Model-driven software development deals with the automation of software production. Infrastructure code, subsystems, configurations or entire applications are generated from models. (dpunkt.verlag)

Name: Authoring on the Fly
Definition: A technology with which traditional courses can be converted into digital form and published on the Internet. Lectures and presentations can be followed live online, corrected or saved locally on a server for repeated viewing. Combination of lecture recording, teleteaching and the production of multimedia teaching documents.

Name: Anycastingverfahren
Definition: Addressing type in computer networks

Name: Self-serving routing
Definition: Users send data in a network in such a way that their own packets reach their destination as quickly as possible. (Department of Computer Science, University of Lübeck)

Name: Dongle
Definition: Copy protection plugs are used to protect software from unauthorized duplication. (Wikipedia)

Name: Interactive whiteboard
Definition: Computer-aided, touch-sensitive and interactive projection board

Name: Prozessmuster
Definition: Patterns that contain knowledge about activities and procedures (processes) in software development

Name: End-to-end principle
Definition: Placement of functions of a network at its ends; design principle for Internet protocols

Name: Chatbot
Definition: Text-based dialog systems on the Internet

Name: Artificial society
Definition: Computer programs that adopt the robustness, adaptability and creativity of real social systems (Gesellschaft für Informatik)

Name: Sozionik
Definition: Interdisciplinary field of research between sociology and artificial intelligence (KI). The question is whether and how it is possible to develop computer programs capable of communication and cooperation that are based on the model of human society. Just as bionics takes biological bodily functions as a model for technical constructions, socionics sets itself the task of using social processes and structures as inspiration for the design of distributed computer systems. (German Informatics Society)

Name: Time-controlled system
Definition: Time-controlled systems are characterized by the fact that essential aspects of their behaviour are not controlled by external influences (event-controlled system), but by a statically predetermined schedule, whereby this schedule is processed according to a strict time grid. (TTTech Computer Technology)

Name: Vector data type
Definition: Composite data types for listing data or a list of numbers. A one-dimensional array.

Name: Mbus
Definition: A lightweight, message-oriented coordination protocol for group communication between application components. (Dirk Kutscher, University of Bremen)

Name: Miniroboter
Definition: Small robots that can move freely and perform operations independently with the help of their motors, sensors, software, etc.

Name: Medieninformatik
Definition: Media informatics is the science that deals with the theoretical and technical foundations, processing, editing, transmission and presentation of digital media using the means and methods of computer science. (TB Media Informatics)

Name: Webforum
Definition: Discussion forum on a website

Name: ANSI/NISO Z39.89-2003
Definition: US-american. Standard for the use of ANSI/NISO Z39.50-2003 in library applications

Name: Demo program
Definition: 1. variant of a program that is limited in its functional scope, useful life or otherwise.  2. prototype that illustrates the on-screen appearance and sometimes the promised capabilities of a program under development.  3. stand-alone or embedded program that serves to demonstrate the programming and artistic skills of the programmer and at the same time the performance parameters of the platform used, and which also serves as the author's calling card.

Name: Empfehlungssystem
Definition: 1. recommender systems provide a user with recommendations, hints and warnings based on their user characteristics and current context. (software-kompetenz.de) 2. recommender systems attempt to automatically generate recommendations by extracting suggestions from the contributions of other users. (Lex. Wirtschaftsinformatik)

Name: Kollaborative Filterung
Definition: Information is filtered according to the behavior of other users who were previously interested in similar information. (nethics.net)

Name: Phishing
Definition: Attack with the aim of obtaining personal information such as passwords or PIN numbers of the victim. E-mails are sent from apparently well-known companies that lure the victim to a website and ask for personal information. Phishing is a neologism made up of "password" and "fishing"

Name: Rootkit
Definition: Software tools that are installed on the compromised system after a computer system has been broken into in order to hide future logins of the intruder, hide processes, copy data and record input.

Name: Global illumination
Definition: In 3D computer graphics, the simulation of all possibilities for the propagation of light rays in a 3D scene. This completely fulfills the laws of geometric optics and energy conservation and produces a relatively realistic image. (Wikipedia)

Name: Topic map
Definition: Abstract model with SGML- or XML-based data format for the formulation of knowledge ontologies

Name: Nanodot memory
Definition: Information storage with dot-shaped nanostructures for non-volatile data storage

Name: Electronic health card
Definition: Further development of the health insurance card, contains medical data as well as administrative data

Name: Webcam
Definition: Video camera that transmits your recording to the Internet

Name: Computervisualistik
Definition: 1. name for the interdisciplinary computer science degree program, which is currently only offered in Magdeburg and Koblenz. 2. in the overlapping area of computer science and image science, computer visualists work on image science topics using computer science methods. 3. collective term for: Image processing, image understanding (computer vision), pattern recognition, computer graphics and information visualization.

Name: Chip multiprocessor
Definition: Multi-processor system on one chip

Name: Social engineering security
Definition: Manipulation of people based on their good faith. Planning and carrying out attacks on information and systems by exploiting the "human vulnerability". Mainly used in the IT area (stealing passwords)

Name: Personal Area Network
Definition: Wired or wireless ad hoc network (range of a few meters) that small devices such as PDAs or cell phones can set up to communicate with each other or with a larger network

Name: DoS attack
Definition: Attack on a host (server) with the aim of rendering one or more of its services inoperable, usually by overloading it

Name: BSP Computer architecture
Definition: Scalable multi-processor system with global communication space and effective synchronization of the processors

Name: Decentralized data processing
Definition: Form of electronic data processing in which several computers are connected via a computer network, can exchange data and use shared resources, but each perform their own tasks autonomously. (B Computer)

Name: Seitenkanalattacke
Definition: Cryptanalytical method that is theoretically able to break the encryption algorithm of a smart card, security token or similar system with the help of information outside the actual data channel (covert channel). Side channels are, for example, the computing time used, power consumption, electromagnetic radiation, memory requirements, reactions to incorrect entries, etc. (Wikipedia)

Name: World Wide Web 2.0
Definition: Term for the further development and changed perception or use of the WWW. The "new" web is technically based on the widespread availability of a large number of broadband internet access points, which enable users to create and/or edit the content provided on the internet themselves, among other things. Typical examples of this are wikis, weblogs, podcasts and image and video sharing portals. The "new" web is no longer a mere collection of web pages, but a platform for a range of new interactive internet technologies and services.

Name: Soziale Software
Definition: Software systems that support human communication, interaction and collaboration. What these systems have in common is that they support the creation and maintenance of social networks and communities and largely function by means of self-organization. Popular examples include weblogs, wikis, web forums, contact exchanges and special systems for specific topics such as collecting photos.

Name: Kripke structure
Definition: Kripke structures are a formalism widely used in the context of model checking to describe system models.  (http://www.software-kompetenz.de)

Name: LAN-Party
Definition: Event where participants connect their computers to a local network (LAN) to play computer games together

Name: Cybernetics-oriented programming
Definition: New theory in software development

Name: Persistent identifier
Definition: Unique, location-independent identifiers for digital objects that also guarantee permanent access to digital resources

Name: Mustersprache
Definition: Collection of design patterns in software development

Name: Trusted Computing
Definition: Approach to the security of IT systems

Name: Vascoda
Definition: German Internet portal that provides access to scientific information

Name: Geodateninfrastruktur
Definition: A complex network for the exchange of geodata in which geodata producers, geodata service providers and geodata users are linked via a physical data network, usually the Internet.

Name: Functional size measurement
Definition: Software size is understood as the size of software functionality or the process of measuring functional size according to ISO 14143-1

Name: e-Measurement software
Definition: Use of web-oriented technologies in software measurement

Name: Humanoid robot
Definition: Robots that have a human form

Name: Variable length code
Definition: Code that maps source symbols into a variable number of bits; e.g. Huffman code

Name: GEO-LEO
Definition: German Internet portal providing access to scientific information on the subjects of geosciences, mining, geography and thematic maps at: www.geo-leo.de

Name: The European Library
Definition: Web portal that provides access to the collections (books, journals, electronic media), both in digital and non-digital form, of the European national libraries; in existence since 2005

Name: Pairing-based cryptography
Definition: Design of cryptographic systems using computable pairings

Name: Application-specific processor
Definition: Processor for a specific task or application

Name: ANSI/NISO Z39.88-2004
Definition: US-american. Standard, responsible OCLC

Name: Audiovisualisierung
Definition: Calculation of graphics generated from acoustic data to visualize this data

Name: Computer-assisted translation
Definition: Computer-assisted translation refers to the use of computer programs to support translators. Computer-assisted translation should not be confused with automatic translation (without or only with very limited involvement of human translators).

Name: CBRAM
Definition: New storage technology based on solid-state electrolytes

Name: Blu-ray Disc
Definition: Digital optical storage medium developed as a high-definition successor to the DVD

Name: HD-DVD
Definition: Blue laser-written DVD with particularly high storage capacity for digitally stored data, especially films in high-resolution formats.

Name: ASURO
Definition: Freely programmable robot in C, developed by the Institute of Robotics and Mechatronics in Oberpfaffenhofen

Name: Web-Intelligent-System
Definition: Scalable web-based platform with components for collecting and analyzing data about users to create user profiles

Name: Chord communication protocol
Definition: Search protocol for peer-to-peer systems

Name: WebGraph
Definition: WebGraph is a directed graph, where the web pages are the nodes and the hyperlinks are the edges

Name: Predictive coding
Definition: Coding based primarily on predictions and assumptions

Name: Videoportal
Definition: Website that provides videos for streaming (e.g. Youtube, MyVideo, Clipfish)

Name: Cloud computing
Definition: Cloud computing refers to the provision of IT infrastructure and IT services such as storage space, computing power or application software from a service provider via the Internet.

Name: High availability
Definition: Ability of a system to ensure unrestricted operation in the event of failure of one of its components

Name: Hypercomputation
Definition: Computational processes that exceed Turing computability, the Church-Turing thesis (from the template)

Name: Post-quantum cryptography
Definition: Quantum computer-resistant crypto method

Name: Intelligent camera
Definition: Integrated system for machine vision

Name: Europeana
Definition: Internet platform with search function in a selection of European digital libraries, museums and archives. Project based on the infrastructure and experience of the European Library; in existence since November 2008

Name: Data profiling
Definition: Method for analyzing data structure, content and quality

Name: Cross-site scripting
Definition: Exploiting a vulnerability in a web application through malicious script code

Name: Dokumentenserver
Definition: Digital library for publishing and archiving electronic publications in a repository. In contrast to a simple publication on a homepage, the operator of the publication server also takes care of the long-term archiving and indexing of the published documents with the help of bibliographic metadata. Document servers are often used for preprints.

Name: Multiphysics
Definition: Simulation of coupled effects

Name: Physical Computing
Definition: Combining physical systems with software and hardware to create an interactive whole

Name: Sonifikation
Definition: Conversion of data into non-speech sound events or audio information

Name: Telnet
Definition: Protocol for logging on to the Internet

Name: Agent-oriented software engineering
Definition: Software whose structure and functionality is viewed from the perspective of a set of agents

Name: Design Science Computer Science
Definition: Design science is a subfield of information systems and represents innovative, purposeful artifacts (such as mathematical models, software, natural language descriptions) to solve current and future problems in organization and management

Name: Graphics library Programming
Definition: Program library that provides basic functions for graphics output

Name: Bookmark Internet
Definition: Internet address stored by a browser

Name: Core Concerns
Definition: Realizes the core functionality of a system

Name: Koroutine
Definition: In computer science, coroutines are a generalization of the concept of a procedure or function. The fundamental difference between coroutines and procedures is that coroutines can interrupt their flow and resume it later while retaining their status.

Name: Semantic File Carving
Definition: Semantic file carving is a form of file carving that is based on the content analysis of the proposed files.

Name: File Carving
Definition: A process of retrieving and reassembling computer files from fragments, disregarding metadata

Name: Continuous integration
Definition: Process of regular, complete rebuilding and testing in software development

Name: Partial reconfiguration
Definition: Functional parts in FPGA can be reconfigured while other functional units continue to run undisturbed

Name: Web designer
Definition: Further training occupation according to regulations of the Chambers of Industry and Commerce or Chambers of Crafts or according to internal regulations of the course providers

Name: Web-Designerin
Definition: Weiterbildungsberuf nach Regelungen der Industrie- und Handelskammern bzw. Handwerkskammern oder nach internen Vorschriften der Lehrgangsträger

Name: Telematik
Definition: The term telematics was formed from parts of the words "telecommunication" and "information technology" and stands for the joint, integrative application of both technologies.

Name: Linked Data
Definition: Data in WWW (ideally freely available), uniquely identified by Uniform Resource Identifier (URI), directly retrievable by HTTP and enabling semantic structuring through reciprocal linking.

Name: Screencast
Definition: Digital film that records and plays back software functions on the computer screen.

Name: Discovery Service
Definition: Provides own (catalog) data and external data in a comprehensive central search engine index and makes it available to users as a "one-stop store"

Name: World Wide Web 3.0
Definition: Following on from the term Web 2.0, according to John Markoff we speak of Web 3.0 when the concepts of the semantic web are added to the concepts of Web 2.0.

Name: Net neutrality
Definition: Term for the value-neutral transfer of data on the Internet.

Name: Desktop virtualization
Definition: When virtualizing desktop computers, each user works in their own virtual system environment, which in principle behaves like a complete local computer. This differs from the provision of a terminal server, where several users share the resources of a specially configured operating system.

Name: Graphdatenbank
Definition: Database that uses graphs to display and store information.

Name: Distributed hash table
Definition: Data structure for P2P systems

Name: Mobile device management
Definition: Centralized management of mobile devices such as smartphones, sub-notebooks, PDAs or tablet computers by one or more administrators using software

Name: Screenshot
Definition: Recording or output (hard copy, screenshot) of the current screen content or part of it

Name: Sozioinformatik
Definition: Field of computer science that studies the interaction between social groups and software systems

Name: Concast-Kommunikation
Definition: Several transmitters send to a common receiver

Name: Upgrade
Definition: Expansion, extension of the functionality of a software or hardware product

Name: Open Data
Definition: Free availability and usability of data and the movement behind it.

Name: Kopienzahlvariation
Definition: Copy number variation refers to a form of structural variation in the genome that produces variations in the number of copies of a particular DNA segment within a genome.

Name: Cyber-physisches System
Definition: Cyber-physical systems are systems in which information and software technology is connected to mechanical components, with data transfer and exchange as well as monitoring and control taking place in real time via an infrastructure such as the Internet.

Name: Produktionstechnik
Definition: Production technology comprises processes, measures and equipment for the manufacture of new goods.

Name: Machine to Machine
Definition: Automated exchange of information between end devices

Name: Fortgeschrittene elektronische Unterschrift
Definition: The Digital Signature Act distinguishes between simple, advanced and qualified electronic signatures (SigG, §2). The advanced electronic signature is defined in §2 No. 2 of the Digital Signature Act.

Name: Differenzmaschine
Definition: Program-controlled calculating machine, developed by Charles Babbage in 1822

Name: Chipless RFID
Definition: Technology that allows discrete marking with tags without a chip by printing tags directly onto the object

Name: Virtual factory
Definition: A virtual factory is a merger of legally independent, heterogeneous companies with different areas of expertise to form a temporary group of companies. The aim of the virtual factory is to solve temporary orders more efficiently. Virtual factories are created on an ad hoc basis and use the modern possibilities of communication.

Name: Smart Factory
Definition: Production environment in which manufacturing plants and logistics systems largely organize themselves without human intervention.

Name: Tweet
Definition: Message of max. 280 characters that is sent to the user's followers via Twitter; often contains shortened links

Name: Cyberterrorismus
Definition: Terrorism that uses Internet technologies to carry out attacks on computer systems

Name: Mikrorobotik
Definition: Microrobotics includes miniature robots, in particular mobile robots, with dimensions smaller than 1 mm.  The term can also be used for robots that handle components with dimensions in the micrometer range.

Name: Mikroroboter
Definition: Microrobots are miniature robots, usually mobile robots, with geometric dimensions smaller than 1 mm.

Name: Nanorobotik
Definition: Nanorobotics deals with the manufacture of machines and robots with dimensions in the nanometer range. Nanorobotics is a subfield of nanotechnology.

Name: DevOps
Definition: DevOps is a portmanteau of 'Software DEVelopment' and 'Information Technology OPerationS'. It describes models and practices for collaboration and communication between software development and operational IT operations and is intended to cover the entire process of development and productive operation.

Name: Pseudonymisierung
Definition: Pseudonymization means the processing of personal data in such a way that it can no longer be attributed to a specific data subject without the use of separate and protected information.

Name: ω-Sprache
Definition: Sets of infinite words are called ω-languages

Name: Reconfigurable Computing
Definition: Reconfigurable computing is a computer architecture that combines the flexibility of software with the high performance of hardware by using very flexible high-speed computing structures.

Name: Roundtrip engineering
Definition: Roundtrip engineering as a synchronization concept is originally a term from the field of software engineering and ensures the consistency of designs and their implementation. Roundtrip engineering deals with the system: design, product and the connecting transformation procedures.

Name: Cooperative system
Definition: A cooperative system is made up of many actors who pursue common goals through task-related action and with the aid of interaction and coordination mechanisms. For automation technology systems, such as in automotive electronics, traffic control technology and process technology, their implementation in the form of cooperative systems represents an approach for mastering the high complexity and decentralized structure as well as for fulfilling the requirements for robustness and fault tolerance.

Name: ORCID
Definition: Non-proprietary, predominantly numeric code for the unique identification of scientific authors

Name: Second-order cybernetics
Definition: Theory of "cybernetics of cybernetics" or second-order observation founded by Heinz von Foerster

Name: Socio-cyber-physical systems
Definition: Socio-cyber-physical systems are combined systems of socio-technology and cyber-physical systems.

Name: Esoteric programming language
Definition: Programming languages that were not developed for practical use, but to implement unusual language concepts

Name: Semantic Computing
Definition: "Semantic Computing (SC) is defined as "Computing with (machine processable) Descriptions of Content and Intentions." It brings together those disciplines concerned with connecting the (often vaguely formulated) intentions of humans with computational content that includes, but is not limited to, structured and semi-structured data, multimedia data, text, programs, services and, even, network behavior." (https://www.worldscientific.com/page/ijsc/aims-scope)

Name: Hashgraph
Definition: Data structure, consensus algorithm, (de)centralized platform without servers, developed by the company "Swirlds"; alternative system to "blockchain".

Name: Extract Transform Load
Definition: In IT, Extract, Transform, Load (ETL) refers to a process for combining data from multiple data sources, possibly with different structures, in a target database. This process is carried out in three steps, from which the term ETL is derived.

Name: Hashtag
Definition: A key term in a Twitter message (tweet) highlighted by a preceding # sign. The hashtag allows tweets to be searched and analyzed for specific topics (e.g. frequency of use as a characteristic of a thematic trend). Other social networks and media on the internet are also increasingly using hashtags to mark and tag information.

Name: OPNsense
Definition: Open source firewall system; based on "FreeBSD" and the predecessor version "pfSense".

Name: Webentwicklung
Definition: Web development refers to the software development of web applications, web services or other complex websites

Name: Social bots
Definition: Social bots are computer programs that generate communicative activities (e.g. likes, text messages) while pretending that they originate from a (fictitious) human person.

Name: Symbolic execution
Definition: Procedures for the verification and validation of programs

Name: Netzpolitik
Definition: policy field around questions of network culture, media policy and media law.

Name: Troll Internet
Definition: Term used to describe a person who limits their communication on the Internet to posts aimed at emotionally provoking other participants in the conversation.

Name: Internet phenomenon
Definition: Concept in the form of a link or an image, sound, text or video file that spreads quickly via the Internet. The most widespread sub-form is that of a meme spread via the Internet.

Name: Open Science
Definition: Collective term for e.g. Open Access, Open Data, Open Educational Resources, Open Methodology, Open Peer Review, Open Source etc. The aim is to make science more easily accessible to a larger number of people

Name: Digitaler Zwilling
Definition: Digital model of a real object or process. If the physical counterpart exists, its current status can be transferred to the digital twin using sensors and data exchange.

Name: Upload filter
Definition: Server-side software that checks files during upload, rejects them if necessary, modifies them or initiates other measures. Machine data processing is intended to replace human content checks.

Name: Speedrun
Definition: Playing through a computer game in the shortest possible time.

Name: Human-in-the-loop
Definition: Human-in-the-loop is the integration of human intelligence into KI processes in order to continuously train and validate KI models and thus achieve the best results in the long term.

Name: Wissensgraph
Definition: A knowledge graph is a knowledge base that uses a graphically structured data model or a topology to integrate data.

Name: Non-Fungible Token
Definition: Non-replaceable digitally protected object based on a stored character string that cannot be exchanged or copied. The technology is used, for example, to identify digital files such as memes or computer-generated works of art as unique pieces.

Name: Deepfake
Definition: Audiovisual material that has been created or altered and falsified using artificial intelligence and is difficult to distinguish from authentic material.

Name: Data-centric computing
Definition: Data-centric computing describes an information system in which the data is stored independently of the applications and can be updated without cost-intensive and time-consuming data migration.

Name: Bewertungsportal
Definition: Internet portal where users can rate certain services and products

Name: Metaversum
Definition: Metaverse refers to the currently still loose vision of a digital universe that represents a further development of the internet. In the metaverse, participants can use avatars to trade virtual goods, hold meetings in a digital work environment, take part in concerts or live in houses, for example.

Name: Ultra HD Blu-ray
Definition: Successor format to the Blu-ray disc

Name: Sachdaten
Definition: Factual data is data that has no reference to an identified or identifiable natural person.

Name: Datenmodellierung
Definition: Process of schematic mapping of data flows by means of their attributes and relationships

Name: Document term matrix
Definition: Mathematical matrix that describes the frequency with which terms occur in a corpus of documents. The term-document matrix is the corresponding inverse matrix.

Name: Fachverfahren
Definition: Specialist procedures are computer programs that authorities and courts can use to handle regularly occurring structured processes.

Name: NOR gate
Definition: Logic gate that only outputs 1 if both inputs are 0

Name: Autotune

Name: Trainingsdaten

Name: Gesundheitsdaten

Ziel der Zusammenstellung der Software in einem Paket ist es, eine besonders einfache Installation zu erreichen.
